questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about cephalhematoma?

choices.text: It is usually found immediately after birth
It can lead to neonatal jaundice
It usually gets absorbed within 2-4 days
It is usually located on the presenting part of the head

questions.solution:
Cephalhematoma can lead to the development of neonatal jaundice. 

Cephalhematoma is a well-defined swelling that is contained within suture lines and does not cross them. It is a subperiosteal hemorrhage (located between the periosteum of skull bone and the bone). It is not present at the time of birth and usually develops after a few hours/one day. This swelling is usually filled with blood. Hence, the resulting hemolysis leads to the development of jaundice with hyperbilirubinemia in the neonate. Some babies may require phototherapy in severe cases. It resolves within 2 weeks to a few months.

 

Caput succedaneum is an ill-defined swelling over the scalp that is caused by excessive pressure to the neonatal head by the cervix and pelvic walls during vaginal delivery. It presents as a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It is present at the time of delivery. It does not require any treatment and disappears within 1 week of life. Scalp ecchymoses are a feature of this condition.

Sub-galeal hemorrhage is an accumulation of blood underneath the aponeurosis of the scalp (galea aponeurotica). This is also a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It usually occurs due to the rupture of emissary veins and is associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. A timely diagnosis is essential to prevent hypovolemic shock and death of the neonate.

Epidural hemorrhage is an accumulation of blood between the dura mater and the inner surface of the skull. It results from prolonged labor or a fetal head disproportionate to the size of the mother's birth canal. It usually resolves without any complications. 

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with the microabscesses seen in them:

 

Disease Micro-abscess
1. Mycosis fungoides A. Munro’s microabscess
2. Psoriasis vulgaris B. Pautrier’s microabscess 
3. Pemphigus vegetans C. Papillary tip microabscess
4. Dermatitis herpetiformis D. Kogoj’s pustules
  E. Eosinophilic microabscess
questions.solution:
The correct matches are as follows:

Disease Micro-abscess
1. Mycosis fungoides B. Pautrier’s microabscess 
2. Psoriasis vulgaris D. Kogoj’s pustules
3. Pemphigus vegetans E. Eosinophilic microabscess
4. Dermatitis herpetiformis C. Papillary tip microabscess

A microabscess is a focal accumulation of polymorphs, lymphoid cells, or eosinophils in the epidermis, adnexal structures or mucous membranes. Microabscesses are part of the defense mechanisms of the body against pathogens.

Microabscesses are classified as follows:

Based on the location:

  • Epidermal, as seen in psoriasis and candidiasis, or
  • Dermal, as seen in dermatitis herpetiformis and vasculitis.

Based on the predominant cell types seen:

  • Neutrophilic - (eg) psoriasis vulgaris, Reiter's syndrome, impetigo, fungal infections such as candidiasis and dermatophytosis.
  • Lymphocytic - (eg) Mycosis fungoides, allergic contact dermatitis, pityriasis rosea
  • Eosinophilic - (eg) Pemphigus vegetans
  • Mixed (neutrophilic and eosinophilic) (eg) Dermatitis herpetifomis

Pautrier's microabscesses are intraepidermal lymphocytic microabscesses in the absence of marked spongiosis, seen in mycosis fungoides.

 

Spongiform pustules of Kogoj are neutrophilic infiltrates in the Malpighian layer. Munro's microabscess is a neutrophilic microabscess present in the stratum corneum of the skin. Both are seen in psoriasis. Munro microabscess present as well-demarcated red scaly plaques. They might have a circle of clear zone around it which is known as the Woronoff ring. 

 

Remember:  
M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis), and 
P (Pautrier’s microabscess) is seen in M (Mycosis fungoides)

The image below shows subepidermal vesicles and papillary neutrophilic microabscesses in the superficial dermis, seen in dermatitis herpetiformis. 

Other options

While Monro's abscess is also seen in psoriasis, Kogoj's pustules are not seen phemphigus vegitans and eosinophilic microabscess' are not present in dermatitis herpatiformis, therefore making option D incorrect.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl child is brought for a routine health check-up. On examination, the attending physician hears an additional third heart sound. What is this probably due to?

choices.text: Late ventricular filling through active atrial contraction
Vibrations in the ventricular wall during systole
Rapid filling phase of the ventricular diastole
Closure of mitral  and tricuspid valves

questions.solution:
The third heart sound is due to the rapid filling phase of the ventricular diastole.

In about one-third of the way through diastole, a soft low-pitched third heart sound is heard in many normal young individuals. It occurs probably due to the vibrations set up by the inrush of blood during the early phase of ventricular diastole, not during ventricular systole.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer. Immunohistochemistry staining revealed the findings as shown in the image below. Which among the following adjuvant treatments will you provide for this patient?
questions.solution:
The immunohistochemistry staining shown in the above image is ER+, PR+, and HER2+, which is triple positive or luminal type B. The adjuvant treatment of choice for this patient is endocrine therapy + chemotherapy + trastuzumab.

Positive staining is indicated by the presence of brown-colored tissue.

  • The Estrogen receptor (ER) and Progesterone receptor (PR) are both nuclear receptors, hence, the nucleus is stained brown if positive.
  • The human epidermal growth factor receptor type 2 (HER2) is a membrane receptor, hence the cell membrane is stained brown if positive.

The image below shows positive and negative staining for ER, PR, and HER2:

 

The adjuvant treatment modalities currently in practice include:

  • Endocrine treatment such as tamoxifen or ovarian suppression. It is given to patients with tumours that are hormone receptor-positive (either ER+ or PR+).
  • Anti-HER2 therapy with trastuzumab (humanized monoclonal antibody). It is given to patients with tumours that are HER2 overexpressing.
  • Chemotherapy as per the American Society of Clinical Oncology guidelines should be considered for patients with positive lymph nodes, HER2-positive disease, tumors >5 mm, triple-negative tumors, or with lympho-vascular invasion.

questions.text:
A patient with asthma is being evaluated. His FEV1 values were measured before and after the administration of a short-acting beta-agonist. Which of the following values represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in this condition?

FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first minute

FVC - Forced vital capacity

choices.text: > 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1
> 50% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 500 mL increase in FEV1
> 20% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 410 mL increase in FEV1
> 6% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 100 mL increase in FEV1

questions.solution:
Reversibility of obstruction in asthma has to be demonstrated by a minimum of 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1 in response to inhalation of short-acting beta-agonist (SABA).

In asthma, there is reversible bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, breathlessness, and cough. Thus, on administering a SABA, there is bronchial relaxation and relief of symptoms. 

Asthma is generally diagnosed clinically based on symptoms alone. However, there are a number of other conditions that can be misdiagnosed as asthma such as causes of wheeze (bronchogenic carcinoma, foreign body aspiration), cough (gastroesophageal reflux, chronic bronchitis, rhinitis), and dyspnea (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pulmonary edema, or obesity). Misdiagnosis would lead to a delay in management. Thus, it is ideal that the clinical diagnosis of asthma is confirmed by pulmonary function tests. 

  • Spirometry: It is a non-invasive investigation that can be used to approximate lung volumes. This shows an obstructive pattern
    • Decreased FEV1
    • Decreased or normal FVC
    • Decreased FEV1/FVC
  • Bronchodilator reversibility: Spirometry is performed both before and after inhalation of a short-acting bronchodilator (400 mcg of β2 agonist or 160 mcg of anticholinergic). A 12% and 200 mL increase in FEV1 compared to pre-bronchodilator value is diagnostic of asthma in adults. 
  • Bronchial provocation test: Provocative stimulus (histamine, methacholine, inhaled mannitol, exercise, eucapnic hyperventilation with dry or cold air) is used to test the presence of airway hyperresponsiveness.  A fall of ≥20% in FEV1 from baseline, with a standard dose of methacholine (methacholine challenge test), is diagnostic of asthma.
  • Peak expiratory flow (PEF): PEF readings are taken twice daily for over 2 weeks. The average daily diurnal PEF variability of >10% is diagnostic of asthma in adults.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding antrochoanal polyp?
  1. It is more common in older adults
  2. It grows posteriorly and may hang below the soft palate
  3. It usually arises from the maxillary sinus
  4. It is allergic in origin and recurrence is common
  5. It is usually multiple and bilateral
questions.solution:
Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoid masse of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum (Statement 3), comes out of it, and grows backward to the choana and nasal cavity and may hang below the soft palate (Statement 2).

It is usually infective in origin (Statement 4). It is usually single and unilateral (Statement 5) which are more commonly seen in children (Statement 1) and young adults.  

  Antrochoanal Polyp Ethmoidal Polyp
Age Young Adults
Etiology Infective Allergic / Multifactorial
Numer Single Multiple
Site Unilateral Bilateral
Origin Maxillary sinus Ethmoidal Sinus, uncinate process, middle turbinate and middle meatus
Growth Grows posteriorly towards the choana. May hang back behind the soft palate in the pharynx Grows anteriorly towards the nares
Appearance Trilobed with antral, nasal and choanal parts.  Small and grape-like masses
Recurrence Uncommon Common
Treatment Endoscopic sinus surgery Endoscopic sinus surgery

 

Related Pearl: Antrochoanal Polyp

  • Main etiological factors: Infection and allergy
  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum
  • Clinical features:
    • Usually single and unilateral
    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice
  • Findings:
    • Grows posteriorly and usually missed on anterior rhinoscopy
    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation: Nasal endoscopy: Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated. NonContrast CT scan: Gives exquisite bony detail of the paranasal sinus anatomy. It is the primary diagnostic imaging modality.
  • Treatment of choice: FESS

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida in her 28th week of gestation was found to have an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 4 cm. Which among the following USG findings can be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of an amniotic fluid index (AFI) less than 5 cm suggests oligohydramnios. The USG finding of key-hole sign is associated with a posterior urethral valve which is a cause of oligohydramnios. 

The USG below shows the key-hole sign seen in posterior urethral valves:


Oligohydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume less than 200 ml
  • AFI less than 5 cm
  • The maximum vertical pocket of liquor is less than 2 cm

Polyhydramnios is defined as:

  • Amniotic fluid volume of more than 2L
  • AFI more than 25 cm
  • A deepest vertical pocket is more than 8 cm 

Option A: Banana sign on USG is seen in spina bifida associated with Arnold-Chiari malformation. An abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum along with effacement of the cisterna magna produces this appearance.  

Option B: Frog eye sign on USG is seen in anencephaly. It refers to the absence of cranial calvaria resulting in prominent orbits thereby resembling the face of a frog. Anencephaly is associated with polyhydramnios.

Option D: Lemon sign on USG is seen in neural tube defects such as spina bifida. Axial USG of the fetal head at the level of the biparietal diameter shows inward concavity of both frontal bones instead of the normally seen convexity. This gives the head the appearance of a lemon.

questions.text:
Arrange the following parts of the gastrointestinal tract according to the rate of basic electrical rhythm from highest to lowest.
  1. Sigmoid colon
  2. Caecum
  3. Distal ileum
  4. Duodenum
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 4→3→1→2 ie. duodenum→distal ileum→sigmoid colon→caecum.

The rate of basal electrical rhythm (BER) in various sites is

  • Duodenum: 12/min
  • Distal ileum: 8/min
  • Sigmoid colon: 6/min
  • Stomach: 4/min
  • Cecum: 2/min

The smooth muscle of the GIT, has spontaneous rhythmic fluctuations in the membrane potential called basic electrical rhythm (BER)  which is initiated by the interstitial cells of Cajal (−65 and −45 mV). The BER is seen in all sites of gastrointestinal smooth muscle except in the esophagus and proximal stomach.

The BER itself rarely causes muscle contraction, but spike potentials superimposed on the most depolarizing portions of the BER waves do. 

Acetylcholine causes an increase in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.
Epinephrine causes a decrease in the number of spike potentials and muscle tension.

questions.text: Name the ligament through which the left gastric artery passes and identify the embryological origin of this ligament in the image.
questions.solution:
The left gastric artery is present in the hepatogastric ligament, which is a part of the lesser omentum. The lesser omentum is derived from the ventral mesentery marked as B in the image given.

The structures marked in the image are:

A: Dorsal mesentery
B: Ventral mesentery

 

Mesenteries are double layers of the peritoneum that enclose an organ and connect it to the body wall. They provide pathways for vessels, nerves, and lymphatics to and from the abdominal viscera.

Ventral mesentery: Only the foregut has a ventral mesentery. It is attached to the terminal part of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper part of the duodenum. The ventral mesentery is derived from the septum transversum. When the liver grows into the mesenchyme of the septum transversum, it divides the ventral mesentery into 2 parts:  

  • Lesser omentum- extends from the lower portion of the esophagus, the stomach, and the upper portion of the duodenum to the liver. It contains the hepatogastric and hepatoduodenal ligaments. The hepatoduodenal ligament contains the portal triad. (Option A, B)
  • Ligaments of the liver- all ligaments of the liver (falciform ligament, right and left triangular ligaments, and coronary ligaments), except ligamentum teres

Dorsal mesentery: The foregut, midgut, and hindgut have dorsal mesentery. This connects the organs to the posterior abdominal wall. It runs from the lower end of the esophagus to the cloacal region of the hindgut. It has the following special names in different regions:

  • Dorsal mesogastrium (or greater omentum)- stomach 
  • Dorsal mesoduodenum- duodenum
  • Mesentery proper- jejunum and ileum
  • Mesoappendix- appendix
  • Transverse mesocolon- transverse colon
  • Sigmoid mesocolon- sigmoid colon
  • Gastrosplenic ligament (stomach to the spleen), lienorenal ligament (spleen to the left kidney), and gastrophrenic ligament (stomach to diaphragm) are derived from the dorsal mesentery.

questions.text: Which of the following testicular tumors are correctly matched with the corresponding tumor markers?
questions.solution:
Embryonal carcinomas are OCT3/4 +ve, cytokeratin +ve, KIT -ve, and podoplanin -ve.

Tumor markers are substances (eg. enzymes, antigens) that are detectable in the blood or tissue pathology of cancer patients. They can aid in tumor diagnosis, monitoring treatment response, and detecting cancer recurrence. Tumor markers immunohistochemistry of testicular tumors are particularly helpful in aiding diagnosis. 

Embryonal carcinomas on immunohistochemistry stain positive for OCT3/4 and cytokeratin. They are negative for KIT and podoplanin (option D). 

Seminomas on immunohistochemistry stain positive for OCT3/4, KIT, and podoplanin (option C). They stain negative for cytokeratin (option A).

questions.text:
A 26-year-old female with endometritis did not complete the course of antibiotics she was prescribed. Following this, her infection failed to resolve and she developed a tubo-ovarian mass. How can this mass manifest?
  1. Tubo-ovarian cyst
  2. Hydrosalpinx
  3. Twisted ovarian cyst
  4. Chronic pyosalpinx
  5. Ruptured endometriotic cyst
questions.solution:
The given scenario of development of a chronic tubo-ovarian mass following acute PID points towards a diagnosis of chronic PID. A chronic tubo-ovarian mass can manifest as a tubo-ovarian cyst, hydrosalpinx or even a chronic pyosalpinx.

Failure to complete treatment of acute PID or drug resistance can lead to the development of chronic PID. This can lead to the development of chronic tubo-ovarian masses which may manifest as:

  • Hydrosalpinx
  • Chronic pyosalpinx
  • Chronic interstitial salpingitis
  • Tubo-ovarian cyst
  • Tuberculous form

A twisted ovarian cyst and a ruptured endometriotic cyst are differential diagnoses of acute PID.

questions.text: You are interpreting data collected from a city to write a research paper on the extent of pollution in it. You come across the soiling index. What is it an indicator of?
questions.solution:
The soiling index or smoke index is an indicator of air pollution.

The soiling index is a measure of the total suspended particulate matter in air. A known air volume is filtered through a white filter paper, and the stain is measured by a photoelectric meter. It is expressed as micrograms/ cubic meters of air over a certain period. The best indicators of air pollution include sulfur dioxide, smoke, and suspended particles. 

Currently, the Air Quality Index (AQI) is the most commonly used tool for the air quality status and severity of pollution. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature, and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration  to calculate the AQI -

  • PM10 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  • PM2.5 (airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  • NO2 (nitrogen dioxide)
  • SO2 (sulfur dioxide)
  • CO (carbon monoxide)
  • O3 (ozone)
  • NH3 (ammonia)
  • Pb (lead)

The National AQI categories and the range are as follows :

AQI Category AQI Range
Good 0 - 50
Satisfactory 51 - 100
Moderate 101 - 200
Poor 201 - 300
Very poor 301 - 400
Severe 401 - 500

 

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

Indicators of air pollution:

questions.text: A patient in the labor room is being evaluated with a cardiac tocography. Uterine contractions are estimated at 7 contractions per 10 minutes. She is receiving IV Pitocin. Which of the following intervention should be done next?
questions.solution:
This patient with 7 uterine contractions in 10 minutes has developed tachysystole, associated with late decelerations shown in the image above. This is likely secondary to excessive pitocin infusion. Pitocin is an oxytocin analogue. The next step in this patient would be to stop the infusion of pitocin immediately. 

Oxytocin is a hormonal drug that is used in obstetrics. It is used for induction and augmentation of labour. Sometimes, the drug can be given in high concentrations and can lead to complications like tachysystole and hyponatremia. 

Tachysystole (Hypertonic uterine dysfunction):

  • The uterine contractions are uncoordinated and increase in frequency (>5 contractions in 10 minutes) without rest in between and also increase in the baseline tone.
  • It is associated with late active phase dysfunction (not latent). i.e. when the cervix is almost 7 cm dilated.
  • The most common cause is occipito posterior presentation. Hence, a wait-and-watch policy is adopted.
  • More common in nulliparous females
  • Oxytocin administration leads to hyperstimulation of the uterus. Hence, it is not recommended. If the patient is already receiving it, the infusion must be immediately stopped.

Other options:

Option B and C: As this graph shows late decelerations, urgent intervention is required. Maternal repositioning and amnioinfusion is used for the conservative management of variable decelerations. It will not help in late decelerations.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presenting with headaches was found to have increased aldosterone levels and low renin levels. Excess secretion of aldosterone can cause all except ________
questions.solution:
Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually <4-6 mEq/L rise in plasma sodium. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.

This patient with high blood pressure with high aldosterone levels and low renin levels most likely has Conn's syndrome. 

Conn’s syndrome or primary hyperaldosteronism is due to an aldosterone producing tumour of the zona glomerulosa, causing:

  • Loss of potassium by the kidneys leading to hypokalemia.
  • Mild metabolic alkalosis.
  • A slight increase in extracellular fluid volume and blood volume.
  • A modest increase in plasma sodium concentration.
  • Hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following set of immunophenotype markers are observed in nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
The immunophenotype markers observed in nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma are CD15-, CD30-, CD20+, and EBV-.

Hodgkin’s lymphoma is classified into 5 subtypes. Most have a unique variant of the Reed-Sternberg (RS) cell and differentiating features on immunophenotyping. 

The nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma is an uncommon and "non-classic" variant of Hodgkin's lymphoma. It is non-classic as the characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells are difficult to find in histopathology. It is characterized by the popcorn cell, which is a lymphohistiocytic (L&H) variant with multilobed nuclei. This is demonstrated in the image below:

 

In contrast to the classic form of Hodgkin lymphoma, L&H variants express B-cell markers such as CD20 and BCL6. They are negative for CD15 and CD30. EBV is usually not associated with this subtype. 

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

  • Pleomorphic/Necrotic/Mummified Variant: Lymphocyte depleted 
  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: Hyperpolarization in response to a stimulus is seen in ______.
questions.solution:
The rod receptor potential differs from other surface receptors in that it shows hyperpolarization.

In most sensory receptors: Arrival of stimulus → Ion channels are opened up allowing current to flow => depolarisation of the receptor.

In photoreceptors: When the light strikes the outer segment, a cascade of reactions (refer image below) are initiated, that close some of the Na+ channels in the outer segment, resulting in hyperpolarization.

questions.text: An 8-week-old baby presents with jaundice. No improvement was noticed following phototherapy. Laboratory studies showed a total serum bilirubin of 14 mg/dl and 2 mg/dl of indirect bilirubin. Which of the following is the underlying pathophysiology of this patient's jaundice?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an 8-week-old baby presenting with jaundice that does not improve on phototherapy, and elevated direct (conjugated) bilirubin (total - indirect bilirubin = 12 mg/dL) indicates impaired bilirubin excretion. 

Neonatal jaundice can be classified as conjugated (direct) or unconjugated (indirect) hyperbilirubinemia.

Causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia can be further divided into:

  • Extrahepatic - due to impaired bilirubin excretion. The conditions associated with this include biliary atresia and choledochal cysts.
  • Intrahepatic - due to impaired liver function or impaired hepatic secretion of bilirubin. The conditions associated with this include Rotor syndrome, Dubin-Johnson syndrome, cystic fibrosis, or TORCH infections. 

The causes of neonatal unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia include increased bilirubin production (option B). It is observed in patients with hemolytic diseases. Another cause is reduced glucuronosyltransferase activity (option C), which is observed in Gilbert and Crigler-Najjar syndrome. It results in decreased conjugation of bilirubin.

Reduced serum bilirubin binding (option A) can be observed in patients with low albumin, as albumin is required for solubilizing unconjugated bilirubin. This condition is characterized by an increase in unconjugated bilirubin, as opposed to direct bilirubin, as seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 45-year-old farmer presents with a 2-year history of on-and-off abdominal pain, recurrent cough, and intermittent diarrhea. A stool wet mount image is shown below. Which of the following is the likely causative organism and mode of acquisition of this infection?

choices.text: Ascaris, ingestion of infective eggs in contaminated soil or food
Strongyloides, ingestion of infective eggs in contaminated soil or food
Ascaris, skin penetration by filariform larvae or internal autoinfection
Strongyloides, skin penetration by filariform larvae or internal autoinfection

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the wet mount showing rhabditiform larva in the stool indicate that the likely causative organism is Strongyloides and the likely mode of acquisition is via skin penetration by filariform larvae or internal autoinfection.  

Strongyloides exhibits autoinfection within the host. Filariform larvae can develop from eggs within the intestine, penetrate the intestinal wall, and migrate through the bloodstream to the lungs, then back to the gut, completing the cycle. This continuous reinfection can explain the chronic and recurrent symptoms in the patient.

The rhabditiform larva (not the egg) in feces can be seen under a microscope, and eosinophilia in the blood is diagnostic of the disease.

 

The worm is ovoviviparous. The eggs contain fully formed larvae that hatch out immediately. Characteristics of the egg of Strongyloides stercoralis: thin-walled, transparent, ovoid in shape and contain the rhabditiform (first stage) larva.

Strongyloidiasis (infection caused by S. stercoralis) is generally benign and asymptomatic. The clinical disease may have cutaneous (dermatitis at the site of penetration, perianal pruritis, urticaria), pulmonary (bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, asthma) and intestinal manifestations (mucus diarrhea, dysentery).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the condition shown in the given image?

choices.text: Autosomal dominant inheritance may be seen

questions.solution:
The given image shows a keloid scar. Keloids can be inherited as autosomal dominant with incomplete penetration.

A keloid scar is defined as excessive scar tissue that extends beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound. Its etiology is unknown, but is associated with elevated levels of growth factor, inherited tendencies, darker skin, and racial predilection among African-Americans, Asian and Hispanics (Option A).  

The underlying abnormality of keloid scars is the excessive accumulation of collagen with hypervascularity. It can arise from surgery, burns, skin inflammation, infections, ear piercing, and even spontaneously. It occurs 3 months to years after the initial insult with even minor injuries causing keloid formation. Commonly affected areas are the skin of the earlobe, deltoid, presternal area, and upper back.

The histology of keloid scars shows excess, thick, wavy collagen fibers in random orientation (predominantly type 3 collagen). Keloids do not improve spontaneously (Option B) with time and have a high rate of recurrence following excision, but contractures rarely develop (Option C). 

Treatment options:

  • Pressure- local moulds or elastic garments
  • Silicone gel sheeting
  • Intralesional triamcinolone injection
  • Excision and steroid injections
  • Excision and postoperative radiation (external beam or brachytherapy)
  • Intralesional excision
  • Laser to reduce redness
  • Vitamin E and palm oil massage

questions.text: An arterial and a venous blood sample is drawn from a patient and a complete blood count is done separately for both samples. The test results report a high packed cell volume (PCV) in venous blood. What is the reason behind the high PCV in the venous sample?
questions.solution:
Hematocrit (PCV) of venous blood is normally 3% greater than that of arterial blood because of 2 reasons: 

  • Chloride shift(Hamburger phenomenon)
  • A small amount of fluid in the arterial blood returns via the lymphatics rather than the veins leading to decreased fluid in the venous blood.

For every CO2 molecule added in a RBC, an additional ion like Cl- or HCO3- is added which takes up water and leads to an increase in size of the cell leading to an increase in PCV. The combined effect of decreased fluid in the veins combined with the increased cellular mass due to the Hamburger phenomenon leads to the overall increase in PCV.

Chloride shift:

  • Upon entering the red blood cell, CO2 is rapidly hydrated to H2CO3 by carbonic anhydrase.
  • H2CO3 is in equilibrium with H+ and its conjugate base, HCO3-.
  • H+ can interact with deoxyhemoglobin, whereas HCO3- can be transported outside of the cell via anion exchanger 1 (AE1 or Band 3).
  • In effect, for each CO2 molecule that enters the red cell, there is an additional HCO3- or Cl- in the cell.
  • Because of this chloride shift, the Cl – content of the red cells in venous blood is significantly greater than that in arterial blood.\

Other options:

Options A and B: Haldane effect is the increased capacity of deoxygenated haemoglobin to bind and carry CO2, Bohr's effect is the decrease in O2 affinity of haemoglobin when the pH of the blood falls.

Option D: 2,3 BPG is formed from glycolysis. It is found in high amounts in red blood cells and in trace amounts in most other cells. 2,3 BPG facilitates increased oxygen delivery by reducing the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen.

questions.text: A 57-year-old unresponsive male patient is brought to the hospital. He is pulseless and is not breathing. His lead II ECG rhythm strip is shown in the image below. What is the treatment for the given ECG abnormality?
questions.solution:
The ECG with no identifiable P wave, QRS complexes, and irregular rhythm is ventricular fibrillation (VF) and the treatment is defibrillation. 

Ventricular fibrillation is a disorganized ventricular rhythm. In a heart with ventricular fibrillation, there is little to no cardiac output as there is irregular cardiac contraction. In patients outside the hospital, sustained ventricular tachycardias are a common cause leading to ventricular fibrillation.

VF is a shockable rhythm. Thus, defibrillation must be performed in order to restore normal sinus rhythm according to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) guidelines. In defibrillation, an electrical current is passed into the myocardium which 'resets' it by converting the dysrhythmia into a normal sinus rhythm. 

When the timing of electric current is adjusted according to the R waves or the QRS complex of the cardiac cycle, it is known as synchronized shock, which is administered in cardioversion. In ventricular fibrillation, because of irregular cardiac electrical activity, there are no R waves or QRS complexes to which the cardioversion can be synchronized. Hence, it is administered unsynchronized to the cardiac cycle.

 

Other options:

Option A - Magnesium sulfate is used to treat torsades de points. It is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. 

Options C and D - Synchronised cardioversion and rate control are used to treat atrial fibrillation (AF). AF has normal QRS complexes with variable atrial activity resulting in irregular P waves of varying morphology.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true regarding leukocyte recruitment and extravasation in response to injury?

PECAM: Platelet Endothelial Cell Adhesion Molecule
VCAM: Vascular Cell Adhesion Molecule

choices.text: P-selectin is expressed only on platelets
Integrins mediate initial leukocyte margination and rolling
PECAM-1 or CD31 is involved in diapedesis
VCAM-1 is a ligand for selectin molecules

questions.solution:
PECAM-1 (platelet endothelial cell adhesion molecule) or CD31 is involved in the diapedesis of leukocytes in response to injury.

The first steps in leukocyte recruitment involve leukocyte margination, rolling, and adhesion to the endothelium. Subsequently, there is migration across the endothelium and vessel wall, known as transmigration or diapedesis. The final step involves the migration of leukocytes to the site in tissues through the process of chemotaxis. The process is demonstrated in the image below.


Margination: Redistribution of leukocytes along the peripheral wall of venules is known as margination.

Leukocyte rolling: Sensing endothelial signals, the slowed leukocytes roll across the endothelial surface. Factors involved in leukocyte rolling include:

  • Selectins:
    • E-selectin - present on endothelium;
    • L-selectin - present on leukocytes;
    • P selectin - present both on platelets and endothelium (option A)
  • Sialyl-Lewis glycoproteins: Ligand for selectin molecules.

Leukocyte adhesion: Leukocytes then firmly adhere to the endothelium with the help of:

  • Integrins: Beta-1 integrin VLA-4; Beta-2 integrins LFA-1 & MAC-1 (option B)
  • VCAM -1 (vascular cell adhesion molecule), ICAM-1 (inter-cellular adhesion molecule): Ligands on the endothelium that bind to integrin molecules (option D)

Transmigration or diapedesis: The process of leukocyte transmigration through the intact endothelium is known as diapedesis. This is mediated by PECAM-1 or CD31, which is a member of the immunoglobulin superfamily.

Chemotaxis: Once leukocytes have exited the circulation, they move towards the inciting stimulus by chemotaxis. This process is mediated by:

  • Exogenous chemoattractants, such as bacterial products.
  • Endogenous chemoattractants: cytokines of the chemokine family (e.g., IL-8), components of the complement system (particularly C5a), and arachidonic acid (AA) metabolites (mainly leukotriene B4).

questions.text: A girl presented with itching and oozing from an earlobe lesion after wearing nickel earrings. What test will you do to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of allergic contact dermatitis and the diagnosis is made by a patch test.

Allergic contact dermatitis is a reaction to a substance (allergen) that causes an eruption only in those individuals previously sensitized by the same molecule. It is a delayed-type of hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. It presents as pruritis and an eczematous eruption in sites where contact has taken place with the etiological agent/allergen.

Nickel is the most frequent contact allergen. Most of its salts, for example, nickel chloride and nickel sulfate, are readily soluble in water and sweat and have strong sensitizing properties. Jewelry and metal components of clothing are the usual sources of nickel in prolonged contact with the skin. 

Patch tests are used to identify the etiologic agent(s) of allergic contact dermatitis. Patches are usually applied to the back and removed 48 hours after application. The skin where the patch was applied is examined with readings taken 1 hour after removal and again 48 hours later.

The image below shows a picture of a skin patch allergy test:

 

Treatment of includes

  • Avoidance of the allergen (for example, further use of nickel‐plated objects should be avoided in this case)
  • A topical clioquinol–steroid combination can be considered as a treatment (clioquinol is known to chelate nickel)

questions.text: The blood culture of a patient with unexplained fevers shows the growth of gram-positive cocci in clusters. Which of the following tests would be useful in differentiating the pathogenic strain from the normal skin flora?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of a patient with fever growing gram positive cocci in clusters is suggestive of bacteremia with Staphylococcus aureus, an organism that is not part of normal skin flora. Other staphylococci, especially Staphylococcus epidermidis, may contaminate blood cultures and can be differentiated from Staphylococcus aureus by the coagulase test.

 

S. aureus is a gram-positive coccus arranged in grape-like clusters. S. aureus is coagulase and catalase positive. 

The coagulase test helps differentiate Staphylococcus aureus (positive) from other Coagulase Negative Staphylococcus (CONS) species. Coagulase is an enzyme produced by S. aureus that converts soluble fibrinogen in plasma to insoluble fibrin. CONS are a part of normal human flora and they include S. epidermidis, S. haemolyticus, S. lugdonensis and S. saprophyticus. 

Other options:

Option A: Novobiocin resistance test is used to differentiate between S. epidermidis

(novobiocin sensitive) and S. saprophyticus (novobiocin resistant). Both these species are part of CONS. 

Option B: Optochin resistance differentiates the major pathogenic alpha-hemolytic streptococci. S. pneumoniae is optochin sensitive whereas S. viridans is resistant to optochin. 

Option D: Catalase test is used to differentiate streptococci from staphylococci. Streptococci grow in chains and not as clusters.

questions.text: What is the appearance of colonies produced by Salmonella on Wilson and Blair medium?

choices.text: Jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen
Transparent colonies with a green center

questions.solution:
Jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen are produced by Salmonella on Wilson and Blair medium.

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet-black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on the Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. The Wilson and Blair medium is selective for Salmonella species. It is a type of selective and indicator media. It also serves as a differential media. While S. typhi forms large black colonies with a metallic sheen, Salmonella paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

An image of Wilson and Blair medium is given below:


On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salt-sucrose agar (TCBS) agar:

  • Vibrio cholerae forms yellow colonies. 

 

  • Vibrio vulnificus may form colorless colonies.
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus forms transparent colonies with a green center.

questions.text: A medical officer is conducting a case-control study and employs matching to select controls similar to the cases. Which of the following types of bias is likely to be reduced as a result?
questions.solution:
Matching controls to be similar to the cases is likely to reduce confounding bias or bias due to confounding factors.

A confounding factor is one that is related to both exposure and disease and is distributed unequally in study and control groups. Irrespective of being associated with the exposure under study, the confounding factor might itself serve as a risk factor for the disease. Hence, the elimination of these confounding factors is essential before carrying out a case-control study. 

Matching, which is usually done in analytical studies (such as a case-control study), is the process where the participants in two groups (cases and controls in this case) are matched based on factors that are known to influence the outcome of disease (such as age, gender, race, etc.) to stop the potential confounders from distorting the results.

Other strategies to eliminate confounding factors include randomization, stratified randomization, and restriction.

Other options:
Option A - Recall bias in case-control studies occurs because history recollection is better in the case group as they have a stronger exposure than the control group. This bias can be reduced by decreasing the recall period as much as possible.

Option C - Selection bias is a type of sampling bias that occurs because of the nonrandom allocation of subjects such that the study population is not representative of the target population. The best way to reduce this is by randomization to create groups with similar distributions of known and unknown variables. 

Option D - Interviewer bias is a type of bias that occurs because the interviewer is aware of the case group and the hypothesis being tested, which can influence interviews and analysis. This can be reduced by blinding to reduce their influence on interviews and interpretation of outcomes.

questions.text:
Which of the following are examples of ligand-gated receptors?
  1. GABAA receptor
  2. GABAB receptor
  3. GABAC receptor
  4. Nicotinic Ach receptor
  5. Muscarinic Ach receptor
questions.solution:
GABAA, GABAC, and nicotinic Ach (1,3,4)receptors are examples of ligand-gated receptors.

Receptors for neurotransmitters are classified into two broad families based on structure and function. They are:

  • Ligand-gated channels (Ionotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, a membrane channel is opened leading to a brief increase in ionic conductance.
    • Important for fast synaptic transmission.
    • Examples - GABAA, GABAC, Nicotinic cholinergic, Glycine, and Serotonin (5HT3 subtype).
  • G-protein coupled receptors (Metabotropic receptors)
    • When bound to these receptors, secondary messengers are released that modulate voltage-gated channels on neuronal membranes.
    • Examples - GABAB, Muscarinic cholinergic, Catecholamines, Serotonin (all subtypes except 5HT3), and opioid receptors.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the organism shown below?
  1. Catalase positive 
  2. Catalase negative
  3. Normal commensal in the upper respiratory tract of most of the children.
  4. Most common cause of meningitis in adults.
  5. Production of beta-lactamase is the common mode of resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics.
questions.solution:
The given gram stain showing gram-positive diplococci appearing in paired/short chains is suggestive of Streptococcus pneumoniae. Statements 2,3 and 4 are true regarding Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Gram-positive cocci are differentiated based on the catalase test. Staphylococci are catalase-positive while streptococci are catalase-negative (statements 1,2).

S.pneumoniae also called pneumococcus is a capsulated bacteria with polysaccharide capsule. They are non-motile facultative anaerobes and capnophiles. It is optochin-sensitive and gives a positive bile solubility test. When grown on blood agar, the colonies are alpha-hemolytic with zones of greening.

The below image shows different types of hemolysis:

 

Streptococcus pneumoniae is normal commensal in upper respiratory tract flora in 70-90 % of children and most adults. (statement 3). It can cause otitis media, sinusitis and acute exacerbation of COPD. It is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia overall and meningitis in adults (statement 4). Other diseases are endocarditis, osteomyelitis and septic arthritis.

The drug of choice is amoxicillin in mild cases and parenteral penicillin in severe cases. The most common method of resistance to beta-lactam drugs is the alteration in the penicillin-binding proteins on the bacterial surface not the production of beta-lactamase(statement 5).

Prophylaxis - Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) 13: WHO recommends 3 primary doses or 2 primary doses plus one booster of the PCV vaccine. In India, 2 primary doses at 6 and 14 weeks and 1 booster is given at 9-12 months.

Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine(PPSV23): Children under 2 years of age and immunocompromised individuals do not respond well to the vaccine. It is recommended for post-splenectomy, sickle-cell disease, generalized malignancies and organ transplantation cases.

questions.text: A precipitation test yielded a negative result in a patient with suspected syphilis. However, all his symptoms, signs, and risk factors are strongly suggestive of syphilis. Which of the following reasons best explains this outcome?

choices.text: The patient lacks antibodies against syphilis.
The antigen-antibody ratio was optimal for precipitation.
Sample antigen concentration exceeds antibody binding sites.
Non-specific test antigen used, leading to cross reactivity with other antibodies.

questions.solution:
The patient's symptoms suggest syphilis infection, but the negative precipitation test result indicates a mismatch between antibody and antigen levels. The most likely explanation for the negative test result is excessive antigen concentration in the patient's serum sample, exceeding the available antibody binding sites (post-zone phenomenon). With excess antigen, antibody binding sites become saturated, preventing lattice formation and visible precipitation. This leads to a false-negative result.

The lattice hypothesis explains precipitation reactions and agglutination reactions. The amount of precipitate formed is influenced by the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation occurs when a lattice consisting of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.

 

The prozone phenomenon is caused by excessive antibodies in the test system. There is weak/absent precipitation, giving a false-negative test.

In the zone of equivalence, antigen and antibody are in optimum proportions and maximum precipitation occurs. Lattice formation is enhanced.

Post-zone phenomenon is due to the presence of excessive antigens in the test system. There is weaker/absent precipitation.

Prozone phenomenon and post-zone phenomenon can give rise to false-negative results in precipitation reactions. This can be overcome by making serial dilutions of serum, thereby optimizing the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

Other options: 

Option A: This can be ruled out since the patient exhibits clear symptoms.

Option B: This is unlikely because a negative result suggests insufficient precipitation.

Option D: Cross-reactivity usually leads to weak positive results due to non-specific binding with other antibodies. A completely negative result, as in this case, is less typical.

questions.text: A mother brings her infant after noticing the child is dyspnoeic. An echocardiogram showed multiple masses in the ventricles causing obstruction to blood flow. Following surgical resection, the histopathologic reports of the mass showed spider cells. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An infant's echocardiogram showing multiple cardiac masses in the ventricle which on histopathology shows spider cells suggests a likely diagnosis of rhabdomyoma.

Rhabdomyomas are the most common pediatric primary cardiac tumor and are seen during the first years of life. They are commonly noted during evaluation for valvular or other flow obstructive causes. Around one-half of the cardiac rhabdomyomas are due to sporadic mutations while the other half are associated with tuberous sclerosis

They are gray-white myocardial masses that are usually multiple in number and are mostly seen involving the ventricles and protruding into the lumen. Microscopically, they consist of bizarre, markedly enlarged myocytes. Routine histologic processing removes the glycogen and artifactually reduces the cytoplasm to thin strands stretching from nucleus to surface membrane. These appear to look like spider cells. 

They are considered hamartomatous as they often undergo spontaneous regression. Surgical resection is only indicated if the tumors cause obstruction.

The image below shows histopathological findings of cardiac rhabdomyoma with spider cells.

Other options:

Option A: Papillary fibroelastomas are sea-anemone-shaped endocardial tumors and are mainly present on valves. They are usually incidental but become clinically important if they embolize.

Option B: Myxomas are the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. They are benign Unlike rhabdomyomas and single and the common site of origin is the region of the fossa ovalis in the atrial septum. Histology reveals the presence of stellate or globular myxoma cells embedded within an abundant acid mucopolysaccharide ground substance. There are characteristic vessel-like or glandlike structures.

Option D: Paragangliomas are rare chromaffin cell tumors and are a form of extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. They are highly vascular and can be hormonally active causing uncontrolled hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following histological features are seen in osteosarcoma?

choices.text: Pleomorphic cells and osteoid arranged in a fine, lacelike pattern
Mosaic pattern of lamellar bone with cement lines
Sheets of uniform small, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes
Osteoclast-type giant cells with multiple nuclei

questions.solution:
The histological features of osteosarcoma include pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant mitoses. The diagnosis is definitive with the presence of malignant tumor cells producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralized bone arranged in a typical fine, lacelike pattern.

Histological appearance of osteosarcoma:

 

Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignant bone tumor. Primary osteosarcomas present most commonly during adolescence whereas secondary osteosarcomas present during the 7th decade of life. They arise from the metaphysis of long bones, especially the distal femur or the proximal tibia (i.e. around the knee joint).

Other options:

Option B - Mosaic pattern of lamellar bone with cement lines is diagnostic of Paget disease. Paget disease is characterized by the formation of disordered and structurally unstable bone (osteolytic phase ---> mixed osteolytic-osteoblastic phase --->osteosclerotic phase). During the osteosclerotic phase, osteoblastic activity is predominant. This is reflected in the arrangement of lamellar bone units in a mosaic pattern by distinct cement lines, giving it a jigsaw puzzle-like appearance. 

Histological appearance of Paget disease:

 

Option C- Sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes are characteristic of Ewing sarcoma. These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termed Homer-Wright rosettes. 

Histological appearance of Ewing sarcoma:

 

Option D- Osteoclast-type giant cells with multiple nuclei are characteristic of giant cell tumors/osteoclastoma. These cells are usually present against a backdrop of mononuclear stromal cells.

questions.text: A patient presents with urethral discharge and dysuria and is diagnosed with gonococcal urethritis. Which of the following attributes of the organism allows it to cause recurrent infections?

choices.text: Residual infection due to obligate intracellular nature of organism

questions.solution:
Pili of Neisseria gonorrhea is antigenic and exhibits phase variation and allow the organism to cause recurrent infections.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a gram-negative, non-sporulating, non-motile diplococcus that is a facultative intracellular organism (Option A). Virulence factors for gonococci are its Outer Membrane Proteins (OMPs), IgA proteases, Pili, Lipo-oligosaccharide (LOS), Transferrin, and Lactoferrin-binding protein. Pili are hair-like structures that act as virulence factors in neisseria gonorrhoeae infections by promoting attachment to host cells and inhibiting phagocytosis.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhea with an incubation period of 2-8 days. The major symptoms include purulent urethral discharge and dysuria. Culture on Gram stain reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It can also be cultured on chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. The Thayer-Martin agar is used to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Single-agent therapy with ceftriaxone is preferred for the treatment of gonococcal infections (Option B).

The capsule of N. gonorrhea (Option C) does not play a major role in the pathogenesis, but it is immunogenic.

questions.text: A  newborn male baby was found to have a very small occiput and posterior fossa. MRI imaging showed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a baby with a very small occiput and posterior fossa and an image showing herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum is suggestive of Chiari malformation. It is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain.

Children present with headaches that are worse with straining and other maneuvers that increase intracranial pressure. Symptoms of
brainstem compression, such as diplopia, oropharyngeal dysfunction, spasticity, tinnitus, sleep apnea, and vertigo, can occur due to brain stem compression. Incidental Chiari malformation with radiological findings compatible with Chiari malformation with no clinical manifestations of the disease is also seen. 

Chiari malformations are classified based on their morphology and severity of anatomic defects, typically through imaging or autopsy to Chiari I - Chiari IV. The Chiari I malformation is the most common type evaluated using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), typically in a child or adult. Chiari II to IV malformations is often first evaluated by ultrasound in utero, with fetal MRI assessment performed for further characterization.

Muscle relaxants, NSAIDs, and the temporary use of a cervical collar are used to treat headaches and neck pain.  The main treatment for re-establishing the CSF flow across the craniovertebral junction and relieving pressure on the cerebellum and hindbrain by decompressing the posterior fossa in Chiari malformation is surgical. This can be achieved by a suboccipital craniectomy in conjunction with C1 and C2 laminectomy. 

Other options:

Option A- Mega cisterna magna/ Arachanoid cyst can also cause hydrocephalus. It is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis. Persisting Blake pouch is a cyst that obstructs the subarachnoid space. 

The image below shows a CT of an arachnoid cyst. 

 

Option B- Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive ciliopathy associated with cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and molar tooth sign (a deepening of the interpeduncular fossa with thick and straight superior cerebellar peduncles). It is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, ataxia, breathing abnormalities including episodic apnea and hyperpnea.

The image below shows an MRI of Joubert syndrome demonstrating the molar tooth sign.  

 

Option C- Dandy-Walker syndrome is a congenital malformation that involves:

  • Cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle
  • Hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis
  • Hydrocephalus
  • Enlargement of the posterior fossa.

The below MRI shows dilation of the fourth ventricle with hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis.

questions.text: An elderly woman on treatment for migraine presents with chest pain. She has a previous history of angina/MI. Which of the following mechanism of the prescribed drug for migraine might have caused this presentation?
questions.solution:
The patient may have been given sumatriptan, a preganglionic 5-HT1b/1d receptor agonist which causes vasoconstriction and used in migraine. Thus, sumatriptan will worsen angina by causing coronary vasoconstriction.

Angina will be worsened if the O2 demand of the heart is increased or there is reduced blood flow to the already ischemic areas.

Sumatriptan is preganglionic 5-HT1b/1d receptor agonist and exerts its action by constricting the dilated blood vessels and also like ergotamine inhibits the neurogenic inflammatory products that are released, thus making it useful in the treatment of mild to moderate episodes of migraine which have failed to remit following analgesic administration.

Contraindications for the use of triptan group of drugs include include:

  • ischaemic heart disease
  • hypertension
  • epilepsy
  • hepatic and renal impairment
  • pregnancy

It is advisable to provide patients with a cautionary recommendation against operating a motor vehicle.
The concurrent administration of sumatriptan and ergotamine is contraindicated within a 24-hour timeframe. Also, there have been reports of interactions with 5-HT reuptake inhibitors, MAO inhibitors, and lithium.

Frovatriptan is a long-acting triptan among other triptans.

Headache recurrences in an attack are less with longer-acting triptans like frovatriptan and naratriptan but onset of action may be slow.

questions.text:
Match the following classes of lupus nephritis with their findings.
1. Class I A. Mesangial Proliferative Lupus Nephritis
2. Class II B. Focal Lupus Nephritis
3. Class III C. Membranous Lupus Nephritis
4. Class IV D. Diffuse Lupus Nephritis
5. Class V  
6. Class VI
questions.solution:
The correctly matched classes with their findings:

2. Class II A. Mesangial Proliferative Lupus Nephritis
3. Class III B. Focal Lupus Nephritis
4. Class IV D. Diffuse Lupus Nephritis
5. Class V C. Membranous Lupus Nephritis

 

Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is a chronic autoimmune disorder representing a type III hypersensitivity reaction, ie, immune complex depositions. Renal involvement results in glomerulonephritis, termed lupus nephritis. Symptoms of nephritis are proteinuria, hematuria, nephrotic syndrome, hypertension, etc. If the patient has clinical or laboratory evidence of nephritis, they have to undergo renal biopsy. Depending on the histopathological features, lupus nephritis is divided into six classes (as summarised in the attached pearl).

Management of lupus nephritis:

Class Features and Management
Class I and II
  • Minimal or no symptoms
  • Excellent prognosis
  • They do not require any therapy
Class III
  • Associated with few symptoms
  • Good prognosis
  • Short course of high-dose corticosteroids or other immunosuppressive agents
Class IV
  • Symptoms include hematuria, nephrotic-range proteinuria, and renal casts
  • Treatment includes the administration of high-dose steroids combined with either cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil for 2–6 months
  • Followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine
Class V
  • Severe manifestations
  • Poor prognosis.
  • Management includes the administration of steroids in combination with other immunosuppressive agents. Inhibitors of the renin-angiotensin system may be administered to attenuate proteinuria
Class VI
  • Present with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) and require hemodialysis

Related Pearl: Classification of Lupus Nephritis (International Society of Nephrology and Renal Pathology Society)

Class 

Findings

Minimal mesangial lupus nephritis (class I)

Immune complex deposition in the mesangium without structural changes by light microscopy.

Mesangial proliferative lupus nephritis (class II)

Mesangial cell proliferation with mesangial immune deposits

Focal lupus nephritis (class III)

Focal, segmental glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli.

Focal subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes

Diffuse lupus nephritis (class IV)

The most common and severe form of lupus nephritis

Diffuse glomerulonephritis involving more than 50% of all glomeruli

Diffuse subendothelial deposits with or without mesangial changes. “Wire loop” structures on light microscopy.

Membranous lupus nephritis (class V)

Global or segmental subepithelial immune deposits with or without mesangial proliferation

Advanced sclerosing lupus nephritis (class VI)

Sclerosis of more than 90% of the glomeruli 
  • Focal- Involves only a few glomeruli
  • Diffuse- Involves almost all the glomeruli
  • Segmental- Involves only a part of glomerulus
  • Global- Involves entire glomerulus

questions.text:
A patient is found to have reduced forced vital capacity (FVC) and increased FEV1/FVC ratio. His diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide (DLCO) is normal. Which of these conditions will you consider as possible differential diagnosis for this patient?
  1. Myasthenia gravis
  2. Interstitial lung disease
  3. Chronic bronchitis
  4. Pulmonary hemorrhage
  5. Massive pleural effusion
questions.solution:
A reduction in FVC and an increase in FEV1/FVC, indicates a restrictive lung disorder. The normal DLCO of the patient suggests that there is an extra-parenchymal restriction and thus, the likely diagnosis could be myasthenia gravis and massive pleural effusion.

These values are measured as a part of the pulmonary function test known as spirometry. At a given lung volume, when a person inhales to the total lung capacity and exhales as hard and completely as possible, the volume of expired air is recorded as forced vital capacity (FVC), and the volume of air expired in the first second is called the forced expiratory volume (FEV1).

Other options:

Option 2: Interstitial lung disease will show a restrictive pattern on spirometry, however the DLCO will be reduced in this condition.

Option 3: Chronic bronchitis will show an obstructive pattern with a reduction in both FVC and FEV1/FVC < 70%. It will also show a normal DLCO.

Option 4: Pulmonary hemorrhage will show a restrictive pattern on spirometry, however the DLCO will be increased in this condition.

questions.text: A newborn baby is vaccinated against tuberculosis disease. All of the following are true about the vaccine except:

choices.text: The dose given at birth is 0.05 ml
Distilled water is preferred for reconstitution

questions.solution:
BCG vaccine is primarily used against tuberculosis disease. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. Hence, option D is not true. 

BCG (bacillus of Calmette and Guerin) is the only live bacterial vaccine. The WHO has recommended the Danish 1331 strain for the production of the BCG vaccine. It protects against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis and tuberculous meningitis. It also reduces morbidity and mortality against primary tuberculosis.

There are two types of BCG vaccine: the liquid (fresh) vaccine and the freeze-dried vaccine. The freeze-dried vaccine is a more stable preparation (option B) than the liquid vaccine. Currently, the vaccine is distributed in the freeze-dried form because of better storage qualities. Normal saline is recommended for reconstituting the vaccine, as distilled water may cause irritation. The reconstituted vaccine may be used up within 3 hours.

The usual strength for vaccination is 0.1 mg in 0.1 ml volume. The dose given at birth (option A) and for newborns < 4 weeks of age is 0.05 ml. It is injected intradermally (option C) just above the insertion of the left deltoid muscle using a tuberculin syringe.  

A papule develops at the vaccination site after 2-3 weeks. It increases slowly in size and then subsides or breaks into a shallow ulcer after 5 weeks. Healing occurs spontaneously within 6 to 12 weeks, leaving a permanent, tiny, round scar, typically 4-8 mm in diameter. Usually, the individual becomes Mantoux-positive after 8-14 weeks. 

Complications include prolonged severe ulceration at the vaccination site, suppurative lymphadenitis, osteomyelitis, and disseminated infection. It should not be given to patients with generalized eczema, infective dermatosis, hypogammaglobulinemia, immunodeficiency state, or pregnancy.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about anti-retroviral drugs is correct?

(HIV - Human Immunodeficiency Virus)

choices.text: Raltegravir prevents release of viral progeny from infected cells
Maraviroc binds to gp41 and prevents viral entry
Enfuvirtide is given via the parenteral route
Tenofovir is active against HIV-1 only

questions.solution:
Enfuvirtide is the only antiretroviral drug approved via the parenteral (subcutaneous) route.

Enfuvirtide binds to the gp41 subunit of the HIV-1 envelope and prevents entry (fusion) of the virus with the host cell. It is not active against HIV-2.

Other options:

Option A: Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor and it prevents the integration of virus DNA into the host chromosome. 

Option B: Maraviroc binds to the host cell CCR5 receptor to block the binding of viral gp120. It prevents the entry of the viral particles.

Option D: Tenofovir is a reverse transcriptase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of viral RNA into proviral DNA. It is effective against HIV 1, 2, and Hepatitis B virus.

The image below shows the mechanisms of actions of various antiretroviral drugs used in the management of HIV.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old vegetarian presents with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Findings on a peripheral smear are shown below. What other peripheral smear findings can be observed in this condition?
  1. Echinocytes
  2. Neutrophils with bilobed nucleus
  3. Macro-ovalocytes
  4. Neutrophils with nuclear hypersegmentation
  5. Acanthocytes
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 40-year-old vegetarian presenting with complaints of fatigue and weakness, and a peripheral smear showing a Cabot ring is suggestive of megaloblastic anemia. The other findings on peripheral smear that can be seen in this condition are macro-ovalocytes and neutrophils with nuclear hypersegmentation (3, 4). 

Megaloblastic anemia is an RBC disorder caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B12 or folic acid. This deficiency results in impaired DNA synthesis, leading to ineffective hematopoiesis and distinctive morphologic changes, including abnormally large erythroid precursors and red cells.

The peripheral smear findings seen in this condition include macro-ovalocytes (large and oval RBCs). The neutrophils are also larger than normal and show nuclear hypersegmentation, having five or more nuclear lobules, as shown below:


Cabot rings are circular, blue, threadlike inclusions with dots (as shown in the image below). They are nuclear remnants seen in megaloblastic anemia, some hemolytic anemias, myelofibrosis, and post-splenectomy.


Other options:

Echinocytes (burr cells) are red cells with short, evenly spaced spicules formed due to altered cell membrane lipids. They are usually artifacts but can be seen in uremia, bleeding ulcers, liver disease, pyruvate kinase deficiency, and gastric carcinoma. They are shown in the image below:


Neutrophils with bilobed nuclei are referred to as pseudo-Pelger-Huet cells. These granulocytes with reduced segmentation are seen in myelodysplastic syndrome and myeloid leukemias. It is shown in the image below:


Acanthocytes (spur cells) are characterized by a few spicules of varying size that project irregularly from the cell surface. This morphology is observed in conditions such as parenchymal liver disease, abetalipoproteinemia, and post-splenectomy/hyposplenism. They are shown in the image below:

Related Pearl: Causes of Megaloblastic Anemia

Vitamin B12 Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Vegetarianism
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Intrinsic factor deficiency
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Gastrectomy
    • Malabsorption states
    • Diffuse intestinal disease (e.g., lymphoma, systemic sclerosis)
    • Ileal resection
    • Ileitis
  • Competitive parasitic uptake
    • Fish tapeworm infestation
    • Bacterial overgrowth in blind loops and diverticula of bowel

Folic Acid Deficiency causes:

  • Decreased Intake
    • Inadequate diet
    • Alcoholism
    • Infancy
  • Impaired Absorption
    • Malabsorption states
    • Intrinsic intestinal disease
    • Anticonvulsants
    • Oral contraceptives
  • Increased Loss
    • Hemodialysis
  • Increased Requirement
    • Pregnancy, infancy
    • Disseminated cancer
    • Markedly increased hematopoiesis
  • Impaired Utilization
    • Folic acid antagonists
    • Unresponsive to vitamin B12 or folic acid therapy
    • Metabolic inhibitors of DNA synthesis and/or folate metabolism

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding the management of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in a 2-year-old child?
  1. Iron is not supplemented in the initial stabilization phase
  2. F-100 diet is energy-dense and contains 2.9g protein/100ml
  3. F-75 diet is recommended as a catch-up feed for rapid weight gain 
  4. Weight gain of >3g/kg/day for 3 consecutive days is a criterion for discharge
  5. Folic acid is supplemented during the initial stabilization phase
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 5 are true regarding the management of severe acute malnutrition (SAM).

The general treatment of SAM involves 10 steps divided into 2 phases. The initial stabilization and subsequent rehabilitation phases are shown in the image below.

 

Refeeding is an important part of management. Initially, cautious feeding is done with 8 to 12 small feeds of starter diet F-75. The F-75 diet contains 75 kcal and 0.9 grams of protein per 100 mL. If a child tolerates that, they are transitioned to F-100 feeds. F-100 is the catch-up feed that helps to achieve rapid weight gain (statement 3). It contains 100 kcal and 2.9 grams of protein per 100 mL. 

Correcting micronutrient deficiencies involves supplementing zinc, folic acid, vitamin A, and copper in the stabilization phase. Supplementing iron is avoided in the stabilization phase as it can lead to free radical injury. Instead, iron supplementation is done once the child starts gaining weight post-stabilization.

A satisfactory weight gain of > 5g/kg/day for three consecutive days is one of the discharge criteria (not >3g/kg/day as given in statement 4). Failure to gain at least this is considered inadequate and may suggest an underlying latent infection. Other factors considered for patient discharge are resolving edema, mid-arm circumference (MAC) reaching 12.5cm, the ability to transition to nutritious foods at home, micronutrient supplementation, and up-to-date immunization.

questions.text: What is the nature of the scotoma that you would expect to see in a patient after the correction of aphakia using spectacles?

choices.text: Scotoma is not associated with spectacle correction of aphakia

questions.solution:
Roving-ring scotoma is seen in the correction of aphakia with spectacles due to prismatic effects at the edge of the lens.

 

The position of this scotoma is not fixed in the visual field because the eye keeps moving (or roving) in relation to the aphakic spectacle. Hence, this is called a roving ring scotoma.

This scotoma occurs because the edge of a convex lens acts as a prism. The light falling on the edge of the lens bends (directly proportional to prism angle) towards the base of the prism which is the center of the lens, but doesnot enter the pupil and is therefore seen as nothing (scotoma). The greater the angle the more will be the bending and subsequently larger the scotoma. This results in a ring-shaped scotoma is more prominent in aphakic spectacles because of the large angle of bending. Other difficulties in the correction of aphakia by spectacles include the following:

  • Image magnification by 25–30%
  • Spherical aberrations producing a “pin cushion effect”
  • Jack-in-the-box phenomenon from the prismatic effects at the edge of the lens
  • Reduced visual fields
  • Physical inconvenience

For aphakia: Best correction is obtained by an intraocular lens (IOL).

Related Pearl: Visual field Defects in Open-Angle Glaucoma

questions.text: Which among the following tissues has the highest arteriovenous oxygen difference?
questions.solution:
The tissue with the highest arteriovenous oxygen difference is the myocardium (114 mL/L). 

The arteriovenous oxygen difference is the amount of oxygen taken up from the blood by the tissue. The heart muscle has the highest oxygen consumption per 100g of tissue in the body (9.7 mL/100g/min oxygen consumption) leading to such a large arteriovenous concentration difference.

Timing post-transplant Infection
1. <1 month A. CMV
2. 1-6 months B. BK Virus
3. >6 months C. Oral candidiasis
questions.solution:
The correct match sequence is 1-C, 2-A, 3-B.

1.  <1 month C. Oral candidiasis
2. 1-6 months  A. CMV
3. > 6 months B. BK Virus

 

Post transplant infections: 

  • Peritransplant (<1 month after transplant) - Oral candidiasis - This fungal infection is common due to antibiotic use, weakened immune system, and altered oral flora during the immediate post-transplant period.
  • Early (1-6 months after transplant) - CMV - This virus can reactivate from a latent state in the recipient, causing significant disease in the early months due to high immunosuppression levels.
  • Late (>6 months after transplant) - BK Virus - This virus typically infects the urinary tract or kidneys in the late post-transplant period, usually after tapering of immunosuppression.

The most common opportunistic infections in renal transplant recipients are as follows:

Early infections(<1 month): The most commonly seen infections include oral candidiasis and infections due to herpes viruses.
In the acute phase(1-6 months): Pneumocystis and cyomegalovirus infections develop in the patient
In the chronic phase(>6 months): Polyoma(BK) virus, nocardia and aspergillus are most commonly associated.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is attached to point 1 of the image?
questions.solution:
The point 1 in the image shows the coracoid process of the scapula. Among the given options, only the pectoralis minor muscle is attached to the coracoid process.

 

The coracoid process arises from the upper border of the neck of the scapula and it projects forward and slightly laterally. Attachments at the coracoid process include:

  • The conoid portion of the coracoclavicular ligament 
  • Pectoralis minor 
  • Medial end of coraco-acromial ligament
  • Coracohumeral ligament 
  • Glenocorocoid ligament 
  • Coracobrachialis muscle
  • Short head of biceps brachii muscle

None of the other muscles listed in the options above are attached to the coracoid process.

questions.text: In patients with which of the following type of choledochal cyst, would you advise endoscopic sphincterotomy?
questions.solution:
A type III choledochal cyst is the cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles. Patients with type III choledochal cyst are managed with endoscopic sphincterotomy. 

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the extrahepatic and/or intrahepatic biliary tree. Females are more commonly affected than males. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain.

Diagnosis is confirmed using ultrasound abdomen but ERCP or MRCP is required to analyze the anatomy of the cyst, classify the type, and plan the surgical procedure accordingly. 

Choledochal cysts are classified according to the Todani Classification, and the management for each type is summarized in the table below:

Type of choledochal cyst  Management

Type I 

 
  • Excision of the cyst with cholecystectomy
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy

Type II
  • Excision of the diverticulum with cholecystectomy
  • Suturing of the CBD wall
  • Reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy can be done

Type III (choledochocele)
  • Endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is preferred
  • Cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy can be done

Type IV
  • Extrahepatic- cyst excision and Roux-en-Y hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure)
  • Intrahepatic- segmental resection of the liver by hepatectomy
  • Lily’s operation- if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of cyst wall is left behind but mucosa of the part is removed
  • Definitive- liver transplantation

Type V (Caroli disease)
  • Liver transplantation

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Feature

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.
