Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: Which of the following lysosomal storage disorders is matched correctly with the respective inclusion body seen in the condition?
questions.solution:
Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy. It is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy resulting from a deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase, the enzyme required for the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosyl sphingosine, a compound toxic to both oligodendrocytes and astrocytes.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Survival beyond the age of 2 years is uncommon. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

A unique and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages (globoid cells) in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

Other options: 

Zebra cells are seen in Niemann-Picks disease and not in Fabry's disease. Fabry's disease is associated with maltese crosses in the urinary sediment.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of night blindness.  The mother notes that the child's father also has similar complaints. Fundus examination reveals the below image. Which of the following investigation needs to be done?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and fundal image are suggestive of retinitis pigmentosa (RP). Electroretinogram (ERG) is the investigation that needs to be performed in this case.

RP is a retinal degenerative disease that is initially predominant among rod photoreceptors and later spreads to cones (rod-cone dystrophy). It is the most common form of hereditary fundus dystrophy. It may occur as a sporadic disorder, or in an inherited form. Autosomal dominant type is the most common form of inheritance.

Nyctalopia and dark adaptation difficulties are frequently presenting symptoms, but peripheral visual problems may be noticed. The classic triad of clinical findings are:

  1. Bone-spicule retinal pigmentation
  2. Arteriolar attenuation
  3. ‘Waxy’ disc pallor

A posterior subcapsular cataract is a complication of this condition that is commonly seen in all of its subtypes.

Full-field ERG is a sensitive diagnostic test. Initially, it shows reduced scotopic rod and combined responses. With progression, the photopic responses reduce and eventually the ERG becomes extinguished.

Other options:

Option A: 20 Δ base-out prism test is used to test for binocular fusion in infants without manifest squint.

Option B: Hess chart is plotted to help in the diagnosis and monitoring of a patient with strabismus.

Option C: Cover-uncover test is used to test for the presence and type of heterophoria.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: The cause of resistance to acyclovir is viral RNA polymerase deficiency
Foscarnet requires activation by viral thymidine kinase for antiviral activity
Oseltamivir is a viral endonuclease inhibitor

questions.solution:
Remdesivir acts by inhibiting the activity of RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Remdesivir is a nucleoside analog. Inside the cells, it is converted to nucleoside monophosphate, which is subsequently converted to nucleoside triphosphate. This metabolite inhibits viral replication by inhibiting the enzyme RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Remdesivir (under Emergency Use Authorization) is used in the treatment of COVID-19. It may be considered in patients with moderate to severe disease, requiring supplemental oxygen, within 10 days of onset of the illness.

The most common cause of resistance to acyclovir in herpes simplex 1 (HSV-1) is deficient or absent viral thymidine kinase activity (Option A). Viral thymidine kinase is needed in the conversion of acyclovir to acyclovir triphosphate which competitively inhibits the viral DNA polymerase activity.  

The image below shows the sites of actions of antiretroviral drugs:

 

Foscarnet inhibits viral nucleic acid synthesis by directly inhibiting Herpes Simplex Virus DNA polymerase (or HIV reverse transcriptase). It does not require viral thymidine kinase to exert its effects (Option B). It is active against acyclovir resistant herpes simplex, Cytomegalovirus, varicella zoster virus, and human immunodeficiency virus.

Oseltamivir is a viral neuraminidase inhibitor used for treatment of influenza virus (Option D).

questions.text: In addition to dopamine antagonism, quetiapine has which of the following pharmacological properties?
questions.solution:
Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic that blocks 5-HT1A, 5-HT2, D2, α1, α2, and H1 receptors in the brain.

Quetiapine has low D2 blocking activity and therefore extrapyramidal and hyperprolactinemic side effects are less. However, there is an increased risk of metabolic side effects due to serotonin antagonism.

Other options:

Option B: Phenelzine is an example of monoamine oxidase inhibitor.

Option C: Antidepressants work by inhibiting norepinephrine reuptake.

Option D: Aripiprazole has partial dopamine agonistic activity.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with a non-progressive, painless, yellowish blob on the nasal side of her conjunctiva as shown below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image shows a pinguecula. Most pingueculas are asymptomatic and do not require any treatment. No active intervention is needed for small, non-progressive pinguiculas.

Pinguecula is a degenerative condition of the conjunctiva, characterized by the formation of a yellowish-white patch on the bulbar conjunctiva near the limbus. It usually presents as a triangular patch on the nasal side, with the triangle's apex commonly pointed away from the cornea. The underlying etiology is hyaline infiltration and elastotic degeneration of the submucous tissue. It is caused by elastosis of the subepithelial tissue due to chronic ultraviolet light exposure.

Pinguecula is usually found in the elderly during routine eye examinations and generally produces no symptoms. Exposure to sunlight, dust, and wind are possible risk factors. The condition is non-progressive, and treatment is usually not required. In rare cases, it may present with inflammation or congestion. Such cases are managed symptomatically with topical steroids. 

Other options: 

Option A: Surgical excision is rarely necessary for pinguecula. It is typically only considered in patients with large, cosmetically bothersome pingueculas, or those that are causing significant irritation or visual impairment.

Option B: Topical steroids may be used in patients with pinguecula who experience mild inflammation or irritation. However, long-term use of steroids can have side effects such as glaucoma and cataracts, so they should be used with caution.

Option C: Topical antihistamines are used for the management of allergic conjunctivitis.

questions.text: The electrocardiograph of a neonate, presenting with the following facial rash, is suggestive of a complete heart block. Which of the following antibodies are most likely to be associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given findings of a periorbital rash with ECG findings of a complete heart block are suggestive of neonatal lupus erythematosus. It is most likely to be associated with anti-Ro antibodies.

Neonatal lupus results from the passive transfer of maternal IgG autoantibodies (anti-Ro and anti-La) to the fetus. Hence, mothers with a known history of SLE or those who are positive for autoantibodies should undergo screening with fetal echocardiography. Detection of anti-Ro antibodies in a newborn is specific for neonatal lupus syndrome.

Clinical manifestations of neonatal lupus include a characteristic annular or macular rash typically affecting the face (especially the periorbital area), trunk, and scalp. The rash typically appears within the first 6 weeks of life after exposure to ultraviolet light and may last for 3-4 months.

The most feared complication is congenital heart block. Conduction system abnormalities range from prolongation of the PR interval to complete heart block. In severe cases, they can develop progressive cardiomyopathy. Conduction system abnormalities can be detected in utero by fetal echocardiogram beginning at 16 weeks of gestational age. Other noncardiac features include hepatitis, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Treatment options include corticosteroids (dexamethasone or betamethasone), intravenous immunoglobulins, plasmapheresis, hydroxychloroquine, and terbutaline, which are given to pregnant women with anti-Ro or anti-La antibodies to prevent occurrence or progression of fetal cardiac abnormalities. Treatment for neonates is directed at specific organ involvement. With cardiac pacing, children with conduction system disease in the absence of cardiomyopathy have an excellent prognosis. 

Other Options:

Option A: Serology for rubella antibodies is done to confirm congenital rubella syndrome, which can have heart defects (most commonly patent ductus arteriosus). However, other features of the syndrome, like sensorineural hearing loss, blueberry muffin rash, and cataracts, are not present in this patient.

The given image shows a blueberry muffin rash seen in congenital rubella syndrome:

 

Option B: Serology for anti-treponemal antibodies is done to confirm congenital syphilis. Heart block and periorbital rash are not the features of congenital syphilis. In congenital syphilis, the maculopapular rash is characteristically present on the palms and soles. There will be hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, and elevated liver enzymes.

The given image shows maculopapular rash in congenital syphilis involving the soles:

 

Option C: Serology for anti-dsDNA antibodies is a highly specific test to diagnose systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Features of SLE include malar rash, arthralgia, serositis, etc. These antibodies will be present in the mother but not in the baby.

The given image shows malar rash in SLE:

questions.text: What is the modified shock index of a patient who has a heart rate of 105 beats/min, systolic blood pressure (SBP) of 90 mmHg, and mean arterial pressure (MAP) of 70 mm Hg?
questions.solution:
The Modified shock index = HR/MAP = 105/70 = 1.5  

The shock index is a hemodynamic stability indicator. In patients with shock, it is a better predictor of mortality than blood pressure or heart rate alone. A shock index >0.9 is indicative of higher mortality.

Original shock index = HR/SBP 

The original shock index does not include the diastolic blood pressure (DBP) which is why the modified shock index was developed. The modified shock index is a more sensitive indicator of tissue perfusion than the original shock index. In critically ill patients, the DBP decreases earlier than SBP, hence, the modified shock index using MAP is better suited to assess the severity of shock.

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the Employees State Insurance (ESI) act.

choices.text: The state government provides 1/8th of the medical care expenses
Medical benefit is given in the form of no cash benefit
The maximum amount given under funeral benefit is Rs 15,000

questions.solution:
The employee contributes 0.75% of the wage according to the ESI Act. Hence, option A is false. 

The Employees State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948 (revised in 2022) is essential to our country's social security and health insurance. It provides several benefits to insured persons, such as medical, sickness, and maternity benefits.

The ESI scheme is run by contributions from employees, employers, and grants from central and state governments.

These contributions include the following:

  • Wage bills:
    • Employer contributes 3.25% of the total wage bills
    • Employee contributes 0.75% of the wages
  • Medical bills:
    • State government provides 1/8th of the total medical expenses (option B)
    • ESI corporation provides the remaining 7/8th of medical expenses

The medical benefits are provided in the form of no cash benefit, i.e., the insured persons can avail of full medical care free of cost (option C). This includes hospitalization in cases of sickness, employment injury, or maternity. Medical care is provided either directly through ESI hospitals and dispensaries, or indirectly through private insurance medical practitioners.

The funeral benefit under the ESI Act is a cash payment given on the death of an insured person for funeral expenses to a maximum amount of Rs. 15,000 (option D).  

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

questions.text: After a camping trip, a patient presents with fever, headache, muscle aches, and a rash shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely vector for this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of fever, headache, myalgia, and a petechial rash involving the palms and soles is suggestive of Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever (RMSF) caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. The hard tick Dermacentor andersoni acts as the vector for this disease.

Rickettsiae are obligate intracellular, gram-negative coccobacilli. They are non-motile, non-capsulated organisms that contain both DNA and RNA. They are usually transmitted by arthropod vectors (except Coxiella burnetii and Bartonella henselae). 

The most common serologic test for the diagnosis is the indirect immunofluorescence assay. Weil-Felix reaction is usually positive in RMSF because the antibodies against Rickettsia react with Proteus antigens. The drug of choice for the treatment of both children and adults with RMSF is doxycycline. 

Rash on palms and soles is typically described in the following 3 diseases:

  • Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
  • Secondary Syphilis
  • Hand Foot and Mouth Disease

questions.text: During your labor postings, you notice the resident performing the following procedure for a primigravida in labor. Which of the following structures will be cut during this process?

choices.text: Both superficial and deep transverse perinei muscles

questions.solution:
During episiotomy, both the superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles are cut.

Episiotomy refers to the surgically planned incision on the perineum and the posterior vaginal wall during the second stage of labor. It is an induced second-degree perineal tear. In mediolateral episiotomy, the incision is made downwards and outwards from the midpoint of the fourchette either to the right or to the left.

The other types of episiotomy include median, lateral, and J-shaped episiotomy.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
  • Bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering these muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin
Midline Episiotomy Mediolateral Episiotomy
Surgical repair is easy Surgical repair is difficult
Blood loss is lesser Blood loss is more
Healing is superior Healing is not so good
Dyspareunia is rare Dyspareunia is comparatively more

Postoperative comfort is maximum

Postoperative discomfort is more

Extension, if occurs, may involve the rectum

Relative safety from rectal involvement from extension 

 

The objective is to enlarge the vaginal introitus so as to facilitate easy and safe delivery of the fetus and to minimize overstretching and rupture of the perineal muscles and fascia, which might end up in complete tears. The below image shows the episiotomy scissors.

 

 

Related Pearl: Mediolateral Episiotomy

It begins within 3 mm of the midline in the posterior fourchette and is directed laterally at an angle of at least 60 degrees from the midline. This yields an incision of 45 degrees off the midline.

It is essentially an inflicted second-degree perineal tear.

Structures cut in mediolateral episiotomy:

  • Posterior vaginal wall
  • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus and part of levator ani
  • Fascia covering those muscles
  • Transverse perineal branches of pudendal vessels and nerves
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

Advantage: Lesser risk of anal sphincter laceration, hence it is preferred over median episiotomy.

Disadvantage: Increased blood loss and causes more perineal pain and dyspareunia.

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent kidney stones. Microscopic examination finding of the urine specimen is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in the urine of this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shows hexagonal, translucent and white crystals suggestive of cystinuria. Histidine is not seen in the urine of this patient. 

Cystinuria is an autosomal-recessive disease due to a defect in renal PCT & intestinal amino acid transporter that is essential for reabsorptive transport of Cystine and the dibasic amino acids Ornithine, Lysine, and Arginine (COLA).

Diagnosis of cystinuria is by the cyanide–nitroprusside test. Initial treatment is with adequate hydration, alkalization of the urine with citrate supplementation or acetazolamide, and dietary modification to reduce salt and protein intake. If this fails then patients are usually started on chelation therapy with penicillamine.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing an elective laparoscopic appendicectomy and the bowel has been prepared. During surgery, the small bowel gets perforated and there is minor spillage of some contents into the peritoneal cavity. What class of surgical wound is this?
questions.solution:
The wound would be classified as clean-contaminated wound as the alimentary tract is entered under controlled conditions (minor spillage with prepared bowel) without gross contamination. 

Surgical Wound Classifications as Defined by ACS NSQIP: 

Class I - Clean Wound:  Uninfected operative wounds in which no inflammation is encountered and the respiratory, alimentary, genital, and uninfected urinary tracts are not entered. Eg. Non-traumatic elective surgery and coronary bypass. 

Class II - Clean / Contaminated: Operative wounds in which the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tract is entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination. Eg. Elective cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, elective colon surgery after bowel preparation.

Class III - Contaminated: Open, fresh, accidental wounds; operations with major breaks in sterile technique or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract; and incisions in which acute, nonpurulent inflammation is encountered. Eg. Emergency cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, emergency colon surgery in unprepared bowel.

Class IV - Dirty: Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue and wounds that involve existing clinical infection or perforated viscera. Eg. Abscess, peritonitis (gross fecal contamination)

questions.text: Which of the following factors is the best prognostic indicator in chronic hepatitis C infection?
questions.solution:
The best prognostic indicator in chronic hepatitis C infection is the liver biopsy. 

The rate of fibrosis and baseline inflammation seen on the liver biopsy correlates well with the prognosis. Patients with minor inflammation and necrosis, as well as those with limited fibrosis have an excellent prognosis and show limited progression to cirrhosis. In contrast, patients with moderate to severe inflammation, necrosis or fibrosis, including septal or bridging fibrosis, progress to cirrhosis over 10−20 years.

The likelihood of progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C is increased by:

  • Longer duration of infection (most important determinant)
  • Older age
  • Obesity - patients with a high body mass index are at an increased risk of developing fibrosis
  • Diabetes mellitus and insulin resistance
  • Concomitant liver disorder (eg., alcoholic liver disease, chronic hepatitis B, hemochromatosis)
  • Concomitant HIV infection.

Other options:

Option A: While HCV RNA is considered the gold standard for establishing a diagnosis of hepatitis C, it has no role in determining the progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C.

Option B: Serum aminotransferase levels have no role in determining the progression of liver disease in patients with chronic hepatitis C.

Option D: Anti-HCV levels do not correlate with the prognosis in chronic hepatitis C infections.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with pain in the right leg accompanied by symptoms of fever and fatigue. His X-ray of the leg is given below. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features and X-ray point to the diagnosis of Ewing's sarcoma. It is a highly radio-sensitive tumor. 

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have a balanced translocation between the EWSR1 gene on chromosome 22 and the FLI1 gene on chromosome 11. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, humerus, and flat bones of the pelvis. Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm.

Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count, LDH levels (lactate dehydrogenase) and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). The common diagnostic test used for Ewing’s sarcoma is the detection of translocation t(11;22) (q24;q12). An onion peel appearance is characteristic on imaging.

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round blue cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2. The tumor cells contain glycogen and are hence PAS positive and they are reticulin negative.

Preoperative chemotherapy with vincristine, ifosfamide, doxorubicin and etoposide results in extensive tumor necrosis and shrinkage. Wide excision may be combined with adjuvant radiotherapy if surgical margins are poor. Definitive radiotherapy rather than surgical excision may be advocated if it is non-resectable or metastasis has occurred. It is a radio-sensitive tumor.

Indicators of poor prognosis in patients with Ewing's sarcoma:

  • Presence of distant metastasis - worst prognostic factor
  • Size and location of the primary lesion
  • Presence of fever, anemia
  • Leukocytosis, raised ESR.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male patient is diagnosed with a fracture of the neck of the femur. T- score on a DEXA scan is -3.0. Which of the following drugs used for this condition acts as a sclerostin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
T-score of -3.0 in a DEXA scan, along with a fragility fracture, is suggestive of severe osteoporosis. Romosozumab is a monoclonal antibody that acts as a sclerostin inhibitor indicated in this condition.

Radiological osteopenia can be diagnosed from an X-ray where the bone appears less dense than normal. Typical signs are loss of trabecular definition, thinning of cortices and insufficiency fractures.

DEXA (Dual Energy Xray Absorptiometry) is used to assess bone mass density after a fracture due to a trivial fall or as a preventative measure for adults aged over 60. It has two scores: T-score (compares bone density with that of younger population) and Z-score (compares bone density with the same age group).

Values of T-scores
≥ -1.0 Normal bone density
-1.0 to -2.5 Osteopenia
≤ -2.5 Osteoporosis
≤ -2.5 plus fragility fracture Severe Osteoporosis

 

Treatment options for osteoporosis include:

  • Bisphosphonates - first line treatment to reduce the postmenopausal osteoporosis. It includes oral drugs such as alendronate, risedronate and i.v. formulations such as zolendronate (given only once per year). They act by reducing bone resorption and rate of bone turnover.
  • Denosumab (Option C) - a monoclonal antibody that acts against the RANK-L which is essential for promoting osteoclast formation. It is given subcutaneously once every 6 months.
  • Romosozumab - a monoclonal antibody that acts as a sclerostin inhibitor and has been shown to increase bone formation.
  • Parathyroid hormone - Teriparatide, a synthetic agent given intermittently at low doses to promote bone formation.
  • Strontium raneolate - a drug which promotes bone formation and reduces bone turnover but is used in limited areas due to its adverse effects.
  • Selective estrogen receptor modulators - Raloxifene, a second-line drug used to reduce future risk of fracture reduction in postmenopausal women.

Other options:

Option B: Odanacatib acts as a cathepsin-K  inhibitor which is an enzyme in osteoclast that facilitates bone resorption.

Option D: Pembrolizumab is a humanized IgG4 monoclonal antibody that acts against PD1 and can be used in the treatment of melanoma and small cell carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was asked to take multiple rapid breaths while undergoing an EEG. The recording showed symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-wave discharges that began and ended suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with a 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG, which was provoked by hyperventilation, suggests a diagnosis of absence seizures.

Absence seizures are the most common seizures in children. The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharge pattern. This EEG finding can be provoked by hyperventilation.

These seizures are characterized by a sudden, brief lapse of consciousness with preserved postural control and without post-ictal confusion. Usually, the seizure lasts only a few seconds. The patient presents with subtle, bilateral motor signs such as rapid blinking of the eyelids, chewing movements, or small-amplitude, clonic movements of the hands. These can occur hundreds of times in a day. The child is often misunderstood to be 'daydreaming' and parents are often told that there is a decline in the child's performance at school.

The first line treatment drugs for absent seizures include valproic acid, ethosuximide and lamotrigine. 

Other options:

Option A: Generalised tonic-clonic seizure is characterized by tonic contractions of muscles followed by periods of muscle relaxation (clonic phase). It is associated with unresponsiveness, muscular flaccidity, excessive salivation, and incontinence. The EEG is characterized by an increase in generalized low-voltage fast waves after which generalized high-amplitude, polyspike discharges in the tonic phase. In the clonic phase, a spike and slow-wave pattern are observed. 

Option B: Atonic seizures are characterized by sudden loss of postural muscle tone. Consciousness may not be impaired and postictal confusion is not usually present. The EEG shows generalized spike-wave discharge followed by diffuse slow waves which correspond to the muscle tone. 

Option D: Myoclonic seizures are characterized by sudden and brief contraction of part of or the entire body. The EEG shows synchronous spike-and-slow-wave discharges just before the onset of myoclonic movements.

questions.text: In the given nerve action potential curve, which point represents the return of  Na+ channels to the closed state?
questions.solution:
At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 

The sequence of events occurring during a nerve action potential is as shown below:

Point A - Resting potential. A state where both Na+ and K+ channels are closed. 

Point B - Threshold potential. Na+ channels open in response to depolarizing stimulus and Na+ influx occurs. The initiation of action potential occurs only after a certain potential is reached, called the threshold potential.

Point C - Peak of action potential. The sodium influx causes the opening of more Na+ channels through a positive feedback loop. Rapid depolarization occurs. At point C, Na+ channels close and K+ channels open, causing repolarization due to K+ efflux. 

Point D - Repolarization and hyperpolarization due to continued  K+ efflux.

Point E - After Hyperpolarization. The K+ channels slowly return to the closed state, causing after-hyperpolarization. Na+ channels are reset and are ready to respond to another depolarizing stimulus.

Both channels then close and the membrane returns to resting membrane potential.

questions.text: A patient has serum bilirubin of 4.9 mg/dl and serum creatinine of 5.2 mg/dl. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Atracurium can be safely used in this patient with elevated serum bilirubin and serum creatinine as it undergoes Hofmann elimination.

Atracurium and cis-atracurium undergo plasma ester hydrolysis and Hofmann elimination at physiological pH and temperature. Hofmann elimination is a spontaneous non-enzymatic organ-independent degradation. So, the clearance of atracurium and cis-atracurium is independent of liver or kidney function. Hence, they are the agents of choice in patients with liver disease and/or renal failure.

The metabolites of atracurium and cis-atracurium are monoquaternary acrylate and laudanosine.

Some of the adverse effects of atracurium are hypotension, tachycardia, and allergic reactions (bronchospasm) due to a dose-dependent histamine release. On the other hand, these adverse effects are not seen with cis-atracurium and so it is preferred over the former.

Pancuronium, rocuronium, and vecuronium are dependent on the liver for excretion.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents with complaints of a recurrent painless mass on the vulva. Local examination reveals a swelling on the right labium majus fixed to the underlying structures and solid in consistency, as seen in the image below. What should be the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image is suggestive of Bartholin's cyst. In the case of a recurrent Bartholin's cyst fixed to the underlying structures and having a solid consistency, the best next step would be to do a biopsy of the cyst wall to rule out malignancy.

Biopsy in the case of Bartholin's cyst is indicated in the following situations:

  • Age greater than 40 years
  • Postmenopausal female
  • Solid cyst
  • The cyst is fixed to a structure

Bartholin glands are the homologs of the male bulbourethral or Cowper glands. The ducts of these glands open in the groove between the hymen and the labia minora at approximately 5 and 7 o’clock positions. These glands are stimulated by sexual arousal. Contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle expresses gland secretions. The glands contain columnar cells that secrete mucus with lubricant properties.  

Clinical conditions :

Bartholin cyst: Caused by obstruction of the Bartholin ducts by proteinaceous material or by inflammation from infection. Symptomatic or recurrent cysts may require marsupialization or gland excision.

Bartholin abscess: An infected Bartholin cyst can lead to an abscess. It usually requires surgical drainage.
Clinical features:

  • Big cysts can cause abdominal and vaginal discomfort with dyspareunia. 
  • A vulval cleft of 'S' shape is usually noted on inspection.
  • It is fluctuant swelling and transillumination can be positive as the fluid collected is generally clear.

Treatment:

  • Supportive treatments including analgesia and antibiotics.
  • Specific treatment:
    • Drainage under anesthesia: Generally conservative method, chances of re-infection and formation of granulation tissue can happen.
    • Marsupialization (Option B): Complete excision of sac and cyst along with drainage of the substance. The edges are also clearly approximated. This is the ideal management.
    • Incision and drainage with word catheter placement (Option A): A deflated word catheter is used to tuck the vagina here and prevent it from damage that can happen during movement of the perineum and thus avert re-infection and granulation tissue formation. Alternatively, a 14 F foley catheter can also be used.
    • Bartholinectomy (Option D): This is a very invasive surgery and carries a greater morbidity profile. This is also associated with loss of lubricant function.

Since this patient is post-menopausal, a biopsy should be done first to rule out malignancy. After that, definitive surgical management can be done.

In a premenopausal woman which do not meet the criteria for suspected malignancy as mentioned previously, surgery can be done without a biopsy.

questions.text: A child presents with profuse, painless diarrhoea. Stool microscopy shows the following finding. What is the mechanism of action of toxin produced by this organism?

choices.text: Toxin binds to GM1 receptor and activates adenylate cyclase
Toxin binds to GM2 receptor and activates adenylate cyclase
Toxin inhibits elongation factor 2 thereby inhibiting protein synthesis.
Toxin inactivate 60s ribosome thereby inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a child presenting with profuse, painless diarrhea and stool microscopy image showing the characteristic fish in stream appearance is suggestive of Vibrio cholerae. It produces cholera toxin, which binds to the GM1 receptor and activates adenylate cyclase which increases the production of cAMP.

Cholera is a diarrheal disease caused by Vibrio cholerae serogroup O1 or O139. It is commonly acquired by eating contaminated water and shellfish. The incubation period is around 24- 48 hours. 

V. cholerae produces a heat-labile enterotoxin consisting of subunits A and B. Subunit B(binding) binds to the ganglioside GM1 mucosal receptor (option B) present in the small intestinal mucosa, which promotes entry of subunit A (active) into the enterocyte and dissociates into two fragments A1 & A2. Fragment A1 causes prolonged activation of cellular adenylate cyclase, which leads to increased levels of cAMP and results in prolonged hypersecretion of water and electrolytes (electrolyte-rich diarrhea) as much as 20–30 L/day, resulting in dehydration, shock, acidosis, and death. 

 

The selective media of the organism is taurocholate–tellurite–gelatin (TTG) agar or thiosulfate–citrate–bile salts–sucrose (TCBS) agar. Treatment involves rehydration with oral rehydration solution or ringer's lactate. Erythromycin and azithromycin are the antibiotic agents of choice.

Other options - 

Option C - Diphtheria toxin is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. The toxin produced by pseudomonas also has a similar mechanism of action.

Option D - Verocytotoxin produced by E.coli which is also known as Shiga-like-toxin inactivates 60S ribosomes by removing adenine from the rRNA and inhibiting protein synthesis.

questions.text: What is the action of the marked structure?

choices.text: Dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot
Dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot

questions.solution:
The structure marked in the given image is the tibialis anterior muscle. Its action is dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot.

Tibialis anterior can be identified as the most medial muscle of the anterior compartment of the leg. The order of the muscles in the anterior compartment of the leg is (medial to lateral): tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus and peroneus tertius. Tibialis anterior muscle is medial to extensor digitorum longus and is inserting towards the medial side of the foot and can be identified in the specimen.

Tibialis anterior muscle originates from lateral condyle and lateral surface of the tibial shaft and the adjacent interosseus membrane. It is inserted into the medial and inferior surface of the medial cuneiform and the adjoining part of the base of the first metatarsal. It receives its innervation from the deep peroneal nerve (L4 and L5). Its actions include dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot. This muscle is most active during activities in which both of these movements are combined, such as walking. 

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Plantar flexion of the foot is a function of the muscles of the posterior compartment of the leg. 

Option B: Dorsiflexion and eversion of the foot is a function of the peroneus tertius muscle. 

Option C: Extension of the great toe is a function of the extensor hallucis longus muscle.

questions.text:
A patient on anti-PD1 immunotherapy (Nivolumab) presents with pruritus, eczema, and urticarial rashes. Histopathological examination reveals a subepidermal blister. The direct immunofluorescence of the lesions is shown below. What is the target antigen?

PD1: Programmed cell death protein 1
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a history of use of an anti-programmed cell death 1 (PD1) drug and direct immunofluorescence of the lesions showed linear C3 and IgG deposition on the basement membrane is suggestive of bullous pemphigoid. The target antigen in bullous pemphigoid is BP 180.

Bullous pemphigoid is one of the most common subepidermal immunobullous disorders. It is commonly seen in the elderly. It is characterized by serum IgG antibodies directed against BP180 and BP 230 antigens of hemidesmosomes at the dermo-epidermal junction.

Anti-programmed cell death 1 (PD1) targeted immune checkpoint inhibitors such as nivolumab and pembrolizumab are associated with an increased risk of development of bullous pemphigoid. Histopathology will show the presence of subepidermal bullae with eosinophils. Immunofluorescence will show the presence of subepidermal split and linear deposition of IgG antibodies and C3 at the dermo-epidermal junction.

Clinical features include:

  • Prodromal phase with excoriated papules, eczematous or urticarial skin lesions and haemorrhagic crusts may be seen.
  • Bullous phase is characterized by:
    • Intense pruritus is almost constantly present.
    • Symmetrically distributed tense bullae and vesicles over the flexural aspects and abdomen of the body.
    • Lesions heal without scarring, provided there are no superinfections.
    • The bullae contain clear, sometimes hemorrhagic exudates.
    • Nikolsky's sign is negative.
    • Oral or mucosal lesions and milia formation are rare.

 

Untreated bullous pemphigoid has a chronic, self-limiting course, with remissions and relapses. Complete remissions are possible with treatment.

Bullous pemphigoid is mainly treated with topical and systemic corticosteroids. Other drugs used like azathioprine, dapsone, doxycycline and immunomodulatory are also used.

Other options:

Option B and C: Pemphigus is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3, Dsg1), which are present intercellularly.  Fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence is seen in pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis targets epidermal transglutaminase 3. Direct immunofluorescence shows focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is currently on treatment with metformin, linaligliptin, losartan, nifedipine, and lovastatin. His recent laboratory investigations are given. Which medication will require dose reduction or change?
Fasting blood sugar 115 mg/dL (normal 70−110)
Creatinine 3.4 mg/dL (normal 0.6−1.2)
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol 85 mg/dL (normal < 100)
questions.solution:
The elevated serum creatinine level in this patient indicates compromised renal function. Among the given list of drugs, metformin is the only medication with renal excretion and is contraindicated in patients with renal failure.

Metformin has been associated with lactic acidosis in patients with impaired renal function.

All the other medications listed above undergo hepatic excretion and do not require dose adjustment in renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with the Bagel sign on sonography as shown below?
questions.solution:
Bagel sign on an ultrasonogram (USG) is seen in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.

Bagel sign is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Other options:

Option C: Double decidual sac sign is seen on USG in early intrauterine pregnancy. It is seen ​​as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac (image below).

 

Option D: Spalding sign is seen on USG in intrauterine fetal demise (IUFD). It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another (image below).

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are accurate criteria for selecting a patient for LASIK surgery?
  1. Age less than 18 years 
  2. Trial of contact lenses or glasses
  3. At least 1 year of stable refractive error 
  4. Corneal thickness <450 microns
questions.solution:
A history of contact lens or glasses usage is a prerequisite for LASIK, and at least 1 year of stable refractive error before surgery is mandatory for optimal results. 

Laser-assisted in situ keratomileusis or LASIK with the excimer laser is the most popular and widely accepted treatment modality among all the choices available at present. Excimer laser beam reshapes the cornea by ablating the superficial stroma to a predetermined extent after lifting a flap of the cornea with a sharp microkeratome. 

Patient selection criteria:

  • Ideally in individuals aged 21 years and above.
  • In individuals who have a stable refractive error for at least 1 year.
  • In individuals who have had unsatisfactory results with non-surgical treatment.
  • In individuals in whom corneal-thinning disorders such as keratoconus have been ruled out. (A normal corneal thickness is around 540-550 microns. Incidence of corneal ectasia increases with a thin cornea and therefore a corneal thickness of <450 microns is not a criteria for LASIK eligibility) 

Complications:

  • Tear instability (dry eye)
  • Wrinkling, distortion, or dislocation of the flap
  • Subepithelial haze with resultant glare, especially at night.
  • Persistent epithelial defects.
  • Epithelial ingrowth under the flap.
  • Diffuse lamellar keratitis (sands of the Sahara)
  • Corneal ectasia
  • Keratoconus

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease started receiving dialysis. Which of his neurological complications can be reversed?
questions.solution:
Uremic encephalopathy in chronic kidney disease is reversible by dialysis.

Uremic encephalopathy occurs due to the aggregation of uremic toxins which in turn damages the neurons. It is seen in chronic kidney disease.

Symptoms begin with difficulty in concentrating and can progress to lethargy, confusion, seizure, cognitive impairment, and coma. Physical findings may include altered mental status, weakness, and asterixis. These findings improve with dialysis.

Electroencephalogram in uremic encephalopathy shows triphasic waves. 

Neurologic complications, which can manifest with advanced CKD and do not improve with dialysis therapy include -

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Restless leg syndrome (15-20%)

questions.text: Which of the following structure is most likely to be injured in a wrist slash injury over the radial side of the left wrist?
questions.solution:
Median nerve is more likey to be injured in case of deep laceration of radial side of the wrist.

Wrist slash injuries:

A deep laceration on the radial side of the wrist may injure the radial artery, median nerve, flexor carpi radialis tendon, and palmaris longus tendon.

A deep laceration on the ulnar side of the wrist may injure the ulnar artery, ulnar nerve, and flexor carpi ulnaris tendon.

questions.text: Echopraxia is a symptom that is seen in catatonic patients, where the patient typically _______________

choices.text: Mimics the action of other person
Mimics the speech of other person
Makes odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions
Makes no response to instructions or external stimuli

questions.solution:
Mimicking the action of another person is known as echopraxia. 

Catatonia is mostly seen in advanced primary mood or psychotic illnesses, including schizophrenia

The features of catatonia are:

  1. Mutism: Complete absence of speech
  2. Rigidity: Maintenance of a rigid posture against efforts to be moved
  3. Negativism: An apparently motiveless resistance to all commands and attempts to be moved, or doing just the opposite.
  4. Posturing: Voluntary assumption of an inappropriate and often bizarre posture for long periods of time
  5. Stupor: Akinesis (no movement) with mutism but with evidence of relative preservation of conscious awareness
  6. Echolalia: Repetition, echo or mimicking of phrases or words heard
  7. Echopraxia: Repetition, echo or mimicking of actions observed
  8. Waxy flexibility: Parts of the body can be placed in positions that will be maintained for long periods of time, even if very uncomfortable; flexible like wax.
  9. Ambitendency: Due to ambivalence, conflicting impulses and tentative actions are made, but no goal-directed action occurs, e.g. on asking to take out the tongue, the tongue is slightly protruded but taken back again.
  10. Other signs such as mannerisms, stereotypes (verbal and behavioural), automatic obedience (commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature) and verbigeration (incomprehensible speech).

questions.text: An elderly man with hepatocellular carcinoma is scheduled to undergo a left hepatectomy. Which of the following Couinaud's liver segments will be removed during this procedure?
questions.solution:
The surgical term left hepatectomy corresponds to the removal of Couinaud segments 2, 3, and 4.

The Couinaud classification is a system used to categorize the liver into two primary functional lobes: the left and right lobes. The lobes are further divided into eight functional segments, based on hepatic portal venous branches. Each of these segments is supported by a biliary triad comprising branches from the hepatic artery, portal vein, and bile duct. 

The given image shows Couinauds segments corresponding to various procedures:

Other options:

Option A - Segments 6, 7 correspond to right posterior sectionectomy.

Option B - Segments 5, 6, 7, 8 corresponds to right hepatectomy or right hemihepatectomy.

Option C - Segments 2, 3 corresponds to left lateral sectionectomy.

Related Pearl: Couinaud's liver segments

The Couinaud classification is currently the most widely used system to describe functional liver anatomy.

  • Based on the distribution of hepatic portal venous branches in the parenchyma
  • Each segment has its own dual vascular inflow, biliary drainage and lymphatic drainage

Segment I corresponds to the gross anatomical caudate lobe and is considered as posterior segment.

questions.text: A person with a gunshot wound of size 3 cm presents with a comminuted fracture of the tibia. On examination, the distal pulse could not be felt. Which grade does this belong to according to the Gustilo-Anderson classification?

An open fracture, with an arterial injury, that requires repair regardless of the size of the soft tissue wound, belongs to classification IIIC.

questions.text: A patient with long standing liver cirrhosis presents with renal dysfunction and is suspected to have hepatorenal syndrome. Which of the following statements regarding its management is true?

choices.text: Treatment involves concomitant liver and renal transplant
Definitive treatment of this condition is renal transplant
Recovery of kidney function can occur spontaneously post liver transplantation
Terlipressin has no role in management of this condition

questions.solution:
Renal function can recover spontaneously in cases of hepatorenal syndrome (HRS) after a liver transplantation. 

Hepatorenal syndrome is a progressive renal failure in patients with acute or chronic liver disease. The diagnostic criteria for hepatorenal syndrome include:

  • Cirrhosis with ascites
  • Diagnosis of acute kidney injury (AKI)
    • Increase in serum creatinine of ≥ 0.3mg/dL in 48 hours, OR
    • 50% increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days
  • Absence of shock
  • No evidence of recent use of nephrotoxic agents
  • Absence of intrinsic renal disease
  • Other criteria that also apply:
    • Urine red cell excretion of fewer than 50 cells per high power field (when no urinary catheter is in place) and protein excretion less than 500 mg/day
    • Lack of improvement in kidney function after volume expansion with intravenous albumin (1 g/kg of body weight per day up to 100 g/day) for at least two days and withdrawal of diuretics

Management of hepatorenal syndrome includes:

  • Norepinephrine
  • Octreotide
  • Terlipressin (Option D)
  • Midodrine
  • Intravenous albumin 
  • Liver transplantation - definitive treatment

Renal transplantation (Options A and B) is not indicated in HRS.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with weakness of the left arm and left face. His visual field and movements of the right leg are found to be normal. Occlusion of which of the following vessels would explain his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of left arm paresis along with sparing of the legs, suggests occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) which is marked as '3' (option C) in the given image:

 

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is the largest branch of the internal carotid artery and it runs in the lateral cerebral sulcus. It supplies most of the lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere thereby supplying the entire motor area except the "leg area". 

Middle cerebral artery occlusion produces:

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss involving the face and arm (faciobrachial monoplegia) as it supplies the precentral and postcentral gyri. 
  • Aphasia if the left hemisphere is affected 
  • Anosognosia if the right hemisphere is affected

Other structures marked in the image are as follows:

1 depicts the anterior communicating artery.

2 depicts the anterior cerebral artery. The legs would be involved in occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery.

4 depicts the posterior cerebral arteries. The visual field would be involved in occlusion of the posterior cerebral arteries.

Related Pearl: Blood supply of Brain

The brain is supplied by Internal Carotid arteries and Vertebrobasilar arteries. 

Areas supplied by various arteries
Anterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves around the corpus callosum within the sagittal fissure

Supply - Dorsomedial frontal and parietal lobes

Effects of occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA): 

- Contralateral Paralysis (or weakness) of muscles of the leg and foot - Upper part of motor area affected.

- Contralateral Loss (or dulling) of sensations from the leg and foot - Upper part of the sensory area affected.
Middle Cerebral Artery

Course - Runs within Sylvian fissure

Supply - Lateral convexity of the cerebral cortex

Effects of occlusion of middle cerebral artery (MCA):

- Contralateral Hemiplegia -  loss of sensations. The face and arms are most affected, foot and leg are spared.  

- Aphasia - Broca’s and Wernicke’s areas affected, especially if the thrombosis is in the left hemisphere in a right-handed person.  

- Contralateral Homonymous hemianopia - due to the involvement of optic radiation.  
Posterior Cerebral Artery

Course - Curves behind the midbrain

Supply - Occipital lobe and inferior and medial temporal lobe

Effects of occlusion of posterior cerebral artery (PCA):

- Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing - Affected Cortical blood supply > Damage to association cortex of visual area causes visual hallucinations (distortion of colour vision).

Note: Macular sparing is due to collateral circulation from MCA to that cortical region. 

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: The type of joint between a tooth and its socket is?
questions.solution:
Gomphosis (dentoalveolar syndesmosis) is a peg-and-socket joint between a tooth and its socket. 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are joined together by fibrous tissue. They are further classified as sutures, syndesmosis, and gomphosis.

Classification of Fibrous joints:

Sutures - Peculiar to the skull. Bones are separated by a layer of membrane-derived connective tissue. Examples include

  • Plane - internasal suture
  • Serrate - interparietal suture
  • Squamous - temporoparietal suture
  • Denticulate - lambdoid suture
  • Schindylesis type, specialized suture in which a ridged bone fits into a groove on a neighboring bone - the cleft between the alae of the vomer receives the rostrum of the sphenoid

Syndesmosis - There is a true fibrous connection between bones. Examples include

  • Connected by interosseous ligament - tibiofibular syndesmosis and radioulnar syndesmosis
  • Connected by a dense fibrous membrane - posterior region of sacroiliac joint

Gomphosis - A peg sits inside a socket supported by fibrous connections. Example includes

  • The tooth in its socket

questions.text:
Match the following diseases with their associated type of mutation.
Disease Mutation type
1. Sickle cell disease A. Nonsense mutation
2. β-Thalassemia major B. Frameshift mutation
3. Duchene muscular dystrophy C. Codon deletion
4. Cystic fibrosis D. Missense mutation
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C.

Disease Mutation type
1. Sickle cell disease D. Missense mutation
2. β-Thalassemia major A. Nonsense mutation
3. Duchenne muscular dystrophy  B. Frameshift mutation
4. Cystic fibrosis C. Codon deletion


Sickle cell disease is a hemolytic anaemia which occurs due to a missense mutation of the β-globin gene. Here, GAG which codes for glutamate is replaced by GUG which codes for valine. This leads to the polymerization of deoxygenated haemoglobin and the production of sickle-shaped RBCs.

β-Thalassemia major is the most severe form of β-Thalassemia, where there is total absence of β-chains in the structure of haemoglobin. It occurs most commonly due to nonsense mutation which leads to premature chain termination and prevents the synthesis of any functional β-globin.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is caused by loss-of-function mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome. It is typically associated with deletions or frameshift mutations that result in a total absence of dystrophin.

Cystic fibrosis is a multi-system disorder which occurs due to the mutation of the CFTR gene. The most common CFTR mutation is F508 deletion(phenylalanine deletion).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man was found dead in the rodenticide factory he works at. The autopsy shows that his gastric contents have a characteristic garlicky odor and are luminous in appearance. What will be the likely color of postmortem lividity in this case?
questions.solution:
The given scenario, in which an autopsy reveals a garlicky odor from gastric contents alongside a luminous appearance, is suggestive of death due to phosphorus poisoning. The likely color of postmortem lividity in this case will be dark brown or yellow.

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms: white phosphorus, which is highly toxic, and red phosphorus, which is non-toxic. Phosphorus is utilized in fertilizers, vermin-killers, rodenticides, fireworks, and gunpowder.

The initial stage of acute poisoning through ingestion involves severe abdominal discomfort, vomiting, and diarrhea. Excreta and breath have a garlicky odor. Luminescent feces and vomit are characteristically seen. Direct contact with the skin can result in second and third-degree burns. Shock, hematemesis due to liver failure, and renal insufficiency are potential causes of death. 

Regular inhalation of phosphorus fumes, leading to chronic phosphorus poisoning, results in necrosis of the lower jaw around a decayed tooth. This condition is known as phossy jaw and is associated with the discharge of foul-smelling pus from multiple sinuses.

Other options:

Option A: Black postmortem lividity is seen in cases of opioid poisoning.

Option B: Bluish-green postmortem lividity is seen in cases of hydrogen sulfide (H2S) poisoning.

Option C: Brick-red postmortem lividity is seen in cases of cyanide or hydrocyanic acid (HCN) poisoning.

questions.text: A patient with anemia undergoes a test on a blood sample and his results are shown in the image below. Which of the following characteristics are shown by the cells affected in this condition?

choices.text: High mechanical fragility; High osmotic fragility
High mechanical fragility; Low osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility; High osmotic fragility
Low mechanical fragility; Low osmotic fragility

questions.solution:
The given image shows NESTROFT i.e. Naked Eye Single Tube Red cell Osmotic Fragility test, which is a screening test for thalassemia. The red blood cells in thalassemia will show a high mechanical fragility and low osmotic fragility.

The principle of NESTROFT is based on the low osmotic fragility of red cells in thalassemia. It is performed as follows:

  1. Mix EDTA blood and 0.36% buffered saline solution.
  2. Shake the tube and leave it at room temperature for 30 minutes.
  3. Shake the tube again and immediately hold the tube in front of a piece of paper with text or lines.

Due to decreased osmotic fragility, the cells do not lyse in 0.36% saline solution. Therefore, if this test tube is held against a white paper with a thin black line, the line will not be visible.

Thalassemia can cause RBCs to become smaller and less flexible. This can make them more mechanically fragile.

questions.text: A young man has recently undergone a vasectomy. How long should this patient use additional contraceptive methods?
questions.solution:
The patient should use additional contraceptive measures for 3 months after undergoing vasectomy.

Vasectomy is a permanent sterilization procedure done in males, where a segment of the vas deferens is resected and ligated bilaterally.

This procedure is done under local anesthesia. A small incision is made in the scrotum. The vas deferens is divided on both sides, disrupting the passage of sperms. The no-scalpel technique has been now adopted. One single incision is made with special forceps, and a skin stitch is not required. Clips and plugs can be applied over the vas instead of cutting. The failure rate of vasectomy is 0.15%.

It is a relatively simple procedure with low rates of complications. A patient who had a vasectomy is not sterile immediately after the procedure because semen is stored in distal channels of the vas deferens for varying periods.

It is estimated that at least 20 ejaculations or 3 months are required to empty the stored semen.

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of the development of the pancreas in sequence.
  1. Differential growth of the wall of gut
  2. Appearance of dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds
  3. Fusion of buds
  4. Rotation of duodenal loop
questions.solution:
The development of the pancreas occurs in the following sequence 2-4-1-3:

2. The appearance of dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds
4. Rotation of duodenal loop
1. Differential growth of the wall of gut
3. Fusion of buds

The steps of pancreatic development are as follows:

  • The pancreas develops from two buds, dorsal and ventral, originating from the endodermal lining of the duodenum.
  • When the duodenum rotates to the right and becomes C-shaped, the ventral bud along with the primitive bile duct lies on the right while the dorsal bud is present to the left of the duodenum.
  • Differential growth of the gut wall shifts the ventral bud closer to the dorsal bud.
  • This is followed by the fusion of the parenchyma and the duct systems of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds.

The parenchyma of the pancreas:

  • Ventral pancreatic bud forms the lower part of the head and uncinate process.
  • Dorsal pancreatic bud forms the upper part of the head, neck, body, and tail.

Pancreatic ducts

  • The main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) is formed by the duct of the ventral bud (proximal part), oblique cross-communication between the 2 ducts (middle part), and the duct of the dorsal bud (distal part).
  • The accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) is formed by the proximal part of the dorsal pancreatic duct.

questions.text:
Assertion: Amphotericin B is given as 5% Dextrose infusion.

Reason: Coadministration of dextrose reduces nephrotoxicity.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both the assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true but the reason is false
Assertion is false but the reason is true

questions.solution:
Amphotericin B is given as 5% Dextrose infusion since 5% Dextrose serves as a carrier for amphotericin.

500 mL of 0.9% saline should be infused before and/or after the administration of IV amphotericin B. This is because sodium restriction is associated with an increased risk of nephrotoxicity. Hence, normal saline(not 5% dextrose) is administered for nephrotoxicity prevention.

questions.text: A 80-year-old man with a known history of varicose veins, presents with an ulcer over the gaiter zone of his leg. The intern is instructed to start the patient on Bisgaard’s regimen. Which of the following is not a component of this regimen?

choices.text: Elevation of limb to reduce edema
Early use of pentoxifylline to improve circulation

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an ulcer over the gaiter zone developing in a patient with a history of varicose veins is suggestive of a venous ulcer. Pentoxifylline to improve circulation is not a component of Bisgaard’s regimen.

Venous ulcers are due to chronic venous insufficiency and are particularly seen in the lower ⅓ of the leg above the ankle on the medial aspect, known as the gaiter zone. Ambulatory venous hypertension is the most acceptable theory in the pathophysiology of venous ulcers. Venous ulcers have a sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by slough and exudate. Marjolin’s ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma seen in chronic long-standing venous ulcers.

 

Management of venous ulcers:

  • Bisgaard's regimen (4Es)
    • Education of the patient
    • Elevation of the affected limb to reduce the edema
    • Elastic compression stockings - The ideal interface pressure in venous ulceration is 35-40 mmHg.
    • Evaluation
  • 4-layer bandaging system comprising of:
    • Orthopedic wool
    • Cotton crepe
    • Elastic bandage - first compressive layer
    • Cohesive bandage - second compressive layer
  • Antibiotics are given only if the wound is infected.
  • Regular dressing.
  • Medical management by oral pentoxifylline is considered which helps in reducing the viscosity and improving circulation. 
  • Surgical management by ulcer excision with pinch mesh grafting has a good outcome and helps in preventing recurrence.

Vacuum-assisted closure (VAC) is a negative pressure dressing. An occlusive dressing is placed over the sore and it is connected to VAC that generates -125mmHg of pressure. It is used in chronic non-healing ulcers, venous ulcers, diabetic ulcers, burn wounds, and bed sores.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient came to the emergency department after a fall on an outstretched hand. The radiograph of the arm is shown below. Which of the following findings can be seen due to the nerve injury that would likely occur in this condition?

choices.text: Loss of sensation in anatomical snuff box only
Loss of sensation in anatomical snuff box and loss of wrist extension
Wasting of thenar eminence and loss of sensation in thumb

questions.solution:
The given image and clinical scenario with a fall on an outstretched hand is suggestive of a shaft of humerus fracture which may lead to an injury to the radial nerve. Radial nerve injury leads to weakness of the extensors of the wrist and diminished sensations in the region of anatomical snuff box.

Radial nerve injuries:

  • Very high lesions like the lesions around the shoulder joint and axilla, it results in loss of extension of the elbow, wrist, and hand.
  • In high lesions like fractures of the humerus and prolonged tourniquet pressure, there is wrist drop, due to weakness of the radial extensors of the wrist, as well as inability to extend the metacarpophalangeal joints. It will also be associated with a sensory loss on the skin over the anatomical snuff box. In a high radial nerve palsy, all the muscles supplied by the radial nerve are paralyzed, except the triceps and anconeus (Options A and D).
  • Low lesions occur due to the fracture or dislocations of the elbow. The wrist and elbow extension is preserved but the patient cannot extend the metacarpophalangeal joint.

Option C: Wasting of the thenar eminence is seen in cases with injury to the median nerve.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about the complement system?
  1. C5b acts as a chemotactic agent for neutrophils and monocytes
  2. C3a stimulates histamine release from mast cells
  3. C3b promotes phagocytosis of microbes by acting as an opsonin
  4. Deficiency of C2 inhibitor causes hereditary angioedema
  5. Terminal complement deficiency predisposes to Neisseria infections
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, and 5 are true about the complement system.

The complement system comprises a group of plasma proteins primarily responsible for host defense against microbes and pathological inflammatory reactions. Some of these proteins are numbered C1 through C9. This system plays a crucial role in both innate and adaptive immunity.

The first step in complement activation involves the proteolysis of component C3 which is cleaved into C3a and C3b with the assistance of the active enzyme C3 convertase. The activated components serve various functions in inflammation and defense. C3a, C4a, and C5a stimulate the release of histamine from mast cells (statement 2), leading to increased vascular permeability and vasodilation. They are referred to as anaphylatoxins. 

When fixed to a bacterial cell wall, C3b functions as an opsonin, promoting phagocytosis (statement 3). C5a serves as a chemotactic agent for white blood cells and additionally activates the lipooxygenase system in arachidonic acid metabolism, further triggering the release of inflammatory mediators.

Terminal complement deficiency is the deficiency of factors C5-C9. These complement proteins are involved in the formation of the membrane attack complex for killing microbes. Deficiency of these components predisposes to recurrent Neisseria infections (statement 5). 

Other options:

Statement 1: C5a acts as a chemotactic agent for neutrophils and monocytes. C5b binds the late components (C6-C9) to form the membrane attack complex. 

Statement 4: Inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitor causes hereditary angioedema.

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.
