questions.text: A cattle farmer presents with chronic, undulant fever, night sweats, fatigue, and joint pain. A coccobacillus that is Castenada test positive is isolated. Which of the following cells is most likely the primary target of the causative agent?

choices.text: Red blood cells in the circulation
Neurons in the central nervous system

questions.solution:
This patient with symptoms of chronic, undulant fever, night sweats, fatigue, and joint pain with an infection by a coccobacillus that is Castenada test positive likely has Brucellosis. Monocytes and macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system are the primary target cells for Brucellosis. 

Brucellosis is transmitted to humans from contact with or consumption of contaminated products. Brucellae are intracellular pathogens with a particular affinity for mononuclear phagocytic cells (macrophages and monocytes) found in the reticuloendothelial system (lymph nodes, spleen, liver, and bone marrow). These bacteria proliferate within the reticuloendothelial system, which accounts for its resistance to simple antimicrobial therapy. 

Patients with acute infection may present with undulant fever, arthralgia, muscular pain, sweating, loss of weight, and appetite. CNS symptoms such as fatigue, irritability, and depression might also occur. Chronic infection tends to be episodic with non-specific symptoms. 

Laboratory diagnosis of brucellosis includes:

  • Polymerase chain reaction
  • Blood culture with the Castaneda method
  • Serological methods include standard agglutination test (SAT), complement fixation test, Coomb’s antiglobulin test, and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA).
  • Tests for animals and animal products: Milk ring tests and Rose Bengal card tests.
  • Milk ring test- A sample of milk is mixed with stained brucella antigen and incubated. If the sample contains antibodies, agglutination occurs seen as a blue ring. 

Treatment includes antimicrobial therapy with IM streptomycin and oral Doxycycline. Prevention of brucellosis can be achieved by pasteurization of milk and milk products.

Other options: 

Option A: Epithelial cells in the lungs: While some bacteria target the lungs, the clinical presentation and occupational history point towards a different organ system.

Option B: Red blood cells in the circulation: Brucellosis primarily affects immune cells, not red blood cells.

Option C: Neurons in the central nervous system: Though brucellosis can rarely involve the nervous system, it wouldn't be the primary target in this case.

questions.text: Whiplash injury is an example of which of the following mechanisms of injury?
questions.solution:
Whiplash injury (sprained neck syndrome/cervical acceleration-deceleration injury) is almost always due to an extension force as in a rear-end collision in RTA. The term whiplash has served effectively to enhance public apprehension at its occurence.

  • A flexion rotation force such as a fall on one side of the shoulder can cause disruption of facet capsule.
  • Pure flexion forces such as fall from the height may result in compression fractures of the vertebral body.
  • In Axial compression fall of an object on the head results in load compression like in explosive comminuted fracture of C5 body.

questions.text: Regarding synaptic transmission, which of the following physiologic processes is correctly paired with a structure?

choices.text: Synaptic vesicle docking and fusion: presynaptic nerve terminal
Action potential initiation: Node of Ranvier

questions.solution:
When the neuronal action potential reaches the presynaptic nerve terminal, voltage-gated calcium channels open and the influx of calcium causes synaptic vesicle docking and fusion leading to the release of neurotransmitter vesicles into the synaptic cleft.

Other options:

Option A: The inhibitory interneuron causing negative feedback inhibition of a spinal motor neuron is called a Renshaw cell and its neurotransmitter is glycine.

Option C: The binding of acetylcholine to the nicotinic cholinergic (NM) receptors results in an influx of Na+ that produces a depolarizing potential called the endplate potential.

Option D: In a spinal motor neuron, initiation of nerve impulse occurs in the axon hillock and initial segment of the axon because it has a very high density of voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a 2-day history of fever and joint pain. She had a sore throat 3 weeks back, for which she was not given any medications. She has a rash on her body as shown in the image below. Identify the skin rash.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young girl presenting with fever, joint pain, and a recent history of sore throat is suggestive of acute rheumatic fever. The associated evanescent macular rash, with central clearing in the image, is erythema marginatum.

Erythema marginatum is included as a major manifestation in the Jones criteria. It is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Related Pearl: Skin rashes (Erythemas)

Erythema marginatum is an evanescent, non-pruritic rash over the trunk and extremities seen in rheumatic fever.

 

Erythema nodosum is an acute, nodular, erythematous, painful eruption, occurring probably due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction to a variety of antigens. Lesions are usually seen over the extensor aspects of the legs. Its causes include infections (tuberculosis), autoimmune (IBD and sarcoidosis), idiopathic.

 

Erythema migrans has a bull's-eye appearance (central erythema and necrosis) and is seen in Lyme disease.

 

Erythema multiforme lesions usually have a target appearance; it is mediated by the deposition of immune complexes in the superficial microvasculature of the skin and oral mucosal membrane. It is usually triggered by certain infections (herpes simplex virus) and drugs.

questions.text: Name the procedure for which the following set of instruments are used.
questions.solution:
The given set of instruments is used for dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR).

 

Instrument 1 shows Muller's self-retaining lacrimal wound retractor. It is made up of two limbs with three curved pins on each for engaging the edges of the skin incision. The limbs are kept in a retracted position with the help of a fixing screw. It is used to retract the skin during surgery on the lacrimal sac e.g. dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) or dacryocystectomy (DCT).

 Instrument 2 shows Nettleship's lacrimal punctum dilator. It has a cylindrical corrugated metal handle with a conical pointed tip. It is used to dilate the punctum and canaliculus during syringing, probing, dacryocystography, DCT, and DCR procedures.

 Instrument 3 shows Bowman's lacrimal probe. It has blunt ends with a central stable platform. It is used to:

  • Probe the lacrimal gland in the management of congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction
  • Identify the lacrimal sac during DCR and DCT.

 Instrument 4 shows lacrimal cannula. It is a long curved hypodermic needle with a blunt tip. It is used for: 

  • Syringing the lacrimal passages
  • Injecting air, tryphan blue dye, pilocarpine, and balanced salt solution in the anterior chamber during intraocular surgery

Instrument 5 shows a bone punch. It consists of a stout spring handle and two blades attached at a right angle. The upper blade has a small hole with a sharp cutting edge. The lower blade has a cup-like depression. It is used to enlarge the bony opening during DCR operation by punching the bone from the margins of the opening.

Instrument 6 shows the chisel. It consists of a blade having a sharp-cutting straight edge with one surface bevelled. It has a long and stout handle. It is used to cut the bone during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 7 shows the hammer. It is a small steel hammer attached to a corrugated handle. It is used to hammer the chisel during DCR and orbitotomy operations.

Instrument 8 shows the lacrimal sac dissector and curette. It is a cylindrical instrument, one end of which is a blunt-tipped dissector, and the other end is curetted. It is used to curette the lacrimal sac in lacrimal sac surgery.

Instrument 9 shows Freer's periosteum elevator. It has a rounded handle with two slightly curved, tear-drop tips. It is used for blunt debulking and lifting periosteum from bones in confined areas. It is used in endoscopic septoplasty and DCR.

questions.text: A statistician is working with a gynecologist on a study about “Awareness regarding Pap smear.” They administer a questionnaire with 50 questions to 200 women, and each correct response gets 1 point. They find that the data are positively skewed. Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively, of the same?
questions.solution:
In a positively skewed data set, mean>median>mode. Hence, here, the mean, median, and mode must be 25, 23, and 20, respectively. None of the other options is consistent with mean > median > mode.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there is an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is demonstrated in the graph below:

 

Other options:

Option A: In a negatively skewed distribution, mean<median<mode.

Option C: In a normal distribution, mean=median=mode.

Option D: The set of values is not representative of either a normal or a skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Measures in Statistics

Measures used in statistics

Definition

Examples

Measures of Location or Central Tendency

These measures summarize the data by defining the centre or the middle.

An entire distribution can be characterized by these measures which represent all the observations.

Mean, median, mode

Measures of Dispersion or Variability or Spread

These measures help in determining the extent to which data is stretched or squeezed.

Range, interquartile range, variance, standard deviation

Measures of Position

These measures give the position of specific data in relation to other data in the set.

Percentiles, quartiles, centiles,  z scores

questions.text:
Below is an image illustrating three types of agarose gel electrophoresis patterns of DNA. Which cellular features are associated with the process responsible for producing pattern ‘3’?
  1. Myelin figures
  2. Nuclear shrinkage
  3. Cytoplasmic bleb formation
  4. Karyorrhexis
  5. Cytoplasmic vacuolation
questions.solution:
In the given image of agarose gel electrophoresis patterns of DNA, pattern ‘3’ shows a smear pattern that represents necrosis. The cellular changes that are associated with necrosis are myelin figures (precipitated phospholipids), nuclear shrinkage (pyknosis), karyorrhexis (nuclear fragmentation), and cytoplasmic vacuolation. 

Necrosis is a pathological process that occurs after severe cell injuries. It is characterized by the denaturation of cellular proteins, leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, and enzymatic digestion of the lethally injured cell.

In H&E stains, necrotic cells show increased eosinophilia and a glassy homogenous appearance due to the loss of glycogen. Enzymatic digestion of the cell’s organelles leads to cytoplasmic vacuolation and a moth-eaten appearance. Dead cells may be replaced by precipitated phospholipids known as myelin figures.

Nuclear changes are seen as one of the three patterns:

  • Karyolysis - enzymatic degradation of chromatin 
  • Pyknosis - nuclear shrinkage and increased basophilia
  • Karyorrhexis - fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus

The smear pattern observed in agarose gel electrophoresis results from the disorganized cleavage of DNA during necrosis. This is attributed to the activation of non-specific lysosomal nucleases.

Other options:

In the image, ‘1’ is the control pattern, and ‘2’ represents the step-ladder pattern of DNA that is seen in apoptosis. Cellular features seen in apoptosis include cell shrinkage, chromatin condensation peripherally under the nuclear membrane, formation of cytoplasmic blebs (statement 3) & apoptotic bodies, and phagocytosis of apoptotic cells.

The step-ladder pattern seen in apoptosis is a result of the precise cleavage of genomic DNA by key apoptotic proteases-caspases. This produces DNA fragments with lengths corresponding to multiple integers (approximately 180 base pairs).

questions.text: The couple protection rate of a community is 60%. What does this percentage signify?

choices.text: 60% of eligible couples are using contraception
60% of eligible couples are effectively protected against childbirth
40% of births are third or higher-order births

questions.solution:
A couple protection rate of 60% indicates that 60% of eligible couples in the community are effectively protected against unplanned childbirth through the use of one or more approved family planning methods. This encompasses both the effective utilization of contraception and procedures such as sterilization.

The couple protection rate (CPR) is an indicator of contraception practices in the community. Attaining a 60% CPR would be highly effective in restricting all third or higher-order births. It is considered a dominant factor for the reduction of the net reproduction rate.

Other options: 

Option A: While a high CPR likely indicates high contraceptive use, it also considers the effectiveness of those methods in preventing unplanned pregnancies. 60% of couples using contraception doesn't guarantee all these methods are successful in every case.

Option C: A high CPR would likely decrease unintended pregnancies. However, it doesn't indicate the exact percentage of unintended pregnancies in a community. 

Option D: A high CPR might lead to fewer third or higher-order births indirectly, but it does not measure the same.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: The ECG of a patient with systemic hypothermia is given below. The findings marked in the image are described as:
questions.solution:
The Osborn wave (J wave) is a positive deflection seen at the J point in precordial and true limb leads as seen in the given electrocardiogram. It is most commonly associated with hypothermia.

Osborn waves may be seen in the ECG of patients with systemic hypothermia. They are observed as a hump-like elevation at the junction of the QRS complex and ST segment. An alteration in the ventricular transmural action potential is attributed to their appearance on an ECG.

The J wave can be accentuated in hypothermia and hypercalcemia. Spontaneous accentuation of the J wave may predispose to ventricular arrhythmias (polymorphic VT and VF).

Other options:

Option A: Delta wave is the slurred upstroke of the QRS complex as seen during ventricular pre-excitation, a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome. 

 

Option C: Epsilon wave is representative of T wave inversion and delayed ventricular activation as seen in arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy (ARVC).

 

Option D: Saw-tooth wave is seen in atrial flutter. It is caused due to repetitive atrial excitation caused by large re-entry impulses circulating within the atrial myocardium.

questions.text: Which of the following options regarding the given pairs of diuretics and their indication is incorrect?

choices.text: Spironolactone - alcoholic patient with cirrhotic ascites
Intravenous mannitol - patient with an acute attack of glaucoma
Acetazolamide - mountaineer with acute mountain sickness
Furosemide - patient with lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

questions.solution:
Amiloride is the most appropriate treatment for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI). Furesemide is contraindicated in the management of lithium induced diabetes insipidus. 

The development of NDI is related to the accumulation of Li+ in distal tubular cells and subsequent inhibition of GSK-3β, leading to vasopressin insensitivity and downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels. Amiloride is a potassium-sparing diuretic that blocks entry of Li+ into renal distal tubule ENaCs and thus can be used to treat lithium-induced NDI. 

Drugs that cause diuresis lead to sodium loss which in turn leads to compensatory Lithium absorption from the proximal tubule, thus leading to toxicity. Hence, furosemide, bumetanide, hydrochlorothiazide and losartan can all cause lithium toxicity

Increased reabsorption of lithium from the proximal tubules is also seen with non-steroid anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen, naproxen, and possibly aspirin.

Other options:

Spironolactone is used in the treatment of ascites due to cirrhosis. The diuretic of choice in a patient with cirrhotic ascites is spironolactone. Spironolactone is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of the kidneys. It causes a decrease in sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubule. As a result, spironolactone promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels. Spironolactone is particularly helpful in edematous states caused or exacerbated by hyperaldosteronism such as in cirrhotic ascites.

Acetazolamide is used in the treatment of acute mountain sickness. It is available as an intravenous formulation. It is also indicated in the acute management of open-angle glaucoma for the rapid reduction of IOP.

Intravenous mannitol is used for the treatment of acute attacks of glaucoma. Other indications are:

  • Reduce cerebral edema and intracranial pressure
  • Enhancement of urinary excretion of salicylates, barbiturates, bromides, and lithium
  • For diagnosis of bronchial hyperreactivity (inhalation)
  • Antihemolytic urological irrigation during transurethral procedures

questions.text: During wound healing by secondary intention, what are the changes seen in the collagen fibers of the scar tissue by 2 weeks?

choices.text: Type 3 collagen replaced by type 1 collagen
Type 1 collagen replaced by type 3 collagen
Type 3 collagen replaced by type 4 collagen
Type 4 collagen replaced by type 3 collagen

questions.solution:
By 2 weeks of wound healing by secondary intention, type 3 collagen is replaced by type 1 collagen.

Wound healing occurs in two distinct mechanisms—first intention/primary union and secondary intention/ secondary union.

Primary union is seen in cases where only the epithelial layer is injured. An example of such healing is seen in a clean surgical incision approximated by sutures. It begins with the activation of the coagulation cascade and subsequent clot formation. This clot attracts growth factors, cytokines, and migrating cells.

Within the first 24 hours, the neutrophils migrate to the injury site. Within 24-48 hours, epithelial cells from both edges of the wound begin to migrate and form a thin layer of epidermis over the wound. By day 3, macrophages replace neutrophils, and granulation tissue starts forming. This process of neovascularization reaches its peak on day 5. 

Deposition of collagen and fibroblast proliferation is seen in the second week. By the end of the first month, the scar is formed, which is made of cellular connective tissue largely devoid of inflammatory cells but covered by an essentially normal epidermis.

Wounds heal by secondary intention when the wound is large, involving a more significant loss of cells and tissues. Since the wound is large, the blood clot formed is large. This leads to increased inflammation and increased formation of granulation tissue. The provisional matrix has fibrin, plasma fibronectin, and type III collagen. In two weeks, it is replaced by type I collagen. This remodeling makes the collagen more organized while increasing strength at the site of injury. By the end of 1 month, the scar tissue, mainly made of acellular connective tissue, is formed, and myofibroblasts in the scar tissue cause wound contraction.

Related Pearl: Factors Influencing Healing

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios is not included under cognizable offense?

choices.text: Accepting gift hampers on referral of patient
Operating under the influence of alcohol

questions.solution:
Accepting gift hampers on the referral of patients is not a cognizable offense. 

Accepting gift hampers on the referral of patients comes under dichotomy. It is a type of unethical act, wherein a physician offers or receives any gift or bonus for referring or procuring any patient for medical or surgical treatment. 

A cognizable offense is that in which a police officer can arrest a person without having a warrant from the magistrate. Examples include cases of rape, murder, dowry death, and death due to rash or negligent acts. In such cases, the individual is sent by the police to the doctor for a medical examination. 

Punishments for cognizable offense: 

  • Death
  • Imprisonment for life
  • Imprisonment could be rigorous and involve hard labor
  • Forfeiture of property
  • Fine

In non-cognizable offenses, the accused cannot be arrested without a warrant issued by the magistrate. The injured person can directly go to the doctor or he may file an affidavit in the court of a magistrate, who will send him to the doctor for examination and report. 

Other options:

Options B and C: Operating under the influence of alcohol and performing amputation on the wrong limb come under criminal negligence. Criminal negligence is when a doctor lacks gross skill or care while treating, which results in serious injury/death of the patient, or when an illegal act is performed by a doctor. Criminal negligence is a cognizable offense.

Option D: Ragging in any form is a cognizable offense.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of seizures. Imaging revealed the presence of a tumor in the frontal lobe. Surgery was done, and the biopsy specimen is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a frontal lobe tumor, presenting with seizures and the histopathology image showing the ‘fried egg appearance’ of tumor cells, points to the diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.

Oligodendroglioma is a subtype of infiltrating glioma. It is comprised of cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumors are composed of sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives it the ‘fried egg appearance.’ The tumor cells that infiltrate the cortex usually collect around the neuron, and this is known as perineural satellitosis. There is a delicate network of anastomosing thin-walled capillaries between the tumor cells, resembling 'chicken wire.'

Oligodendrogliomas are most commonly detected in the fourth and fifth decades of life. Patients may have had several years of antecedent neurologic complaints, often including seizures. The lesions are found mostly in the cerebral hemispheres, mainly in the frontal or temporal lobes. It is treated with a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. 

Other options:

Option A: Glioblastoma is a synonym for grade IV astrocytoma. Infiltrating astrocytomas and glioblastomas are usually seen in the cerebellum, brainstem, or spinal cord. Histologically, glioblastoma appears like an anaplastic astrocytoma with serpiginous foci of palisading necrosis and microvascular proliferation. 

Option C: Ependymomas in adults occur in the spinal cord and near the ventricles, particularly the fourth ventricle. The microscopic appearance shows both true rosettes and perivascular pseudorosettes.

Option D: Schwannomas are benign tumors often arising directly from peripheral nerves. On microscopy, they are comprised of dense areas called Antoni A areas and loose areas referred to as Antoni B areas. Antoni A areas are eosinophilic and contain spindle cells arranged in intersecting fascicles with nuclear palisading. The central nuclear-free zones are called Verocay bodies. Schwannomas are a component of NF-2.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correlation coefficient (R) of the given scattergram?
questions.solution:
The given scattergram demonstrates a strong negative correlation between the X and Y variables. The correct correlation coefficient (R) value in this case would be -0.9.

A scattergram is a graph in which the values of two variables are plotted along the two axes. Each point on the graph signifies a pair of values from the same observation. The pattern of the resulting points reveals if any correlation exists. A scattergram with positive correlation (R-value > 0) means high values of one variable are associated with high values of another variable. One with a negative correlation (R-value < 0) means high values of one variable are associated with low values of the other variable.

In the given graph, the data points show increasing values on the x-axis correspond with decreasing values on the y-axis and vice-versa (negative correlation). The “line of best fit” for the given scattergram will have data points closer to the line, demonstrating a strong negative correlation (R-value closer to -1).

 

Determining a correlation coefficient (R) involves finding the “line of best fit” (an imaginary straight line) to the plotted data points. The closer the data points to this straight line, the stronger the linear correlation between the two variables.

Other options: 

Option A: R-value of +0.3 is a weak positive correlation (R-value > 0, closer to 0 than 1), as shown below.

 

Option B: R-value of +1 is a strong positive correlation (R-value > 0, closer to 1 than 0), as shown below.

 

Option C: R-value of -0.4 is a weak negative correlation (R-value < 0, closer to 0 than 1), as shown below.

Related Pearl: Correlation

Correlation expresses the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables in terms of a correlation coefficient. It is represented by r.

  • Values of r vary from -1 (perfect negative correlation) to +1 (perfect positive correlation).
  • Value (size) of the coefficient: Indicates the strength of relationship
  • Sign of the coefficient: Indicates direction of relationship

Coefficients between ±0.5 and 1 are regarded as strong whereas those between ±0.5 and 0 are regarded as weak.

The data is plotted in a scattergram as shown in the examples given below

Examples:

Types of correlation coefficients

  1. Pearson coefficient
  2. Spearman coefficient

Coefficient of Determination (CD) =  r2

It is simply the percentage variability in one factor due to change in another variable.

questions.text:
As a mosquito control measure, use of residual spray is recommended in an area. Which of the following can be used as a residual spray?

1. DDT
2. Abate
3. Chloropyrifos
4. Lindane
5. Malathion
questions.solution:
Among the following, DDT, lindane, and malathion can be used as residual spray for mosquito control. Hence, option C is correct. 

Residual sprays are effective at controlling adult mosquitoes in households. The insecticide of choice is DDT. Other residual sprays, such as lindane, malathion, and propoxur (OMS-33), can be used in areas where mosquitoes are resistant to DDT. Indoor residual sprays (IRS) are used as the main method of vector control in rural areas. 

Abate and chloropyrifos are anti-larval measures, and not used as a residual spray for anti-adult measures. These are the most effective larvicidal agents. This is the main method of vector control in urban areas.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. Has residual action up to 18 months. Used as a residual spray.Least toxic organo-chlorine compound.
HCH (hexachlorocyclo-hexane) Synthesized by Michael Faraday. Normal HCH contains 13 – 16% of gamma isomer. Gamma-HCH or lindane has 99% gamma isomer.Short residual action – 3 months.
Malathion Least toxicity of all organophosphorus compounds. Used as an ultra-low volume spray.
Fenthion Also called baytex. Used as a residual spray.
Pyrethrum Vegetable origin – Chrysanthemum cinerariafolium. Nerve poison and is excellent as a space spray.No residual action.Synergistic action with DDT as space spray.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

questions.text: Which among the following is not used in post laryngectomy rehabilitation?
questions.solution:
Super supraglottic swallow is not used in post-laryngectomy rehabilitation.

Super-supraglottic swallow is a maneuver that prevents the aspiration of food or liquid by closing the airway before swallowing. It is used in the management of dysphagia. This method involves holding one’s breath to close the airway prior to swallowing, followed by coughing voluntarily immediately after swallowing to clear any residual food or liquid from the airway entrance. It is an effortful breath-holding technique, which not only results in Valsalva and subsequent leakage of bolus but can also result in arrhythmias. 

Other options:

Option A: A tracheoesophageal prosthesis(TEP) involves a one-way valve that is inserted through a previously-created tracheoesophageal puncture. When the patient occludes the stoma, the exhaled air is shunted through the TEP into the oesophagus, where it induces vibration of the upper oesophagal sphincter, which is responsible for phonation. It generates the most intelligible, fluent, natural-sounding voice in contrast to other laryngeal speech methods.

 

Option B: Oesophagal speech also involves vibration of the upper oesophagal sphincter and subsequent phonation. 

 

Option C: Polite yawning also called the nasal airflow-inducing maneuver is an important olfaction rehabilitation tool after a laryngectomy.

Electrolarynx produces vibrations that are transmitted through the skin toward the throat. The sound generated is converted into low-pitch speech by the vocal tract—palate, tongue, and teeth. The advantages are that is easy and quick to learn, while the disadvantages are that the voice is monotonous and the constant occupation of one hand.

  2. Coagulopathy (e.g., aspirin, warfarin, or rivaroxaban use)

  4. Suspected basal skull fracture

questions.solution:

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

  • Age >65 years
  • Coagulopathy (e.g., aspirin, warfarin, or rivaroxaban use)
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height, road traffic accident)

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was brought to the psychiatric department for counselling for an attempted suicide 2 days ago. Her father reveals that there were multiple such attempts in the past. She has a history of marked mood fluctuations and unstable relationships. Which of the following non-pharmacological therapy is advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of borderline personality disorder. The psychotherapy advised for this patient is dialectical behavioral therapy.

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP), and mentalization-based therapy (MBT) are the various psychotherapies used in the treatment of this condition. There is no consensus as to which particular therapy (viz. DBT, TFP, or MBT) is superior to the others.

A borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behavior, object relations, and self-image. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder can be made if at least 5 out of the following are shown by the patient:

  • Panicky efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment
  • Unstable interpersonal relationships
  • Marked and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self
  • Impulsivity in at least two areas of potentially self-damaging like sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating, etc.
  • Repeated suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behavior
  • Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood
  • Prolonged feeling of emptiness
  • Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty in controlling anger
  • Transient stress-related paranoid ideation

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. 

Antipsychotics help to control anger, hostility, and brief psychotic episodes. Antidepressants are used to improve depressive mood which is common in patients with borderline personality disorder.

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors help in the modulation of impulsive behavior and benzodiazepine-like alprazolam helps in improving anxiety and depression. Anticonvulsants like carbamazepine help in improving the global functioning of patients with borderline personality disorder. 

Other options:

Interpersonal psychotherapy is used in the treatment of depression. It focuses on grief over loss, interpersonal disputes, interpersonal skill deficits, and role transitions.

Exposure and response prevention is used in the treatment of OCD.

questions.text: Which of the following modes of ventilation is time-triggered, time-cycled, and pressure-limited?
questions.solution:
Pressure Controlled Ventilation (PCV) is time-triggered, time-cycled, and pressure-limited. 

In the context of ventilatory settings:

  • Mode refers to how ventilator breaths are triggered, cycled, and limited. 
  • Trigger: Defines what the ventilator senses to initiate an assisted breath. It can be either an inspiratory effort by the patient or a time-based signal. 
  • Cycle: Factors that determine the end of inspiration. For example, in volume-cycled ventilation, inspiration ends when a specific tidal volume is delivered.
  • Limiting factors: These are user-specified values that are monitored by the ventilators (eg airway pressure). If the specified parameters are exceeded, the inspiratory flow is terminated.

Other Options:

Option B: Pressure support ventilation (PSV) is patient-triggered, flow-cycled, and pressure-limited. 

Option C: In continuous positive airway pressure ventilation (CPAP), all ventilation occurs through the patient’s spontaneous efforts. It is not a true support mode of ventilation.

Option D: In synchronized mode (SIMV), assisted breaths are delivered in synchrony with the patient’s inspiratory efforts. Therefore, it is also a patient-triggered form of ventilation (not time-triggered).

questions.text: A woman is brought to the emergency after developing sudden abdominal pain at the airport. She is diaphoretic, agitated, and found to be have increased blood pressure and heart rate. Her abdominal X-ray is shown below. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Take the patient up for surgery

questions.solution:
The abdominal X-ray showing multiple cylindrical capsules in the stomach and intestine, and the patient presenting with signs and symptoms of cocaine intoxication is suggestive of body packer syndrome. The next best step in management would be to take the patient up for surgery.

Body packing involves swallowing packets of illegal drugs such as heroin, cannabis, morphine, and cocaine to smuggle them. Typically, the drugs are wrapped in latex or plastic before being swallowed. Subsequently, they are excreted with the assistance of laxatives. 

Drug toxicity can develop due to packet rupture or from passive diffusion of the drug from the stomach. Persons caught smuggling may also swallow illegal drugs to conceal the evidence from authorities. Signs and symptoms of drug toxicity appear gradually with systemic absorption.

An abdominal x-ray done for evaluation of such patients would reveal the cylindrical capsules (highlighted with *) as shown below. Surgery is indicated in those patients who exhibit the symptoms of toxicity due to the rupture of packets.

 

Other options:

Option A: Sometimes, drugs like heroin or cocaine that have the same radiodensity as feces, may be difficult to detect on X-rays. In asymptomatic, stable patients, a CT scan may be done to confirm the diagnosis. 

Option B: Colonoscopy is not done because any manipulation can rupture the packets, leading to their toxicity. 

Option D: In asymptomatic, stable patients, single-dose activated charcoal and institution of whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution is done to hasten packet elimination gently.

questions.text: Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act at which of the sites marked in the given image?
questions.solution:
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors act on the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), which is labeled as site 1.

Carbonic anhydrase is predominantly present in the epithelial cells of the PCT. By inhibiting carbonic anhydrase, HCO3- reabsorption is blocked and diuresis occurs. Examples of carbonic anhydrase inhibitors are acetazolamide, methazolamide, dichlorphenamide, and dorzolamide.

They are used in the treatment of glaucoma, urinary alkalinization in cystinuria, management of metabolic alkalosis, and acute mountain sickness. 

These drugs may lower the urinary excretion of NH4+, which can contribute to the development of hyperammonemia and hepatic encephalopathy in patients with cirrhosis.

Other options:

Option A: Site 2 is the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). Thiazides act on the DCT. They are used for the treatment of hypertension and chronic edema.

Option C: Site 3 is the descending limb of the loop of Henle. There is no diuretic with any major action here. Loop diuretics act on the thick ascending limb of Henle’s loop (TAL).

Option D: Site 4 is the collecting duct. Potassium-sparing diuretics act on the cortical collecting tubules, and vasopressin receptor antagonists act on the medullary collecting duct.

questions.text: A policeman presents with complaints of worm-like swelling over his right leg. As an intern, you perform the Trendelenburg test. Which of the following findings in the Trendelenburg test will indicate perforator incompetence?

choices.text: Gaps and pits in the deep fascia

questions.solution:
Gradual filling from below upwards would be suggestive of a positive Trendelenburg (Part II) test and indicates perforator incompetence.

Brodie-Trendelenburg test: The patient is made to lie down and the limb is elevated to empty the veins. A tourniquet is applied below the Saphenofemoral Junction (SFJ) at the groin, and then the patient is made to stand.

  • Trendelenburg l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above-downwards indicates SFJ incompetence (Option C).
  • Trendelenburg ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below- upwards indicates perforator incompetence.

Other important clinical tests for varicose veins are:

Fegan’s Test - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. The patient is asked to lie down and empty the varicose vessels by limb elevation. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence (Option D).

Modified Perthe’s Test - A tourniquet is tied around the upper part of the thigh to prevent reflux down the vein and the patient is asked to walk around. In the presence of normal communicating and deep veins, the varicose veins will shrink. If there is any block, the veins will get more distended. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate deep venous thrombosis (Option B).

Morrissey’s Cough Impulse Test - The limb is elevated to empty the varicose veins and then lowered to the bed. The patient is asked to cough forcibly. An expansile cough impulse is felt at the saphenous opening if the saphenofemoral valve is incompetent. Similarly, a bruit may be heard on auscultation when the patient is asked to cough.

questions.text: A newborn baby was found to have a heart murmur, microcephaly, microphthalmia, cataract and deafness. Upon questioning the mother, she recalls having fever and generalised body rash during the first trimester. Which of the following is the causative organism for these defects?
questions.solution:
The newborn baby has congenital rubella syndrome and the mother had suffered an infection from rubella virus in the first trimester.

Rubella or German measles is a serious infection in pregnancy that causes abortions or severe defects in the fetus if affected in the first trimester. Transmission of the virus occurs through nasopharyngeal secretions (droplets transmission). The mother usually has a fever and generalised body rash. The rash is maculopapular in nature that begins from the face and spreads to the trunk and extremities later. The incidence and severity reduce as the pregnancy advances and is rare after 20 weeks of gestation. 

There is no specific treatment for rubella virus infection in mothers. Post-exposure passive immunization can be beneficial if given within 5 days of exposure to droplets. The incidence of this disease has reduced due to the availability of MMR vaccines. MMR vaccines can be administered only to non-pregnant females as it is a live, attenuated virus. Pregnancy should be avoided for at least 1 month after vaccination.

Triad of Gregg is seen in babies with congenital rubella syndrome. The features include:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • Cataract
  • Sensorineural Hearing loss (SNHL)

Other options:

Option A: Pregnant females infected with Varicella-Zoster virus present with fever, dry cough, dyspnoea, tachypnoea and pleuritic chest pain. The highest risk of transmission to fetus is between 13 to 20 weeks of gestation. The incidence of congenital infection is almost nil after 20 weeks of gestation. Neonates with congenital varicella infection have growth restriction, microphthalmia, cerebral cortical atrophy, hydronephrosis, limb hypoplasia and cicatricial skin lesions.

Option B: Pregnant females affected with Cytomegalovirus present with infectious mononucleosis-like symptoms, that is fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy and polyarthritis. Transmission to the fetus increases as pregnancy advances and is maximum in the third trimester. Congenital infection includes growth restriction, microcephaly, intracranial (periventricular) calcifications, chorioretinitis, mental and motor deficits, hepatosplenomegaly, hemolytic anaemia, thrombocytopenic purpura. Most infected neonates are asymptomatic at birth and later present with these symptoms. 

Option D: Pregnant females are more susceptible to influenza virus infection and usually develop fever and dry cough. Few studies have shown neonates to have neural-tube defects when mothers were infected early in pregnancy.

 Other infections which cause congenital malformations are:

  • Interstitial keratitis

  • Eighth nerve deafness

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

  • The rash appears on day 1

  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: Which of the following is the method of autopsy that involves the removal of individual organs one by one?
questions.solution:
In the Virchow technique, the individual organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here, the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: The following graph shows the response to 4 drugs at different concentrations. Arrange these drugs in the decreasing order of their efficacy.
questions.solution:
In the given image, drug B has maximum efficacy (maximum height) followed by drug A> drug D> drug C.

Efficacy is the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. If the response is more, the drug is said to be more efficacious. Since the response of drug B (height) is maximum in the given graph, it has the highest efficacy.

The potency of the drug is defined as the concentration of the drug which produces half of the maximal effect. The drug which produces half of the maximum effect in the least concentration is said to be more potent. More the curve is towards the left, more is the potency. Therefore, in the graph drug A has maximum potency followed by drug B> drug C> drug D.

Efficacy reflects the capacity of a drug to activate a receptor and generate a cellular response. With respect to the efficacy, a drug can be called as

  • Full agonist- The drug has very high efficacy.
  • Partial agonist- The drug has low efficacy
  • Antagonist- The drug binds to the receptor but has zero efficacy

questions.text: The activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is prolonged in the deficiency of all of the following coagulation factors except
questions.solution:
Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) measures the clotting time of plasma via the intrinsic pathway. Factor VII is a part of the extrinsic pathway. Hence, aPTT is not prolonged in factor VII deficiency. 

Causes of a prolonged aPTT:

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Liver disease
  • Massive transfusion with plasma-depleted red blood cells
  • Administration of heparin
  • Deficiency of a coagulation factor other than factor VII (since it is part of the extrinsic pathway), e.g. in hemophilia
  • aPTT is also moderately prolonged in patients taking oral anticoagulant drugs and in the presence of vitamin K deficiency

Prothrombin time evaluates the extrinsic pathway. It measures the clotting time of plasma in the presence of an optimal concentration of tissue extract (thromboplastin).

Causes of prolonged PT:

  • Administration of oral anticoagulant drugs (vitamin K antagonists)
  • Liver disease, particularly obstructive jaundice
  • Vitamin K deficiency
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Rarely, a previously undiagnosed factor VII, X, V or prothrombin deficiency

Isolated prolonged prothrombin time occurs due to the deficiency of clotting factor VII.

questions.text: Histopathological examination would reveal which of the following characteristic findings in serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary?
questions.solution:
Psammoma bodies are the histopathological finding of serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary.

They are calcified structures seen in areas of cellular degeneration. Their presence does not denote malignancy.

Psammoma bodies are seen in the following conditions:

  • Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Papillary serous carcinoma of the endometrium
  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary
  • Meningioma

The image below shows Psammoma body.

 

Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumours. These are gland-like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

Granulosa cell tumours arise from granulosa cells which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature and the mass is cystic and encapsulated. The image given below shows Call-Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumours.

 

A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. It originates from embryonal structures of the yolk sac by selective differentiation. It is most often seen in children and young women. It usually presents as abdominal distention and a palpable pelvic mass. 

Grossly, the yolk-sac tumor appears yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), and forms a solid mass. Most of the yolk sac tumors have Schiller-Duval bodies and they are pathognomonic. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image given below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumors.

 

Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. It is characterized by mucin-producing signet ring cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in Krukenberg tumor.

questions.text: The sites of cholesterol synthesis are:
questions.solution:
The sites of cholesterol synthesis are the cytosol and endoplasmic reticulum.

Cholesterol synthesis takes place in all nucleated cells. The important sites are the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestine.

Conversion of HMG CoA into mevalonate by the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis. It is a microsomal enzyme present in the endoplasmic reticulum.

Cholesterol is a 27-carbon compound containing 4 rings and a side chain. Cholesterol synthesis is an endergonic pathway (the reaction is carried out with the help of energy released from the hydrolysis of ATP). An imbalance in this pathway leads to increased circulating levels of cholesterol as seen in vascular diseases. 

All carbon atoms in cholesterol are provided by acetyl CoA and reducing equivalents are produced by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate (NADPH). Initially, two molecules of acetyl-CoA condense to form acetoacetyl-CoA catalyzed by cytosolic thiolase. This acetoacetyl-CoA enters the cholesterol synthesis pathway.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman admitted to the surgical ward had been diagnosed with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. Which of the following is not a suitable next step for this patient?
questions.solution:
Switching to warfarin is not a suitable next step for patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). 

Warfarin should not be administered in HIT until platelets return to their baseline level. If warfarin was administered, give vitamin K to restore the INR to normal. 

Patients with HIT, particularly those with associated thrombosis, have increased thrombin generation that can lead to consumption of protein C. If these patients are given warfarin without a concomitant parenteral anticoagulant to inhibit thrombin or thrombin generation, the further decrease in protein C levels induced by the vitamin K antagonist can trigger skin necrosis.

HIT is a life-threatening complication of exposure to heparin. It occurs more with unfractionated heparin than with low molecular weight (LMW) heparin. It is more common in surgical patients and more common in women than in men.

HIT results from an autoantibody directed against endogenous platelet factor 4 (PF4) in complex with heparin. These antibodies bind simultaneously to the heparin-PF4 complex and to platelet Fc receptors, activating the platelets and generating platelet microparticles. This can cause catastrophic arterial and venous thrombosis.

Features:

  • Thrombocytopenia: Platelet count of ≤100,000/μL or a decrease in platelet count of ≥50%
  • Platelet count falls 5–10 days after starting heparin.
  • Venous thrombosis more common than arterial thrombosis

Investigations:

  1. ELISA to detect antibodies against heparin-PF4 complexes (most sensitive)
  2. Platelet activation assays
  3. Serotonin release assay (most specific)

Treatment:

  1. Stop all heparin.
  2. Give an alternative anticoagulant, such as lepirudin, argatroban, bivalirudin, fondaparinux or rivaroxaban.
  3. Do not give platelet transfusions.

Other options: 

Option A - Heparin should be discontinued if the patient has HIT. 

Option B - Lepirudin can be administered as it is an alternative anticoagulant. 

Option D - Rivaroxaban can be given as it is an alternative anticoagulant.

questions.text:
What is the device shown in the image given below used for?

HDR - High dose rate
questions.solution:
The device shown in the image is a remote afterloader. Remote afterloading is related to brachytherapy.

Brachytherapy is a method of treatment in which sealed radioactive sources are used to deliver radiation at a short distance by interstitial, intracavitary, or surface application.

The following isotopes are used in brachytherapy:

  • Iodine-125 and Iridium-192 are used in low-dose rate (LDR) brachytherapy. 
  • Cobalt-60 is used for high-dose rate (HDR) brachytherapy.

Afterloading is the process of placing the radioactive material into the target region. This is either done manually by the oncologist or by using remote afterloading devices.

Remote afterloading devices enable us to eliminate direct contact with radioactive sources during administration. It protects healthcare professionals from radiation exposure by securing the radiation source in a shielded, safe manner.

questions.text:
A stain present on the clothes of a murder victim is being examined. Which of the following tests would help determine whether that particular stain is due to blood?
  1. Phenolphthalein test
  2. Takayama test
  3. Precipitin test
  4. Teichmann’s test
  5. Latte’s method
questions.solution:
The phenolphthalein test, Takayama test, and Teichmann’s test can be used to determine if a particular stain at a crime scene is due to blood.

Tests for determining if a stain is due to blood include the following:

Benzidine test - It is the best preliminary test for blood and is based on the peroxidase activity of blood, which changes the color of the reagent. A negative reaction rules out the presence of blood (high sensitivity). False positive reactions can occur with substances like pus, saliva, milk, rust, or bacteria.

Phenolphthalein or Kastle-Meyer test - This test is done by adding phenolphthalein reagent and hydrogen peroxide to the extracted stain sample. Pink or purple color indicates a positive test. This test is more specific for blood than the benzidine test.

Haemin crystal test or Teichmann’s test - It is done by adding glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride to a stain. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear.

Haemochromogen crystal test or Takayama test - The Takayama reagent (sodium hydroxide, pyridine, and glucose) is added to a suspected stain. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of haemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes.

Spectroscopic test - It is the most definitive test for detecting the presence of blood in both recent and old stains. It is based on the property of blood pigments to absorb rays from the spectrum, producing characteristic dark absorption bands. 

Other options:

Statement 3: The precipitin test does not determine if the stain is due to blood. Rather, it can detect whether a particular stain is of human origin or from a lower animal. The origin of skin, flesh, bone, blood, or even secretions, such as saliva, milk, and semen, is determined by this test.

Statement 5: Latte’s crust method is used on a known blood stain to determine common blood groups such as ABO, MNS, and Rh systems. 

Related Pearl: Tests to detect seminal and blood stains

Tests for seminal stains

  • Barberio's test
  • Florence test
  • Acid phosphatase test
  • Creatine phosphokinase test
  • Immunological test to detect Prostate Specific Antigen

Tests for blood stains  

  • Benzidine test
  • Phenophthalein (Kastle Meyer) test
  • Takayama hemochromogen crystal test
  • Teichmann’s hemin crystal test
  • Spectroscopic test

questions.text:
A patient is started on aliskiren for control of hypertension. Which of the following would most likely be found on further investigation?

PRC - Plasma renin concentration
PRA - Plasma renin activity
questions.solution:
Aliskiren is an antihypertensive medication which is a direct renin inhibitor and causes increased plasma renin concentration and decreased plasma renin activity.

Aliskiren binds to the catalytic site of renin and competitively blocks angiotensinogen, thus inhibiting conversion of angiotensinogen to angiotensin I. This leads to a feedback increase in plasma renin concentration, while the plasma renin activity decreases. Angiotensin I, angiotensin II and aldosterone levels fall in a dose-dependent manner.

Adverse events are mild such as dyspepsia, abdominal pain, loose motions, headache, dizziness, acute hypotension, hyperkalemia, cough, angioedema and rashes. Aliskiren is contraindicated during pregnancy and in combination with angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).

The renin angiotensin aldosterone system (RAAS) is a tightly regulated system that is activated when blood pressure or blood volume decreases. The RAAS is also involved in thirst regulation and sodium balance. It plays a role in the development of hypertension, heart failure, and kidney disease.

Renin is released from the kidneys which converts angiotensinogen (produced in the liver) to angiotensin I. This is converted by ACE to angiotensin II which is a potent vasoconstrictor, and also stimulates aldosterone release from the adrenal glands. These actions work together to increase blood pressure and fluid volume.

Other options:

Option A: Increased plasma renin concentration and activity is seen with the use of ACE inhibitors and ARBs.

questions.text: Which of the following would not be associated with leucorrhea?

choices.text: Increased vaginal discharge necessitating use of a vulval pad
Nonpurulent vaginal discharge with a pH of 6.5
Nonpruritic vaginal discharge causing undergarment staining
Non offensive vaginal discharge containing lactobacilli

questions.solution:
A nonpurulent vaginal discharge with a pH of 6.5 would not be associated with leucorrhea, as the pH is usually between 4 to 5.5.

Leucorrhea is defined as an excessive normal vaginal discharge. The term leucorrhea should fulfill the following criteria:

  • The excess secretion is evident from persistent vulval moistness or staining of the undergarments (brownish yellow on drying) or need to wear a vulval pad.
  • It is nonpurulent and non offensive.
  • It is nonirritant and never causes pruritus.
  • It has an acidic pH similar to that of normal vaginal pH of 4 to 5.5.

The physiologic basis involved in normal vaginal secretion is dependent on the endogenous estrogen level. With the rising estrogen level, there is abundant secretory activity of the endocervical glands and the superficial vaginal epithelium becomes rich in glycogen 

The normal secretion is expected to increase in conditions when the estrogen levels become high. Such conditions are :

  • During puberty - Increased levels of endogenous estrogen lead to marked overgrowth of the endo-cervical epithelium which may encroach onto the ectocervix producing congenital ectopy (erosion) → increased secretion.
  • During menstrual cycle
  • Around ovulation-Peak rise of estrogen → increase in secretory activity of the cervical glands.
  • Premenstrual pelvic congestion and increased mucus secretion from the hypertrophied endometrial glands. 
  • Pregnancy- There is hyperestrinism with increased vascularity. This leads to increased vaginal transudate and cervical gland secretion.
  • During sexual excitement, when there is an abundant secretion from Bartholin's glands.

Other Options:

Option A: Increased vaginal discharge necessitating use of a vulval pad is seen with leucorrhea.

Option C: Nonpruritic vaginal discharge causing undergarment staining is seen with leucorrhea.

Option D: Nonoffensive vaginal discharge containing lactobacilli is seen with leucorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following obstetric grips and their corresponding use is incorrectly paired?

choices.text: Pawlik's grip - To assess the presenting part
Lateral grip - To determine attitude of the baby
Pelvic grip - To determine degree of descent
Fundal grip - To determine lie/ fetal pole at the fundus

questions.solution:
Lateral grip assesses fetal orientation.

Leopold's maneuvers help assess the fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of the fetal head. They are as follows:

  1. Fundal grip (first Leopold):
    • Assesses the uterine fundus.
    • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
    • The breech is felt as a large, irregular mass. 
    • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

  2. Lateral grip (second Leopold): 
    • Assesses fetal orientation.
    • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
    • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
    • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
    • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
    • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

  3. Pawlik's grip/ 1st pelvic grip (third Leopold):
    • Assesses the presenting part.
    • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
    • If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.

  4. Deep pelvic grip/ 2nd pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):
    • Assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head.
    • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
    • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

Leopold Grip Importance
First Fundal To know which fetal pole occupies the uterine fundus.
Second Lateral/Umbilical To know the fetal back and extremities 
Third Pawlik 

To know the presenting fetal part in respect to the true pelvis
Fourth Pelvic

To determine the degree of descent.

If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by neck may be differentiated readily from the head

Which of the following factors increase the minimum alveolar concentration (MAC) of an anesthetic agent?
  1. Hyperthermia (>42C)
  2. Chronic alcohol abuse
  3. Pregnancy
  4. Cocaine use
  5. Older Age
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, hyperthermia (>42°C), chronic alcohol abuse, and cocaine use can increase the MAC (minimum alveolar concentration) of an anesthetic agent. 

MAC is the minimum concentration of an inhaled anesthetic at 1 atm of pressure that prevents skeletal muscle movement in response to a surgical incision in 50% of patients.

Pregnancy and old age can reduce the MAC.
