questions.text: A new drug has a volume of distribution of 12 L. It is excreted by first-order kinetics and has a half life of 10 hours. If given by continuous infusion, how long will it take for the drug to achieve 95% plasma steady state concentration?
questions.solution:
In first-order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. When given as a continuous infusion it reaches 95% steady state concentration in 4 half lives (10 x 4 = 40 hrs). 

The half-life (t1/2) is the time taken for the plasma concentration of the drug to be reduced by 50%. In first-order kinetics, the rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration. The rate of clearance remains constant in first-order kinetics.

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a 20-year history of diabetes mellitus on insulin is found to have poor glycemic control. Her fasting blood glucose at 8 am is found to be 250 mg/dL despite having taken insulin the night before. Somogyi phenomenon is clinically suspected when a patient shows which of the following findings?

choices.text: Early morning hyperglycemia with hypoglycemia at 3 am
Early morning hyperglycemia with hyperglycemia at 3 am
Early morning hyperglycemia with normoglycemia at 3 am
Early morning hypoglycemia with hyperglycemia at 3 am

questions.solution:
Somogyi phenomenon or 'rebound' effect refers to early morning hyperglycemia with hypoglycemia at 3 am.

This occurs due to an excessive administration of the night-time insulin dose which results in hypoglycemia in the middle of night at around 3 am. Following hypoglycemia, there is the release of counter-regulatory hormones such as epinephrine and glucagon, which have an insulin-antagonistic action. This results in early morning hyperglycemia.

Somogyi phenomenon can be detected on continuous blood glucose monitoring. It is treated by decreasing the night-time long-acting insulin dose.

Dawn phenomenon refers to early morning hyperglycemia and normal blood glucose l evels at 3 am (Option C). This occurs due to an early morning surge in plasma growth hormone and cortisol levels, which have an insulin-antagonistic action. In normal individuals, this is countered by increased early morning insulin secretion. However, in diabetic patients, insulin secretion is disrupted which results in the unopposed action of growth hormone. Hence, there will be resulting hyperglycemia.

Related Pearl: Dawn Phenomenon and Somogyi Phenomenon

 

Dawn phenomenon

Somogyi phenomenon

Features

Early morning hyperglycaemia

Early morning hyperglycaemia

 

Normal blood glucose levels at 3 am

Hypoglycaemia at 3 am

Mechanism

Early morning surge in growth hormone and cortisol which causes hyperglycemia

Excessive night basal insulin dose > hypoglycemia in middle of night > triggers the release of counterregulatory hormones which causes hyperglycemia.

Treatment

Increase nighttime long-acting insulin dose

Decrease night time long-acting insulin dose

questions.text: An elderly diabetic man is being evaluated for intracranial pathology on a contrast enhanced CT scan.  His lab reports showed a GFR of 50mg/dL. So the radiologist decided to use a suitable water-soluble contrast. Which of the following contrast agents would be preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient is an elderly diabetic with GFR<60 mg/dL. Iohexol would be preferred to reduce the risk of contrast nephropathy. 

Iohexol is a non-ionic, low-osmolar water-soluble contrast agent. These contrast agents produce fewer abnormalities in the renal blood flow, thus causing less endothelial damage.

Water-soluble iodinated contrast agents are classified based on the osmolarity:

  • Low-osmolar - iohexol
  • Iso-osmolar - a subtype of low-osmolar contrast agent. example - iodixanol
  • High-osmolar - gastrograffin

Contrast nephropathy (CIN) is defined as a rise in serum creatinine by 0.5 mg/dl within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. Some risk factors include:

  • Older age
  • Chronic kidney disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Congestive heart failure
  • ST-elevation myocardial infarction

Prevention of CIN: Adequate hydration with normal saline or administration of sodium bicarbonate before and after the procedure. 

Other options:

Option B: Gadolinium is a contrast agent used in MRI, whereas the patient in the given scenario is undergoing CT. 

Option C: Gastrograffin is a high-osmolar water-soluble contrast agent. 

Option D: Lipoidol is a water-insoluble agent used for sclerotherapy or hysterosalpingography.

questions.text: The image given shows a maneuver used during labor. Which of the following forceps can be used instead of this maneuver?
questions.solution:
The image shows Burns-Marshall technique used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech delivery. Piper’s forceps can be used to deliver the aftercoming head in breech instead of this maneuver.

Piper's forceps, identified by its distinct perineal curve, is used to assist the delivery of the after-coming head in breech.

It has a cephalic curve, reverse pelvic curve, and long parallel shanks that permit the baby’s body to rest against it during head delivery. It may be applied electively or when the Mauriceau maneuver cannot be accomplished easily.

The image below shows Pipers forceps:


Other options:

Option A: Kielland forceps is a long almost straight (very slight pelvic curve) obstetric forceps without any axis-traction device. It has got a sliding lock which facilitates correction of asynclitism of the head. One small knob on each blade is directed towards the occiput.

Option B: Tucker Mclane forceps: Suitable for fetal head with little molding and in rotational delivery.

Option D: Wrigley's forceps is an outlet forceps. It is used to provide traction force and can also be used in cesarean sections. The instrument is short which is due to a reduction in the length of the shanks and handles. It has a marked cephalic curve with a slight pelvic curve.

Related Pearl: Obstetrics forceps

Commonly used forceps: 

1) Simpson forceps

  • The most commonly used types of forceps in outlet delivery.
  • Has elongated cephalic curve.
  • These are used when there is substantial molding of the fetal head.

2) Elliot forceps

  • Has an adjustable pin for regulating the lateral pressure on the handles.
  • They are used most often when there is minimal molding.
  • More suitable for outlet delivery.

3) Kielland forceps

  • Has small pelvic curve and a sliding lock.
  • Suitable for head with little molding.
  • The most common forceps used for rotational delivery.
  • Helps correct asynclitism.

4) Piper forceps

  • Distinct perineal curve.
  • Allows for application to the after-coming head in breech delivery.

5) Tucker-McLane forceps

  • Suitable for fetal head with little molding.
  • Used in rotational delivery.

6) Barton forceps and traction handle

  • Used in rotational delivery.
  • Most importantly used for delivery of occipitotransverse positions in a platypelloid pelvis.
  • It is an obsolete procedure.

Related Pearl: Maneuvers for breech delivery

Pinard’s manoeuvre 

It is used for the delivery of extended legs in case of breech delivery.

Technique:

  • Flex and abduct the popliteal fossa
  • Catch hold of the ankle
  • Pull down along with abduction

 

Lovset’s manoeuvre

It is used for the delivery of extended arms in case of a breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Hold the sacrum with the thumb, and the hips and pelvis with other fingers.
  • Turn the infant 90 degrees to bring the shoulder under pubic symphysis and deliver the anterior shoulder.
  • Then counter-rotate 180 degrees to engage and deliver the posterior shoulder. 

 

Modified Prague’s manoeuvre

It is used in breech presentations to deliver the aftercoming head when the back of the fetus fails to rotate to the symphysis.

Technique:

  • Grasp the shoulders of the baby from below with two fingers of one hand.
  • Draw the feet up and over the maternal abdomen with the other hand.

 

Burns-Marshall method

It is used for delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation.

Technique:

  • Allow the baby to hang by its own weight.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, grasp the baby by the ankles with a finger in between the two.
  • Swing the baby in an arc in an upward and forward direction.

 

Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique

It is another method that can be used in the delivery of aftercoming head in case of breech presentation. It is also called malar flexion and shoulder traction.

Technique:

  • Place the baby on the supinated left arm with limbs hanging on either side.
  • Place the index and middle fingers of the left hand on either side over the malar bones.
  • Place the ring and the little finger of the pronated right hand on the child’s right shoulder, index finger on the left shoulder and middle finger over the suboccipital region.
  • Traction is given in the downward and backward direction till the nape of the neck is visible.
  • Thereafter, the baby is carried in an upward and forward direction towards the mother’s abdomen.

 

Mnemonic:

  • Extend the arm to express Love(Lovset's)
  • Put the fingers in popliteal fossa for Pinard's(P for P)

questions.text: A couple is unable to conceive after a year of unprotected intercourse. The husband’s semen analysis is normal. The wife has a history of dysmenorrhea, irregular menstrual cycles, and chronic abdominal pain. Identify the following investigation done for her:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of infertility due to endometriosis and the investigation shown in the image is laparoscopic chromopertubation. 

Laparoscopy is the gold standard method for the evaluation of tubal factors of infertility. Chromotubation may be performed, in which a dilute dye is injected through a Leech-Wilkinson cannula placed against the cervix or through a balloon catheter positioned within the uterine cavity. Tubal spill is evaluated through the laparoscope. 

Indigo carmine dye, if available, is preferable to methylene blue, as methylene blue rarely may induce acute methemoglobinemia, particularly in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. It is commonly done in the proliferative phase.

Drawbacks: Laparoscopy is more invasive than hysterosalpingography (HSG). It cannot detect abnormality in the uterine cavity or tubal lumen.

Other options:

Option A: Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is an imaging modality in which radiopaque contrast is injected through the cervical canal to assess the endometrial cavity, the fallopian tubes, and the endocervical canal.

HSG can be used for the following:

  • To assess tubal patency in infertility 
  • To detect uterine anomalies, synechiae, and polyps
  • To detect incompetence of the cervical os. 

Given below is an HSG image:

 

Option B: Falloposcopy is the study of the entire length of tubal lumen with the help of a fine and flexible fiberoptic device. It is performed through the uterine cavity, using a hysteroscope. It helps direct visualization of tubal ostia, mucosal pattern, intratubal polyps, or debris.

Option D: Salpingoscopy is the study of the tubal lumen by introducing a rigid endoscope through the fimbrial end of the tube. It is performed through the operating channel of a laparoscope.

questions.text: A patient presents with episodes of vertigo and aural fullness. His pure-tone audiogram is shown below. Which of the following procedures is not indicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the audiogram showing an upsloping/ascending curve suggest a diagnosis of Ménière's disease. Epley's maneuver is a therapeutic maneuver used in benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV) and not Ménière's disease.

Patients with Ménière's disease typically present with episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss and tinnitus. Aural fullness is a warning symptom preceding an attack of vertigo in Ménière’s disease. The given audiogram shows an upsloping/ascending curve suggesting that the lower frequencies are affected first and is seen in early stages of Ménière's disease.

Individuals with Meniere disease have significantly smaller and shorter endolymph drainage systems. The underlying pathophysiology of hydrops is controversial, but the prevalent theory is inadequate absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac. 

Surgery is indicated when the disease is unresponsive or refractory to medical management (including intratympanic gentamicin). Surgery can be:

  • Conservative (when hearing is preserved):
    • Decompression of endolymphatic sac
    • Fick’s Sacculotomy (Option B)
    • Endolymphatic shunt (Option C)
    • Vestibular neurectomy
    • Ultrasonic destruction of the vestibule
  • Destructive: Labyrinthectomy (when hearing is irreversibly impaired)
  • Meniett’s device- provides intermittent positive pressure to the inner ear which improves hearing and reduces vertigo in these patients (Option D)

questions.text: In an Rh-negative pregnancy, which of the following parameters of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) doppler is used to detect fetal anaemia?

choices.text: An increase in peak systolic velocity
A decrease in mean systolic velocity

questions.solution:
Increased peak systolic velocity in fetal MCA doppler is used to detect fetal anemia in RH negative pregnancy.

In many centers, serial measurement of the peak systolic velocity of the fetal middle cerebral artery has replaced amniocentesis for the detection of fetal anemia. The anemic fetus shunts blood preferentially to the brain to maintain adequate oxygenation. The velocity also increases because of increased cardiac output and decreased blood viscosity.

If the MCA peak systolic velocity exceeds 1.5 MoM, further evaluation by fetal blood sampling is necessary to assess the need for fetal transfusion.

questions.text: A  young patient presents with complaints of cramping abdominal pain and painless bright red bleeding in stools for the past 1 week. External and digital rectal examinations are normal. What is the next best step in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
The first step in the workup of suspected lower GI bleed is to rule out the anorectal source of the bleed by digital rectal examination (DRE) and proctoscopy. Proctoscopy is a procedure used to inspect the anus, anorectal junction, and lower rectum (up to 10 cm). Biopsy of the suspicious areas can be taken if needed.

Examination of the rectum:

- Visual inspection of the perineum
- Digital examination
- Proctoscopy
- Sigmoidoscopy – rigid and/or flexible

If the anorectal cause of bleeding is ruled out, it is important to eliminate an upper GI source through nasogastric (NG) aspiration or esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD). An NG aspirate that contains bile and no blood effectively rules out upper tract bleeding in most patients.

Colonoscopy can be performed next when the anorectal or upper GI cause of bleeding is ruled out or if the extent of the hemorrhoid disease is incongruent with the patient’s symptoms, or if the patient has risk factors for colon cancer, such as a family history.

questions.text: The image given below shows various sites of microorganisms on which antibiotics act. Identify the antibiotic that acts on the marked site.
questions.solution:
Moxifloxacin is a fluoroquinolone that acts by inhibiting DNA gyrase.

The fluoroquinolones act by inhibiting the enzyme bacterial DNA gyrase which primarily targets the gram-negative bacteria. It nicks the double-stranded DNA, introduces negative supercoils, and then reseals the nicked ends. Enzyme topoisomerase is the major target of fluoroquinolones for gram-positive bacteria.

Moxifloxacin is also used as part of multiple-drug regimens for the treatment of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis, atypical mycobacterial infections, and Mycobacterium avium complex infections in AIDS. Moxifloxacin does not accumulate in the urine, hence it is not approved for the treatment of urinary tract infections

Among the quinolones, moxifloxacin is found to carry the highest risk for QT interval prolongation and torsades de pointes arrhythmias. Gemifloxacin, levofloxacin, and ofloxacin appear to have a lower risk. Ciprofloxacin has the lowest risk.

Other options:

Option A: Co-trimoxazole is a combination of trimethoprim with sulfamethoxazole in the ratio of 1:5. Sulfamethoxazole inhibits dihydropteroate synthase (1) that converts para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) to dihydrofolate. Trimethoprim is a selective inhibitor of microbial dihydrofolate reductase (2). Both these enzymes are essential for the synthesis of folic acid in a bacterial cell. Inhibition of folic acid synthesis will cause disruption of basic metabolic functions in the microbe leading to its death.

Option C: Vancomycin is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. It binds terminal dipep­tide D­-Ala­-D­-Ala sequence of peptidoglycan units and prevents its release from the bactoprenol lipid carrier. Thus the assembly of the cell membrane and their cross-linking to form the cell wall cannot take place.

Option D: Linezolid is a protein synthesis inhibitor that acts on the 50s subunit.

  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman previously diagnosed with multiple sclerosis now presents with persistent hiccups. She soon develops paraplegia and painful loss of vision in both eyes. Anti-AQP-4 antibodies are positive. Which of the following biological agents has been approved for the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with persistent hiccups followed by acute-onset paraplegia and acute painful loss of vision, along with Anti-AQP-4 positivity points to the diagnosis of neuromyelitis optica (NMO), also known as Devic’s disease. Eculizumab has been FDA-approved for the treatment of neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

NMO is an aggressive inflammatory demyelinating disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis and myelitis. Attacks of optic neuritis can be bilateral or unilateral and myelitis can be severe and involve three or more contiguous vertebral segments.

Acute attacks of NMO are treated with high-dose glucocorticoids. Plasma exchange can be used in acute attacks that do not respond to glucocorticoids. Drugs used for prophylaxis against relapses include mycophenolate mofetil, rituximab, glucocorticoids, and azathioprine. 

Three monoclonal antibodies approved for attack prevention in neuromyelitis optica:

  1. Eculizumab (terminal complement inhibitor)
  2. Inebilizumab (B-cell depletor)
  3. Satralizumab (IL-6 receptor blocker).

Other options:

Option A: Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin. Natalizumab reduces the attack rate of multiple sclerosis thus improving the severity of the disease. It is recommended only for JC antibody-negative patients, due to the risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML).

Option B: Ocrelizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the CD20 molecule located on the surface of mature B cells. It is used to treat patients with relapsing and primary progressive multiple sclerosis. It is associated with an increased risk of malignancies like breast cancers and infusion reactions. 

Option D: Tocilizumab is an anti-IL-6 monoclonal antibody used in the treatment of giant cell arteritis, rheumatoid arthritis, cytokine release syndrome, COVID-19 infection, and systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: Abatacept binds to_____ and blocks the costimulation of T-cells.
questions.solution:
Abatacept binds to CD80/86 and blocks the costimulation of T-cells.

Abatacept is a fusion protein consisting of the binding segment from CTLA4, which is similar to CD28, and the Fc region of human IgG1. By attaching to CD80/86, CTLA4-Ig prevents the activation of T cells by competitively inhibiting CD28. This mechanism has proven to be successful in treating rheumatoid arthritis in patients who do not respond well to other medications.

Other options:

Option A: Alemtuzumab binds to CD 52 proteins, which can be given for the treatment of B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (B-CLL).

Option B: Muromonab is a murine monoclonal antibody that acts on CD3 glycoprotein expressed on helper T-cells and blocks antigen recognition. It is used for acute transplant rejection reactions, especially in steroid-resistant cases. 

Option D: Daclizumab is an IL2R antagonist which binds to CD25. It is used as an immunosuppressant in adults with the relapsing type of multiple sclerosis. It is contraindicated in those with liver disease as it causes severe liver injury, including autoimmune hepatitis and liver failure. Another drug that prevents IL-2R-mediated T-cell activation is basiliximab.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency after a road traffic accident and developed breathing difficulty. What are the two regions assessed in eFAST to arrive at the diagnosis that are not used in FAST?

FAST - Focussed Assessment with Sonography in Trauma; eFAST - extended FAST

choices.text: Right upper quadrant and right lower quadrant
Right thorax and right upper quadrant
Left upper quadrant and Left thoracic region

questions.solution:
Right and left thoracic views are the two additional regions that are included in eFAST.

FAST stands for Focussed Assessment with Sonography in Trauma. It is a rapid, non-invasive bedside test for detecting free fluid using sonography to assess patients for potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It can be performed within 2-4 minutes.

Regions assessed by FAST are:

  • Subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
  • Longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
  • Longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury
  • Transverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

eFAST stands for extended FAST and includes all the above four regions along with anterior pleural views of the right and left thoracic regions to assess for pneumothorax and hemothorax. It uses a 2 MHz to 5 MHz curvilinear (or abdominal) probe.

questions.text: A man suffered from a crush injury and presented with severe pain, soft tissue crepitus, discoloration, and bullae in the affected area. The discharge from the affected site was positive for Nagler's reaction. What type of serological test is Nagler's reaction?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of gas gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Nagler’s reaction done here is an example of neutralization test.

The α-toxin of C. perfringens has lecithinase activity. When C. perfringens is grown on a media containing egg yolk with the α-antitoxin spread on one half of the plate, colonies on the other half without the antitoxin will be surrounded by a zone of opacity. There will be no opacity around the colonies on the half of the plate with the antitoxin due to the specific neutralization of α-toxin. This is known as Nagler's reaction.


Gas gangrene is caused most often by Clostridium perfringens species. Microscopically it is a gram-positive bacteria without spores. It is an anaerobe. Sample collection and transport are to be done in Robertson's cooked meat medium. It grows well on Blood agar showing target hemolysis. The reverse CAMP test is positive with a hemolysis arrow pointing toward the Clostridial streak. Nagler's test is a quick test to show the presence of Clostridium.

questions.text:
Arrange the following structures in order of aqueous flow :
  1. Episcleral vein
  2. Trabecular meshwork
  3. Aqueous vein
  4. Schlemm’s canal
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of structures through which aqueous flows is: Trabecular meshwork (2) → Schlemm’s canal (4) → Aqueous veins (3) → Episcleral veins (1).

Circulation of aqueous humor is necessary both for metabolic purposes and to regulate intraocular pressure. There are two pathways of aqueous outflow :

  • Trabecular/conventional outflow – Main outlet draining 90% of aqueous via trabeculae.
    • Greater part of the fluid is formed in the ciliary region, it flows from the posterior chamber through the pupil into the anterior chamber and escapes through the drainage channels at the angle, i.e. Trabecular meshwork → Schlemm’s canal→ Aqueous veins→Episcleral veins→ Superior ophthalmic vein→Cavernous sinus.
  • Uveoscleral outflow – Drains around 10% of aqueous via ciliary body into the suprachoroidal space, and is drained by the venous circulation in the ciliary body, choroid and sclera.

The rate of formation of aqueous humor is 2-3 μL/min. Formation of aqueous humor involves the following:

  • Ultrafiltration
  • Secretion- Na/K ATPase of non-pigmented epithelium of the ciliary process
  • Diffusion

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide)
  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

Hyperosmotic agents - (e.g., glycerol, mannitol, urea)

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge,  sinusitis, and chronic suppurative otitis media is scheduled for adenoidectomy. Which of the following is a contraindication for this procedure?
questions.solution:
The presence of a cleft palate is a contraindication for adenoidectomy. 

Performing an adenoidectomy in a patient with a cleft palate can lead to velopharyngeal insufficiency, a disorder of the velopharyngeal valve. The function of this valve is to separate the oral and nasal cavities during actions like speaking, swallowing, vomiting, blowing, and sucking. Velopharyngeal insufficiency leads to reduced speech intelligence as well as social and functional impairment. Patients have hypernasal speech, compensatory facial grimacing, and misarticulation.  

Indications for adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Symptomatic adenoid hypertrophy
  2. Recurrent sinusitis (Option A)
  3. Chronic otitis media (Option B) 
  4. Chronic suppurative otitis media and recurrent ear discharge
  5. Dental malocclusion (Option D) occurring due to a low-positioned tongue, and separated lips. 

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include: 

  1. Cleft palate or submucous palate
  2. Hemorrhagic diathesis
  3. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract

questions.text: A patient presents with hypocalcemia, cleft palate, and increased susceptibility to infections. Her G-banding karyotype is reported as 46, XX. Which of the following genetic mechanisms is responsible for the patient's abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient with hypocalcemia, cleft palate, and immunodeficiency is most likely has DiGeorge Syndrome. DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11).

The chromosomal deletion leads to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches (Thymus and parathyroid glands).  

Karyotyping is usually normal and definitive diagnosis requires fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) with a fluorescent DNA probe to detect the deleted DNA segment. Treatment is supportive.

Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. In the G-banding technique of karyotyping, Giemsa staining is performed after partial denaturation of chromatin. It is the most common technique used in cytogenetics. 

Other options:

Option B: Nondisjunction is the mechanism by which errors in chromosome numbers occur due to failure of paired chromosomes to separate appropriately during cell division. Examples include Down’s syndrome (Trisomy 21), Edward Syndrome (Trisomy 18) and Patau Syndrome (Trisomy 13).

Option C: Robertsonian translocation occurs when two (usually acrocentric) chromosomes break down at the centromere and recombine such that two long arms and two short arms are joined. Down’s syndrome may occur due to Robertsonian translocation.

Option D: Uniparental disomy is the inheritance of a pair of non-identical chromosomes from a single parent. Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome are examples of uniparental disomy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old patient presents with loss of pain and temperature sensation in both upper limbs. An MRI is done which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario and the image showing a hyperintense area in the spinal cord is syringomyelia. 

Syringomyelia is a progressive disease of the spinal cord in which there is an enlarging cavity in the cord. Syrinx cavities are acquired cavities of the cord in necrosed areas secondary to trauma, myelitis, and spinal cord tumors. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with central cord symptoms. 

Most patients present with regional loss of pain and temperature of the upper limbs. Touch and vibration senses are intact. The loss of sensation has a 'cape distribution' as it affects the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. Eventually, expansion of the cavity may lead to compression of the long tracts. This results in spasticity, weakness, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome. 

There is no satisfactory treatment for this condition. 

Other options: 

Option A: Spinal epidural abscess presents with fever, pain, and progressive weakness. The pain may be radicular. There would be elevated white cell count and inflammatory markers. The image below shows a spinal epidural abscess compressing the spinal cord. 

 

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord. Patients present with paresthesias in the hands and feet and progressive ataxic weakness. They would be areflexic due to peripheral neuropathy. The image below shows a hyperintensity in the posterior part of the spinal cord due to the involvement of the posterior columns. 

 

Option D: Spinal cord infarction occurs due to infarction of one of the three arteries (anterior spinal artery and two posterior spinal arteries.) Infarction of the anterior spinal artery leads to quadriplegia or paraplegia, loss of pain and temperature, and sparing of vibration and position sense. Posterior spinal artery involvement leads to a loss of posterior column functions.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficient in this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency. 
Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, and night blindness. Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities, perianal, perigenital, and perioral regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options:

Option A- Niacin deficiency leads to a disease called pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. The lesion in the neck is characteristic of Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in pellagra. The Casal collar or Casal necklace is a clinical sign in which there is an erythematous pigmented skin rash in the distribution of a broad collar (dermatomes C3 and C4).

 

Option C- Deficiency of riboflavin can present as anemia, corneal vascularization, mucocutaneous lesions, and personality changes. Milk and other dairy products are important dietary sources.

Option D- Copper deficiency leads to anemia, growth retardation, defective keratinization and pigmentation of hair, hypothermia, degenerative changes in aortic elastin, osteopenia and mental retardation.

questions.text:
Match the tumors in column A with their microscopic appearances in column B.
Column A  Column B
1. Yolk sac tumor A. Signet ring cells
2. Ovarian serous tumor B. Call-Exner bodies 
3. Krukenberg tumor C. Schiller-Duval bodies
4. Granulosa cell tumor  D. Psammoma bodies
questions.solution:
The correctly matched set of the tumors with their corresponding microscopic appearance is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B. 

Column A Column B
1. Yolk sac tumor C. Schiller Duval bodies
2. Ovarian serous tumor D. Psammoma bodies
3. Krukenberg tumor A. Signet ring cells
4. Granulosa cell tumor B. Call-Exner bodies

 

Schiller Duval bodies are seen in yolk sac tumors. A yolk sac tumor/endodermal sinus tumor is an aggressive malignant germ cell tumor of the ovaries. Schiller-Duval bodies are pathognomonic for yolk sac tumors. These are glomerulus-like structures consisting of a central vessel surrounded by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

The image below shows Schiller-Duval bodies seen in yolk sac tumor.

 

Psammoma bodies are concentrically calcified bodies seen in ovarian serous tumors and a few other cancers like papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. Ovarian serous tumors are malignant tumors and account for approximately 40% of all ovarian cancers.

The image below shows Psammoma bodies in ovarian serous tumors.

 

Signet-ring cells are seen in the Krukenberg tumor. Krukenberg tumor is the carcinoma of the stomach that metastasize to the ovary. Signet ring cells are mucin-producing cells. The appearance of a signet ring often originates from the gastric mucosa.

The image below shows signet-ring cells in the Kruckenberg tumor.

 

Call-Exner bodies are seen in granulosa cell tumors. Granulosa cell tumors arise from granulosa cells, which form part of the developing ovarian follicle. They are unilateral in nature, and the mass is cystic and encapsulated.  These are gland-like small structures with acidophilic material and immature follicles.

The image given below shows Call-Exner bodies seen in granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl was kidnapped and sexually assaulted by her neighbour in an abandoned parking lot. According to the latest Supreme Court guidelines, what is the BNS section and the minimum punishment applicable for the accused?
questions.solution:
Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita 2023  defines the punishment for rape of a girl less than 12 years under section 65(2). The punishment includes rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person’s natural life, and with fine or with death.

Other options:

Option A: Section 66 includes punishment for causing death or resulting in a persistent vegetative state of a rape victim. The punishment is rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to imprisonment for life, which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person’s natural life, or with death.

Option B: Section 67 deals with the punishment for sexual intercourse by a husband upon his wife during separation without the woman's consent. The punishment is imprisonment of either description for a term which shall not be less than two years but which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to a fine.

Option D: Section 70 describes the punishment for gang rape. The convicts of the act shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment for a term which shall not be less than twenty years, but which may extend to life which shall mean imprisonment for the remainder of that person’s natural life, and with a fine.

questions.text: Which of the following shuttle is required for the transport of acetyl CoA from mitochondria to cytoplasm?
questions.solution:
Citrate shuttle is required for the transport of acetyl CoA from the mitochondria to the cytoplasm.

Acetyl CoA is formed inside the mitochondria from pyruvate. The inner membrane is not freely permeable to acetyl CoA. Hence the acetyl CoA units are delivered to the cytoplasm as citrate. Citrate is transported from mitochondria by a tricarboxylic acid transporter. In the cytoplasm, citrate is cleaved to oxaloacetate and acetyl CoA by the enzyme ATP citrate lyase. The oxaloacetate returns to the mitochondria as malate or pyruvate.

Fates of acetyl CoA

In the mitochondria

  • TCA cycle
  • Activation of gluconeogeneisis
  • Ketone body synthesis

In the cytoplasm

  • Cholesterol synthesis
  • Fatty acid synthesis

questions.text:
Match the following drug interactions with their respective examples.
Drug interaction Example
1. Synergistic A. Cortisol + Epinephrine
2. Additive B. Levodopa + Carbidopa
3. Permissive C. Trimethoprim + Sulfamethoxazole
4. Potentiation D. Aspirin + Paracetamol
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Drug interaction Example
1. Synergistic C. Trimethoprim + Sulfamethoxazole
2. Additive D. Aspirin + Paracetamol
3. Permissive A. Cortisol + Epinephrine 
4. Potentiation B. Levodopa + Carbidopa

 

When two or more drugs are given together, they can interact with each other in different ways:

Additive effect: The combined effect of two drugs equals the sum of the effects of individual drugs given alone. Effect of A and B together = effect of A + effect of B.
Examples - aspirin + paracetamol (as analgesics), amlodipine + atenolol (as antihypertensive), metformin + glibenclamide (as antidiabetics)

Synergistic effect: The combined effect of two drugs exceeds the sum of the effects of individual drugs given alone. Effect of A and B together > effect of A + effect of B.
Examples - sulfamethoxazole + trimethoprim, aspirin + clopidogrel

Potentiation: One component alone does not produce any effect, but enhances the effect of the other component. 
Example - levodopa + carbidopa. Carbidopa itself doesn't have any activity at the dopamine receptor. It just functions to block the peripheral conversion of levodopa.

Permissive effect: The presence of one substance is required for the full effects of another substance.
Example - glucocorticoids are required for the full effects of catecholamines.

Antagonism: One drug abolishes or decreases the action of another drug or physiological substance. 
Example - naloxone acts as antagonist to morphine at the opioid receptors.

questions.text:
Which of the following increase the risk of developing cervical incompetence?
  1. In-utero exposure to DES
  2. Twin pregnancy
  3. History of MTP with Mifepristone
  4. Genital tract infections
  5. Bicornuate uterus
questions.solution:
In-utero exposure to DES, twin pregnancy, and bicornuate uterus increase the risk of cervical incompetence.

Offsprings born to pregnant mothers who were treated with diethylstilbestrol may develop cervical hypoplasia and malformation. They may also present with cervical incompetence during their 2nd trimester.

Cervical incompetence can be seen following MTP with surgical methods and not with medical methods.

The retentive power of the internal os may be compromised by anatomical abnormalities like bicornuate uterus and overdistended uterus due to twin gestations.

Risk factors for cervical incompetence:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Acquired -
    • Dilatation and currettage 
    • Induced abortion by dilatation and evacuation
    • Vaginal operative delivery through an undilated cervix
    • Amputation of cervix 
  • Multiple gestations
  • Prior preterm birth

questions.text: Following a group psychotherapy session, a patient with general anxiety disorder acknowledges that she doesn’t feel alone anymore about her condition. What is the phenomenon seen here?
questions.solution:
This scenario in which the patient expresses the awareness of not feeling alone about her condition following group psychotherapy is known as universalization.

In group psychotherapy, therapeutic sessions are conducted by one or two therapists along with a group of patients, usually with in-patients in a ward, or in self-help groups.

Some other therapeutic factors in group psychotherapy include:

  • Altruism: It refers to a phenomenon where a person puts another person's needs before their own needs and finds value in helping others.
  • Imitation (Option A): It refers to conscious emulation or modeling of one's behavior after that of another.
  • Cohesion (Option B): It refers to a sense that the group is working together toward a common goal.
  • Catharsis: It is defined as an expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed material that is accompanied by an emotional response that produces a state of relief in the patient.
  • Transference: Projection of feelings, thoughts, and wishes onto the therapist, who has come to represent an object from the patient's past.
  • Ventilation: It is also known as self-disclosure, where the patient expresses suppressed feelings, ideas, or events to other group members. They share personal secrets that ameliorate a sense of sin or guilt.
  • Identification: An unconscious defense mechanism where one incorporates another person or object's qualities into their ego system.

Other options: 

Abreaction (Option D) refers to a process by which a repressed memory or experience, that is particularly painful is brought back to the consciousness. During this process, the patient not only recalls the painful moment but also relives it, which is associated with an appropriate affective response.

questions.text: An infant presents with a history of passing foul-smelling and greasy stools. The peripheral smear shows acanthocytes and a small intestine biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is affected by the most likely mutation seen in the disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with steatorrhea, acanthocytosis on peripheral smear and histopathological slide showing lipid-laden enterocytes is most suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia. Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare autosomal recessive disease, caused due to the mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTTP). 

MTTP is necessary to transfer lipids to nascent chylomicrons in the small intestine, and to Very Low-Density Lipoprotein (VLDL)  in the liver. In abetalipoproteinemia, there is an absence of chylomicrons, VLDL, LDL (apoB containing lipoproteins), and deficient levels of plasma cholesterol and triglycerides.

 

It usually presents with fat malabsorption, diarrhea, and deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins, especially Vitamin E. Vitamin E deficiency can lead to spinocerebellar degeneration and acanthocytosis. Intestinal biopsy shows lipid-laden vacuolated epithelium due to triglyceride accumulation. Treatment with Vitamin E can slow the development of neurological sequelae.

Other Options:

Option A: Familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. Physical findings such as corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas are seen (vs findings in fat malabsorption).

Option C: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged yellow-orange tonsils are pathognomonic

Option D: Norum's disease is caused by a complete deficiency of the enzyme lecithin cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT). Clinical features are dense corneal opacity and renal failure

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with burns to his face, neck, both arms and sides of the chest. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the resuscitation of this patient?

choices.text: Intubate before features of laryngeal edema are present
Muir and Barclay formula is used for calculation of colloids
Urine output is maintained around 0.5 - 1 ml/kg/hour
Topical silver sulfadiazine penetrates burn eschar

questions.solution:
Topical mafenide acetate penetrates eschar whereas silver sulfadiazine does not.

It is often recommended to use an aggressive approach in the management of burns due to the potential risks they pose to patients, such as infection and dehydration. Prompt intubation should be done before the features of laryngeal edema, such as a change in voice, stridor, anxiety, and respiratory difficulty develop. A cricothyroidotomy might be needed if intubation fails (Option A).

Following this, venous access with two large-bore intravenous (IV) catheters and IV fluids is recommended. The fluid resuscitation requirement in a burn patient is calculated using the Parkland formula. Prophylactic administration of antibiotics is frequently employed, and it is recommended that patients receive tetanus prophylaxis (based on wound and immunization history).

Human albumin solution (HAS) is commonly used for colloid resuscitation. The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula (Option B). It is calculated as 0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion. 1 portion is given in each period; considering periods of 4/4/4, 6/6, and 12 hours respectively; a total of 6 portions in 36 hours.

Urine output is a commonly used parameter to monitor resuscitation and it should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body weight per hour (Option C).

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

questions.text: A cruise ship worker comes with pneumonia, diarrhea, and confusion. Culture on buffered charcoal yeast agar demonstrates the growth of coccobacillus. What is true about the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is caused by a gram-positive coccobacillus
Amoxicillin is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a case of Legionnaires disease caused by Legionella pneumophila. Legionnaire’s disease is associated with hyponatremia in patients. 

Legionella pneumophila is a fastidious, aerobic gram-negative coccobacillus (Option A). It can be grown on a buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements.

Infection is mostly spread by inhalation of the bacteria from aerosols produced by contaminated air conditioners, humidifiers, nebulizers, etc. Human to human transmission does not occur (Option C). It may present as a severe, rapidly progressive disease with high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. On chest x-ray, patchy, often multilobar consolidation is seen. Pleural effusion may also occur. Hyponatremia is a feature typical to this infection leading to confusion. It is usually severe in immunocompromised patients.

Diagnosis is by the identification of legionella antigens in urine by latex agglutination or Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA). Direct fluorescent antibody test and culture on BCYE media can be used. Treatment is by newer macrolides, ciprofloxacin or tetracycline. Aminoglycoside and beta lactam antibiotics are ineffective (Option D).

questions.text: The petechial hemorrhages seen over the facial skin in cases of death by hanging are called:
questions.solution:
Petechial hemorrhages over the facial skin in someone who died by hanging are referred to as Tardieu's spots.

Tardieu's spots or petechial hemorrhages are important external as well as internal autopsy findings in a victim of asphyxia. In cases of hanging, they are seen on the skin above the level of obstruction, i.e., over the face, behind the ears, and on the conjunctiva & sclera. They appear due to an acute increase in venous pressure, resulting in distension and rupture of thin-walled peripheral vessels and capillaries. 

Tardieu's spots are also seen internally as postmortem findings of asphyxia. They can occur on the undersurface of the scalp, brain, heart, lungs, and rarely on the parietal pleura & peritoneum.

Other options: 

Option A: Tache noir is a black-colored deposition of cell debris and mucous on the sclera that occurs within 3-4 hours of death. It occurs if the eyes remain open after death as the areas of the sclera exposed to the air dry out.

Option C: Paultauf's hemorrhages are small subpleural intrapulmonary hemorrhages seen as postmortem findings in cases of drowning.

Option D: Kevorkian sign is the segmentation of retinal blood columns which occurs immediately after death.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of seizures and intermittent loss of consciousness. The MRI image of the brain is shown. Which of the following drug regulatory schedules does the drug of choice for this condition belong to?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of seizures and the radiological findings of multilobulated cystic lesions in the subarachnoid space, typical parenchymal brain calcifications are suggestive of neurocysticercosis caused by T. solium (Cysticercosis cellulose). Albendazole is the drug of choice for neurocysticercosis. It belongs to schedule H according to the drug regulatory schedules.

Schedule H deals with prescription drugs. All the drugs listed under schedule H should be provided to the patient only with a prescription from a registered medical practitioner. 

All the drugs under the list must have the warning mentioned below, on their packaging listed prominently. 

"Schedule H drug. Warning: To be sold by retail on the prescription of a registered medical practitioner only" 

Schedule H1: To be sold on the production of a valid prescription, but the chemist will maintain a separate register where the identity of the patient, contact details of the prescribing doctor, and the name and dispensed quantity of the drug will be recorded. The dispensing quantity should be strictly according to the valid prescription. It is a recently introduced list with the objective of curtailing indiscriminate use of antimicrobials. 

Schedule X: To be sold with a valid prescription. Prescription in duplicate, separate license requirements, meticulous storage, and dispensing records must be maintained by the chemist. The drugs that have high abuse liability are included in schedule X.

questions.text:

G6PD- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in image 1 is an X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance, which is seen in G6PD deficiency.

Clues for diagnosis of the pattern of inheritance as X-linked recessive:

  • Males are affected, and females are carriers.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) is an enzyme of the pentose phosphate pathway. Its deficiency commonly manifests as neonatal jaundice and episodic acute hemolytic anemia. The common provoking agents are infections, some drugs like sulfa drugs/ quinine group, and fava beans.

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. The life cycle of the causative organism is given below. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
The given clinical history of high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures, along with the given replication cycle showing a virus with a linear double-stranded DNA genome, is suggestive of HSV Encephalitis caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. 

Steps of HSV replication:

The virus enters the cell by fusing with the plasma membrane, and viral DNA is released from the capsid at the nuclear pore. This is followed by the circularization of the genome and transcription of immediate-early genes.

α-Proteins are products of immediate-early genes. These proteins stimulate the transcription of early genes. β-proteins are products of early genes. These proteins function in DNA replication, to yield concatemeric DNA. Transcription of late genes gives rise to γ-proteins. These primarily consist of viral structural proteins and participate in virion assembly.

Viral DNA is cleaved from concatemers and then packaged into capsids. Enveloped viral particles collect in the endoplasmic reticulum and are then transported by a vesicular movement to the cell surface.

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is defined as inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by the herpes virus, and it typically presents as an acute febrile illness. Patients typically present with acute onset of fever, altered levels of consciousness, personality changes, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms, especially in the temporal lobe. Focal or generalized seizures occur in many patients with HSV encephalitis. Other most commonly encountered focal findings include aphasia, ataxia, upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron type lesions, and cranial nerve deficits.

HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. Other investigations that can help include CSF examination, CSF culture, serological studies, MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy. The T2-weighted MRI of the brain will show hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.

Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction, avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures, and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in treating HSV encephalitis.

Other options:

Option A: CSF culture in chick embryos - It is not a sensitive test used for the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. Negative CSF viral cultures have no value in ruling out HSV encephalitis. Although this method can be used to isolate HSV, it is not as sensitive or specific as PCR for viral DNA and it can take a longer time to obtain results. 

 Option B: Tzanck smear of CSF - A positive smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and ground glass appearance. It is a rapid, inexpensive, and fairly sensitive diagnostic test. The Tzanck smear is typically used to diagnose cutaneous herpes infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. It is not an appropriate diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis, as it does not provide definitive confirmation of the presence of HSV in the CSF.

Option D: Brain biopsy was used earlier to establish a diagnosis and begin early specific therapy, but now has been replaced by HSV DNA detection by CSF PCR.

questions.text: A bruise on an alleged victim of assault has a brown color. What is the likely age of the bruise and the pigment responsible for this particular color?
questions.solution:
A bruise develops a brown color in 4-5 days due to the pigment hemosiderin. 

A contusion or bruise is characterized by the infiltration of extravasated blood into the subepithelial and/or subcutaneous tissues. It results from the rupture of small blood vessels (veins, venules, and small arteries) due to blunt-force trauma.  

The extravasated blood attracts macrophages, which degrades the hemoglobin into various compounds like hemosiderin (brown), and hematoidin (green). At 7-10 days, it is converted to bilirubin (yellow). This gives rise to shifting color changes that begin at the wound's periphery and migrate toward the center as time goes on.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presented with an episode of sudden left-sided weakness and speech difficulty which resolved spontaneously within 24 hours. She has a history of recurrent miscarriages. ECG shows a sinus rhythm. Echocardiography revealed small vegetations on both sides of the mitral valve. What is the most probable diagnosis?

ECG - electrocardiogram
questions.solution:
The given presentation of neurological deficit resolving within 24 hours indicates a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The history of recurrent miscarriage points toward antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). These factors, along with the pattern of vegetations on the mitral valve, are strongly suggestive of Libman sack’s endocarditis.

Libman sack’s endocarditis is a type of non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis (NBTE). It is associated with autoimmune conditions such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and antiphospholipid antibody syndrome. The deposition of immune complexes leads to the formation of small (1 to 4 mm), sterile vegetations on heart valves. 

Vegetations can occur anywhere on the valve surface, on the chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium. Histologically, there is intense valvulitis and fibrinoid necrosis of the valve substance. Patients may present with symptoms of stroke or TIA's due to emboli from the vegetation.

Other options:

Option A: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart valves or the mural endocardium. The classic hallmarks of infective endocarditis are vegetations on heart valves. They are large, irregular masses on the valve cusps that can extend onto the chordae. Vegetations in infective endocarditis are friable, bulky, destructive lesions composed of fibrin, inflammatory cells, and microbes. 

Option C: Marantic endocarditis or Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterized by the deposition of small (1 to 5 mm), sterile, non-destructive thrombi along the line of closure of the leaflets of the cardiac valves. A hypercoagulable state is a predisposing factor for marantic endocarditis.

Option D: Rheumatic heart disease is the inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves that typically results in fibrinoid necrosis within the cusps or tendinous cords. Vegetations in RHD are small (1-2 mm) along the lines of closures of the valve leaflets. Irregular subendocardial thickenings are termed MacCallum plaques.

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the mitral valve will open at point:
questions.solution:
The mitral valve will open at point 1.

The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling

It begins at a ventricular volume of about 50 ml (end-systolic volume) and a diastolic pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg. As venous blood flows into the ventricle from the left atrium, the ventricular volume normally increases to about 120 ml (end-diastolic volume) and the diastolic pressure rises to about 5 to 7 mm Hg.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction

During isovolumic contraction, the volume of the ventricle does not change because all valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle increases to equal the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) as depicted by point 3.

Phase III: Period of ejection

During ejection, the systolic pressure rises even higher because of still more contraction of the ventricle. At the same time, the volume of the ventricle decreases because the aortic valve has now opened and blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

At the end of the period of ejection (point 4), the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. The line labeled IV traces this decrease in intraventricular pressure without any change in volume. Thus, the ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 ml of blood left in the ventricle and at an atrial pressure of 2 to 3 mm Hg.

The area subtended by this functional volume-pressure diagram (the shaded area, labeled EW) represents the net external work output of the ventricle during its contraction cycle.

questions.text: Angiography of the upper limb vessels in a patient shows a blockage in the brachial artery. All of the following vessels will have decreased flow, except:
questions.solution:
The anterior circumflex humeral artery is a branch of the axillary artery. Hence, it is unlikely to have a decreased flow due to blockage in the brachial artery. 

The brachial artery has 3 branches: 

  • Profunda brachii (accompanies radial nerve in the spiral groove) gives off nutrient artery to the humerus and an ascending branch which anastomoses with posterior circumflex humeral artery. It then divides into: 
    • Anterior descending artery (Radial collateral artery)  
    • Posterior descending artery (Middle collateral artery) 
  • Superior ulnar collateral artery (accompanies ulnar nerve)
  • Inferior ulnar collateral (supratrochlear) artery

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus for the first time. When should he visit an ophthalmologist?

choices.text: When symptoms of loss of vision begin to appear

questions.solution:
A patient with type II diabetes mellitus should visit the ophthalmologist at the time of diagnosis of diabetes. 

American Diabetes Association recommends: 

  • For type 2 diabetes mellitus - immediate comprehensive eye examination just after the diagnosis of diabetes 
  • For type 1 diabetes mellitus - comprehensive eye examination within 5 years of diabetes onset.
  • For women with preexisting type 1 or type 2 diabetes who become pregnant or are planning pregnancy - comprehensive eye examination before pregnancy or in the first trimester. Furthermore, these patients should be monitored every trimester and for 1 year postpartum.

After the initial examination in both type 1 and type 2 DM,

  • Annual examination of fundus is recommended therafter.
  • If there is no significant abnormality, the fundus should be examined every 2 years.
Severe vision loss is a microvascular complication of DM primarily due to progressive diabetic retinopathy, characterised by macular edema and new blood vessel formation. Diabetic retinopathy is classified into two stages:
  • Nonproliferative diabetic retinopathy : Usually presents in the 1st decade of hyperglycemia
  • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

The most effective therapy for diabetic retinopathy is prevention. Hence, intensive glycemic and blood pressure control and routine screening becomes essential. 

Related Pearl: Early treatment diabetic retinopathy study (ETDRS) classification

Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy (NPDR):

  • Mild NPDR
    • At least one microaneurysm must be present
  • Moderate NPDR
    • Microaneurysms/intraretinal hemorrhage in 2 or 3 quadrants
    • Early mild intraretinal microvascular abnormalities (IRMA)
    • Hard exudates and cotton-wool spots may or may not be present
  • Severe NPDR - any one of the following (4-2-1 rule)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes
  • Very severe NPDR - any two of the following (4-2-1)
    • 4 quadrants of microaneurysms and extensive intraretinal hemorrhages
    • 2 quadrants of venous beading
    • 1 quadrant of IRMA changes

Proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR):

  • PDR without high-risk characteristics (Early PDR)
    • Early neovascularization at the optic disc (NVD) or neovascularization elsewhere (NVE)
  • PDR with high-risk characteristics as follows
    • NVD < 1/4 disc area with vitreous hemorrhage (VH) or preretinal hemorrhage (PRH)
    • NVD 1/4 to 1/3 of disc area with or without VH or PRH
    • NVE > 1/2 disc area with VH or PRH

Clinically significant macular edema: 1 of the following 3 criteria are present on slit-lamp examination with 90D lens

  • Thickening of the retina at or within 500 micron of the center of the fovea.
  • Hard exudates at or within 500 micron of the centre of fovea associated with adjacent retinal thickening.
  • Development of a zone of retinal thickening one disc diameter or larger in size. At least a part of this should be within one disc diameter of the foveal center.

Advanced diabetic eye disease:

  • Persistent vitreous hemorrhage
  • Tractional retinal detachment
  • Neovascular glaucoma

questions.text: A patient undergoes a brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA). Which part of the test would be affected if there is damage to X?
questions.solution:
The structure marked as X in the given image is the inferior colliculus. Waves VI and VII in brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) are produced by the inferior colliculus.

Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA) is an objective and non-invasive method of hearing assessment that detects electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway. Stimuli are applied in the form of clicks or tone bursts which then elicit brainstem responses. In a normal person, 7 waves are produced in the first 10 ms. Each wave corresponds to an anatomic structure in the auditory pathway shown below. 

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

2. Whole blood products B.  +20°C to +24°C ; 5 days 
3. Single donor platelets C. +2°C to +6°C ; 42 days     
4. Packed red cells with SAGM D. -30°C or lower ; 1 year

 

SAGM - sodium, adenine, glucose, and mannitol
questions.solution:
The correct match for the above question is 1-D, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C.

Blood products Storage temperature ; shelf life
1. Cryoprecipitate                         D. -30°C or lower & 1 year
2. Whole blood products A. +2°C to +6°C & 35 days   
3. Single donor platelets B.  +20°C to +24°C & 5 days 
4. Packed red cells with SAGM C. +2°C to +6°C & 42 days     


Cryoprecipitate and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) are typically stored at a temperature of –30°C with a shelf life of 1 year. FFP is plasma separated from a unit of whole blood within 6 hours of collection and rapidly frozen. Once thawed, FFP has a shelf life of 24 hours at 1°C to 6°C.

Whole blood and packed red cells are consistently stored at +2°C to +6°C and transported within the temperature range of +2°C to +10 °C, with a shelf life of 35 days. If blood is not stored within this temperature range, its oxygen-carrying ability is significantly reduced. Packed red cells stored with SAGM (sodium, adenine, glucose, and mannitol) offer a shelf life of up to 42 days.

Platelet concentrate (PC), comprising either random donor or single donor platelets, is prepared by centrifuging whole blood within 6 hours of collection. It should be stored at a temperature of +20°C to +24°C and has a shelf life of approximately 5 days. Continuous gentle agitation is employed during storage to prevent platelet aggregation.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice and vomiting 1 week after birth. She has been refusing to breastfeed. Benedict's test was positive for urine, and her blood glucose level was low. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase is the deficient enzyme.
It can predispose to Escherichia coli  sepsis in neonates.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a newborn presenting with jaundice, vomiting, and refusing to breastfeed, along with reducing sugars in urine and hypoglycemia, is suggestive of impaired galactose metabolism. Breastfeeding is absolutely contraindicated in this condition.

Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency leads to classical galactosemia. It is an autosomal recessive disorder. Normally, newborns receive up to 40% of their intake as lactose (glucose + galactose). The deficiency of this enzyme leads to an inability to convert galactose-1-phosphate to uridine diphosphate galactose. This leads to the accumulation of galactose 1-phosphate and causes injury to the kidney, liver, and brain.

Clinical features:

  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the liver causes liver damage & leads to hepatomegaly, vomiting, and convulsions.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes the liver of inorganic phosphate leading to diminished ATP synthesis which affects gluconeogenesis resulting in hypoglycemia.
  • Accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in the nerves causes intellectual disability.
  • Accumulation of galactitol in the lens causes oil-drop cataract.
  • Patients with galactosemia are at an increased risk of developing Escherichia coli neonatal sepsis.

In uridyl transferase deficiency, the epimerase is present in adequate amounts, so that the galactosemic individual can still form UDPGal from glucose. This explains how it is possible for normal growth and development of affected children to occur despite the galactose-free diets.

Urinary reducing sugar (Benedict's test) and mucic acid test are positive. Direct enzyme assay using erythrocytes establishes the diagnosis.

Treatment is a galactose-free diet.

questions.text: A surgeon performs a Dunhill procedure on a patient with thyroid carcinoma. This procedure is best described as:
questions.solution:
Total lobectomy + isthmusectomy + subtotal lobectomy is an accurate description of the Dunhill procedure. 

 

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text:
A patient has been taking ramipril to control his hypertension for the past 10 years. On a recent follow-up visit, the doctor advised the addition of one more antihypertensive drug to his regimen. Which of the following drugs cannot be prescribed to this patient?

1. Spironolactone
2. Metolazone
3. Triamterene
4. Amiloride
5. Chlorthalidone
questions.solution:
Spironolactone, triamterene, and amiloride (1, 3, and 4) should not be prescribed to patients taking ramipril. Ramipril is an ACE inhibitor, and if it is taken along with potassium-sparing diuretics, it may lead to hyperkalemia. 

K+ sparing diuretics work by 2 mechanisms:

  • Blocking the ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) in the late distal tubules.
    • Triamterene
    • Amiloride
  • Aldosterone receptor antagonist
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
    • Canrenone

Thiazides and loop diuretics may lead to loss of potassium and cause hypokalemia. Metolazone and chlorthalidone are thiazides and can be given along with ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: A male patient is brought to the hospital with generalized weakness and a history of diarrhea. He also gave a history of removal of renal stones 6 months back. Investigations reveals metabolic acidosis and hypokalemia. Urine analysis shows a pH of 5.9, positive urine anion gap, hypocitraturia, and hypercalciuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is renal tubular acidosis - type 1 (RTA-1)  or distal renal tubular acidosis. The history of diarrhea and renal stones with metabolic acidosis, urine with pH>5.5, hypokalemia, positive urine anion gap, and hypercalciuria are characteristic findings of RTA-1.

RTA-1 occurs due to defective urinary acidification in the cortical collecting tubule due to ineffective H+ ion secretion by the alpha-intercalated cells. This leads to the formation of urine with pH > 5.5. The decreased H+ secretion also leads to inadequate HCO3- regeneration in the alpha-intercalated cells thus leading to metabolic acidosis. As H+ is usually exchanged with K+ from the lumen in the DCT, decreased H+ secretion is also associated with decreased K+ absorption, resulting in hypokalemia.

Acidosis reduces net proximal fluid reabsorption, which leads to volume contraction and activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). This results in decreased proximal tubular Na+ reabsorption and increased distal delivery of Na+ to the cortical collecting duct. These processes, along with increased aldosterone secretion, leading to increased K+ secretion by activation of ENaC (epithelial sodium channel) channels in the collecting duct thus causing hypokalemia.

Ammonium produced as a result of glutamine metabolism is secreted in the proximal tubule, which normally combines with H+ ions secreted in the alpha-intercalated cells of the distal tubule to form NH4+ ions. Since this process is impaired in RTA-1, the urine anion gap (UAG) is positive due to low urine NH4+ concentration. RTA-1 is associated with hypercalciuria and with persistent alkaline urine it is a risk factor for developing calcium phosphate stones. 

Other options:

Option A- Renal tubular acidosis - type 2 or proximal RTA occurs due to generalized proximal tubule dysfunction. Defective HCO3- resorption is the primary dysfunctional mechanism causing metabolic acidosis and is also associated with glycosuria, aminoaciduria, and phosphaturia.

In the initial stages of the disease or during HCO3- replacement the urine remains alkaline, but as HCO3- losses continue, the urine turns acidic with pH <5.5. There is no defect in the urine concentrating mechanism at the cortical collecting tubule, thus urine NH4+ concentration is normal and UAG is negative. There is no associated hypercalciuria.

Option C- Renal tubular acidosis - type 4 also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism occurs due to end-organ resistance to aldosterone and is characterized by hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and a positive UAG.

Option D- Alport syndrome is caused by mutations affecting type IV collagen that result in hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure, sensorineural deafness, and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.
