questions.text: What is the characteristic feature of the scales seen in actinic keratosis?

choices.text: Scales become more prominent on scratching them
Scales are centrally detached and peripherally attached
Plugs are seen on the undersurface on removing the scale
Sandpaper-like texture is felt on palpation of the scales

questions.solution:
A gritty sandpaper-like texture is felt on palpating the yellow/brown, firmly adherent, dry, rough scales in actinic keratosis.            

Actinic keratoses are hyperkeratotic lesions occurring on chronically light‐exposed adult skin that carry a low risk of progression to invasive squamous cell carcinoma. It is associated with mutation of the TP53 gene.  Human papillomavirus (HPV) is present in significant numbers in actinic keratosis. 

It commonly presents on light‐exposed areas such as the face, scalp, and dorsum of the hands. Lesions are usually multiple and comprise either macules or papules with a rough scaly surface resulting from disorganized keratinization and a variable degree of inflammation. 

In most individuals, the number of lesions can be better understood by skin palpation, which is a sensitive way of detecting the characteristic roughness associated with smaller lesions. 

The image-below shows the characteristic rash of actinic keratosis:

 

Option A: Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign, scratch sign, stroke of the nail) is an important diagnostic clue for pityriasis versicolor when the scales are not visible. Here the barely perceptible scales are made to stand out by scratching the lesion with fingernails.

Option B: Centrally detached and peripheral attached scales are seen in pityriasis rosea, known as the collarette scales.

 

Option C: In cutaneous lupus erythematosus or discoid lupus erythematosus, when the scale is removed its undersurface shows horny plugs that have occupied dilated pilosebaceous canals. This is called the ‘carpet tack sign or tin- tack sign, or cat's tongue sign. There is hyperkeratosis and plugging of the follicular ostia with keratotic material.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Squamous Cell Carcinoma

Risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma

  • UV exposure
  • Male sex- due to more sun exposure
  • Environmental factors-
    1. Psoralen and UVA (PUVA)
    2. Physical agents such as ionizing radiation
    3. Chemical agents such as arsenics
  • HPV-16 & 18
  • Immunosuppression 
  • Smoking
  • Chronic nonhealing wounds, burn scars, and chronic dermatosis
  • Hereditary conditions such as xeroderma pigmentosum, epidermolysis bullosa, and oculo-cutaneous albinism

questions.text: An epileptic patient was being managed on phenytoin. Now valproate has been added to his management regimen. What will be the most likely effect seen on the pharmacokinetics of phenytoin due to the addition of valproate?

choices.text: Increased levels of free drug in plasma

questions.solution:
The addition of valproate to a patient who is already on phenytoin therapy would result in increased levels of free phenytoin in the plasma.

Valproate can increase the levels of unbound phenytoin in the plasma in two ways. Both valproate and phenytoin are extensive plasma protein-bound drugs. The addition of valproate can compete and displace phenytoin from plasma proteins and result in increased levels of free drug in circulation. Valproate is also an enzyme inhibitor which thereby decreases the metabolism of phenytoin by the liver cytochrome enzymes.

Displacement of phenytoin from plasma proteins can occur due to other factors like hyperbilirubinemia and other extensive plasma protein-bound drugs like warfarin. Usually increased free levels of phenytoin do not result in toxicity unless associated with a concomitant decrease in its metabolism as seen in cases of valproate therapy.

Phenytoin has a lot of drug interactions. Phenytoin itself is an inducer of CYP2C8/9 & CYP3A4/5 and an inhibitor of CYP2C9/19 enzymes. Thus it can interfere with the metabolism of a lot of other drugs.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient came to urology OPD with incomplete voiding of urine and increased frequency of urination. After a complete workup, the urologist decided to perform a prostatectomy by Millin's approach. Which of the following indicates this approach in the given image?
questions.solution:
Option 2 is the Millin's or retropubic approach for prostate surgery.

In this approach, using a low, curved transverse suprapubic Pfannenstiel incision, the recti are split in the midline and retracted to expose the bladder. With the patient in the Trendelenburg position, the surgeon separates the bladder and the prostate from the posterior aspect of the pubis. In this approach the exposure of the inside of the prostatic cavity is good. However, this procedure is rarely performed nowadays as HOLEP (Holmium laser enucleation of the prostate) has largely superseded it. Open surgery may be performed in situations where HOLEP is not available or where diverticulectomy or the removal of large stones is required.

Other options:

Option A: 1 - Transurethral approach (TURP) is the most commonly used approach

Option C: 3 - The transvesical approach is called the Freyer approach.

Option D: 4 - The prineal approach is also called the Young's approach.

questions.text: What is the phenomenon seen in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the phenomenon of emperipolesis.

Emperipolesis is a condition wherein hematopoietic cells in a living and intact state are seen in the cytoplasm of a host cell without any damage. The cells frequently involved are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. 

In phagocytosis, the engulfed cells are dead or dying cells or other materials floating around the extracellular space.

Histopathologic characters:

  • The engulfed cell is enclosed in a membrane-bound vacuole in the cytoplasm of the host cell.
  • Internalized cells appear to continue living within the host cell for brief periods of time. Sometimes, they even undergo division within the vacuole.

Other options- 

Option A: Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type. While cells that are internalized by this mechanism are initially viable with the majority of them undergoing a non-apoptotic form of cell death.

Option B: Necroptosis has features similar to necrosis and apoptosis. Like necrosis, it is characterized by loss of ATP, cellular and organelle swelling, the release of lysosomal enzymes, and the rupture of the plasma membrane. However, like apoptosis, this is programmed cell death. Ligation of TNFR1 initiates necroptosis.

Option D: Pyroptosis is a form of programmed cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and microbe-infected cells. Cytoplasmic innate immune receptors recognize microbial products that have entered infected cells and activate the multiprotein complex called the inflammasome.

questions.text:
Which of the following pairs are correctly matched with regards to methylene blue - 3 swab test observation and its interpretation?
  1. The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - Ureterovaginal fistula
  2. The uppermost swab gets stained - Vesicovaginal fistula
  3. Middle swab and lowermost gets stained -  Vesicovaginal fistula
  4. Only lowermost swab gets stained - Urethrovaginal fistula
  5. Swabs don't take up the stain but get soaked with urine - Vesicovaginal fistula
questions.solution:
The correctly matched pairs are:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained -  ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab and lowermost swab gets stained - vesicovaginal fistula
  • Only the lowermost swab gets stained - urethrovaginal fistula

The 3-swab test is done to identify the type of genitourinary fistula. In this test, a catheter is introduced into the bladder through the urethra, and 50-100ml methylene blue is injected. The vaginal cavity is packed with three sterile cotton swabs. One at the vault, one at the middle, and one just above the introitus.

Interpretation:

  • The uppermost swab gets wet and not stained - the leak is from the ureter, seen in ureterovaginal fistula
  • The middle swab and the lowermost swab gets stained - the leak is from the bladder, seen in vesicovaginal fistula
  • Only the lowermost swab gets stained- the leak is from the urethra, seen in urethrovaginal fistula

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding thermogenin which is an uncoupler of the electron transport chain?

choices.text: It decreases the ATP:ADP ratio in the cell
It decreases the membrane permeability to H+ ions
It directly inhibits the ATP synthase enzyme
It decreases the production heat in the cell

questions.solution:
Thermogenin is a physiological uncoupler of the electron transport chain (ETC) thereby causing a decrease in ATP generation within the cell. This would lead to a decrease in the ATP:ADP ratio within the cell.

Uncouplers act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions (Option B), thereby collapsing the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex. 2, 4 dinitrophenol is a synthetic uncoupler. Thermogenin is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation (Option D), especially in newborns.  

Oligomycin is a competitive inhibitor of the Fo (oligomycin-sensitive) complex of ATP synthase (complex V) and blocks oxidative phosphorylation (Option C).

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: What is the intermediate host for the organism shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Ascaris lumbricoides (roundworm). It has no intermediate host.

It is the most common of human helminths and is distributed worldwide. Adult worms live in the small intestine (85% in the jejunum and 15% in the ileum). It is the largest nematode parasite in the human intestine.

The adult worms are large cylindrical worms, with tapering ends, the anterior end being more pointed than the posterior end. Man is the natural host. There is no intermediate host.

Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces containing eggs of Ascaris. The eggs contain the infective rhabditiform larva.

questions.text: The trigger to initiate the contractile process in skeletal muscle is:

choices.text: ATP binding to the myosin cross bridges

questions.solution:
The cytosolic calcium binds with troponin C and causes a conformational change in the protein to expose the actin-binding site for myosin resulting in the formation of myosin-actin cross-bridges and initiating the process of muscle contraction.

Muscle contraction occurs by sliding of thin filament (actin) over thick filament (myosin). The sequence of events are as follows: 

  • Troponin I is bound to actin and tropomyosin and covers the sites where actin interacts with myosin heads in a resting muscle. The myosin head contains tightly bound adenosine phosphate (ADP) and inorganic phosphate (Pi).
  • Following an action potential, cytosolic Ca2+ is increased due to the Ca2+ released from the sarcoplasmic reticulum.  Simultaneously Ca2+ influx happens through voltage-gated Ca2+ channels too. 
  • The free Ca2+ binds with troponin C. This binding will weaken the troponin I interaction with actin and exposes the actin-binding site for myosin.
    This results in the formation of myosin-actin cross-bridges. (Option A)
  • The cross-bridge between the head of the myosin and the active site of the actin causes a conformational change in the head and the power stroke occurs, moving the thin filament relative to the thick filament. 
  • Once the head of the cross-bridge tilts, the ADP and phosphate ion that were previously attached to the head are released and a new ATP molecule can bind in that place. (Option D)
  • The binding of the new ATP molecule to the free site on the myosin causes detachment of the head of the myosin from the actin. (Option C)
    ATP is hydrolyzed and Pi released, causing a re-cocking of the myosin head and completing the cycle. 

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic cough, weight loss, and low-grade fever presents with complaints suggestive of lower urinary tract infection. The intravenous urogram of the patient is shown below. What is the finding seen?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario exhibits symptoms consistent with tuberculous cystitis, including a mild fever and signs of a urinary tract infection. Tuberculous cystitis results in fibrosis and stiffening of the entire urinary bladder, leading to an inability to expand and a significant reduction in bladder capacity, as depicted in the figure. The medical term for this feature on the intravenous urogram is a thimble bladder. 

Tuberculous urinary infection is secondary to renal tuberculosis. Urinalysis reveals pus cells without organisms and urine culture is negative. Urodynamic studies show a reduced bladder volume.

Lesions caused by tuberculosis in the kidney include:

  • Papillary ulcer - earliest lesion
  • Pyonephrosis - caused by multiple scattered papillary ulcers undergoing caseous necrosis, which later become filled with pus
  • Perinephric abscess -  by extension of pyonephrosis or tuberculous renal abscess
  • Pseudocalculi - occurs when calcium gets deposited in a papillary ulcer healed with fibrosis
  • Ghost calyces - caused by the destruction of the calyces
  • Thimble bladder -Entire urinary bladder gets fibrosed, stiff, and unable to dilate and accommodate urine (IV urogram finding).
  • Golf hole ureteric orifice -  This is due to fibrosis causing rigid withdrawn dilated ureteric orifice to look like a golf hole (cystoscopic finding).
  • Putty/cement kidney - amorphous dystrophic calcification eventually involves the entire kidney (seen in X-ray and CT

 

Patients usually respond to anti-tubercular drugs. If bladder volume is greatly reduced, bladder augmentation surgery (ileocystoplasty or caecocystoplasty) is done to avoid the risk of upper tract damage due to high filling pressure and vesicoureteric reflux.

 

Other options:

Option A: Pine cone or Christmas tree appearance, in which the bladder is elongated and pointed with a thickened trabeculated wall, is seen in cases of neurogenic bladder.

 

Option C: Tear-drop shaped bladder or a pear-shaped bladder is one whose normal round or ovoid shape has been extrinsically compressed by pelvic tissue (eg. pelvic hematoma, pelvic lipomatosis, etc) to resemble a pear or a tear. 

 

Option D: Sunburst appearance of the bladder is seen in extraperitoneal bladder rupture.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding developmental milestones.
  1. Object permanence is achieved at 1 year of age
  2. Binocular vision is well established by 4 months of age
  3. Vocalization not attained at 7 months of age is a red flag sign
  4. Sitting without support not attained at 1 year of age is a red flag sign
  5. Lifting the head on ventral suspension is not attained at 4 weeks of age
questions.solution:
Statements 2, 3, 4, and 5 are correct regarding developmental milestones. 

Binocular vision, the ability to use both eyes together, begins at approximately 6 weeks and becomes well-established by 4 months. By 6 months, children start adjusting their positions to keep track of objects of interest, and by 1 year, they can follow rapidly moving objects.

When an important developmental milestone crosses the upper age limit to develop, it is considered a red flag sign. The upper age limit to attain vocalization as a language milestone is 6 months. The upper age limit to attain sitting without support as a gross motor milestone is 10 months. A child needs to be evaluated for developmental delay if they do not attain the milestones by this age. 

On ventral suspension, a child is unable to lift the head until 4 weeks of age. At 6 weeks, the child momentarily holds the head in a horizontal plane. By 8 weeks, they can maintain this position well. By 12 weeks, they can lift their head above the horizontal plane.

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when it is not seen. It starts to develop by 7 months of age as an infant persists in searching for lost objects. It is well established by 9 months of age (statement 1).

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman was admitted for right knee arthroplasty. On the 7th postoperative day, she developed a fever and cough with purulent, blood-tinged sputum. Her chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following would be the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the chest-Xray showing lobar consolidation with bulging fissure sign are suggestive of late-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia most likely caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or nosocomial pneumonia is a lower respiratory infection that presents clinically 2 or more days after hospitalization and was not there at the time of admission. It can further be classified as:

  • Early-onset HAP, which occurs within 4-5 days of admission and is commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Enterobacter species, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Late-onset HAP occurs >5 days after hospital admission and is usually caused by gram-negative bacteria like Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Klebsiella spp, and Acinetobacter baumannii.

Pneumonia caused by Klebsiella species shows the following classic chest X-ray findings:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows a bulging fissure sign.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be used for treatment and include third-generation cephalosporins and beta-lactam antibiotics with beta-lactamase inhibitors. Nosocomial infection with Klebsiella is difficult to treat in many situations as they produce extended-spectrum beta-lactamase and are resistant to many antibiotics.

Other options:

Option B: Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative agent of community-acquired pneumonia.

Option C: Legionella pneumophila causes community-acquired pneumonia and early-onset hospital-acquired pneumonia.

Option D: Coxiella burnetii is the causative agent of Q-fever.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old child presented with complaints of recurrent respiratory infections, skin purpura, and eczema. She is currently undergoing evaluation for Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. Which immunoglobulins are elevated in this condition?
  1. IgA
  2. IgM
  3. IgG
  4. IgE
  5. IgD
questions.solution:
The immunoglobulins elevated in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome are IgA and IgE (option B).

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is an X-linked recessive disease characterized by thrombocytopenia (resulting in bleeding diathesis such as skin purpura), eczema, and recurrent infections. It is caused by a mutation in the gene located at Xp11.23, which encodes the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASP).

The disease is characterized by low serum IgM levels. The serum IgG levels are usually normal. The levels of IgA and IgE are elevated. Patients are at an increased risk for B-cell lymphomas.

The thymus appears normal in the early course of the disease, but there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood and the T-cell zones (paracortical areas) of the lymph nodes, resulting in variable defects in cellular immunity.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency room in a comatose state. He weighs around 70 kg. On examination, his serum glucose levels were found to be 500 mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.33, with increased plasma ketone levels. His serum potassium levels are normal. What is the bolus dose of insulin that should be administered immediately to this patient?

choices.text: 7 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously
7 units of short acting insulin subcutaneously
14 units of short acting insulin intravenously
14 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient is likely to have diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The dose of insulin that should be immediately administered to this patient is 0.1 units per kg. Since the patient weighs around 70 Kg he should be administered 7 units intravenously.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, thirst/polyuria, severe abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. It is precipitated by various events like inadequate insulin administration, infection (pneumonia/UTI/ gastroenteritis/sepsis), infarction (cerebral, coronary, mesenteric, peripheral), drugs (cocaine), and pregnancy.

Clinical signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid breathing)
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath (acetone breath)
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250–600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia - there is a 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis.
  • Osmolality – 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones – positive
  • Metabolic acidosis – increased anion gap (HAGMA)
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L – best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

The algorithm for the management of DKA is shown below.

questions.text: What is the sequence of clamping of structures in vaginal hysterectomy?
questions.solution:
The sequence of clamping of structures in vaginal hysterectomy is Uterosacral ligament-Cardinal ligament-Uterine artery-Round ligament.

The sequence of clamping of structure in vaginal hysterectomy

  • First clamp includes the uterosacral ligament, Mackenrodt’s ligament, and descending cervical artery
  • Second clamp includes the uterine artery and the base of the broad ligament
  • Third clamp includes the round ligament, fallopian tube, mesosalpinx, and ligament of the ovary

The sequence of clamping of structures in abdominal hysterectomy

  • First clamp includes the round ligament and infundibulopelvic ligament (when ovaries are to be removed)
  • Second clamp includes the uterine artery
  • Third clamp includes the cardinal ligament and uterosacral ligament

Note: In vaginal hysterectomy, the uterosacral ligament is clamped before the Mackenrodt (cardinal) ligament, whereas, in abdominal hysterectomy, the Mackenrodt (cardinal) ligament is clamped before the uterosacral ligament.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man who is a known case of diverticulosis presents to the emergency department with complaints of acute abdominal pain. Patient is vitally unstable and abdominal guarding and rigidity is present. During laparotomy, gross feculent deposits with yellow exudates are seen over the peritoneum. What is the stage and the management of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
Fecal peritonitis in a patient with a history of diverticulosis belongs to Stage 4 in the Hinchey's staging system. Gross feculent contamination in a young patient who is vitally unstable is managed with Hartmann's procedure.

Resection with primary anastomosis (Option B) may be performed (with or without a diverting proximal stoma) in young fit patients, if gross contamination or overwhelming sepsis is absent.

Diverticula are saccular outpouchings of the bowel wall. Diverticulosis refers to the presence of diverticula without inflammation. Diverticulitis refers to inflammation and infection associated with a diverticulum. The majority of patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic or present with distension, flatulence, and a sensation of heaviness in the lower abdomen. Diverticulosis can present with complications like diverticulitis, abscess, peritonitis, intestinal obstruction, hemorrhage, or fistula formation. 

Hinchey's classification is used to describe the severity and complication of acute diverticulitis, as follows:

Hinchey's Classification
Stage 1 Mesenteric or pericolic abscess
Stage 2 Pelvic abscess
Stage 3 Purulent peritonitis (Options A, C)
Stage 4 Fecal peritonitis

 

The management is as follows:

  Diverticulosis
  • High fiber diet
  • Bulk-forming laxatives
  • Antispasmodics for recurrent pain
Uncomplicated diverticulitis
  • IV antibiotics
  • Bowel rest
Small abscess (< 2-5 cms)
  • IV antibiotics
Larger abscess
  • CT-guided percutaneous drainage
  • IV antibiotics
Peritonitis or peritoneal soiling

Washout of the contamination followed by Hartmann’s procedure - segmental resection of the diseased colon and a proximal end-colostomy with the closure of the distal rectal stump (Hartmann’s pouch). 

Resection with primary anastomosis may be performed in young fit patients who are vitally stable, and signs of gross contamination or sepsis are not present.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the 6 x 6 x 6 strategy employed by the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program?
questions.solution:
Among the listed options, 6 testing methods are not a part of the 6x6x6 strategy employed by the Anemia Mukt Bharat Program.

The Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. The 6 x 6 x 6 strategy represents:

  • 6 beneficiaries (option A)
  • 6 interventions (option C)
  • 6 institutional mechanisms (option D)

The 6 beneficiaries include:

  1. Preschool children (6-59 months of age)
  2. Children (5-9 years of age)
  3. Adolescents (10-19 years of age)
  4. Pregnant women
  5. Lactating mothers
  6. Young women in the reproductive age group (20-24 years of age)

The 6 interventions include:

  1. Prophylactic iron and folic acid supplementation
  2. Deworming
  3. Intensified year-round “behavior change communication campaign”
  4. Testing of anemia using digital methods and point-of-care treatment
  5. Mandatory provision of iron and folic acid-fortified foods in government-funded health programs
  6. Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia in endemic pockets, with a special focus on malaria, hemoglobinopathies, and fluorosis

The 6 institutional mechanisms include: 

  1. Intra-ministerial coordination
  2. National Anemia Mukt Bharat unit
  3. National Center of Excellence and Advanced Research on Anemia Control
  4. Convergence with other ministries
  5. Strengthening supply chain and logistics
  6. Digital Anemia Mukt Bharat dashboard and online portal

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the OPD with palpitations and tremors. He mentions that he has had similar episodes for the past 2 months and feels better after eating food. He gives a history of a recent change in his diabetic medication. The blood sugar level is measured to be 60mg/dL. What is the cause of these symptoms in this case?

choices.text: Inhibition of reabsorption of glucose from PCT
Blocking of ATP sensitive potassium channels

questions.solution:
The given scenario of a diabetic patient experiencing episodes of palpitations and tremors following a recent change in medication and blood glucose levels of 60mg/dL suggests hypoglycemic episodes occurring as a side effect of sulfonylureas. Blocking of ATP-sensitive potassium channels is the cause of the symptoms in this case.

Sulfonylureas act by closing the ATP-sensitive K+ channels in the beta-cells of the pancreas. This closure causes cell membrane depolarization and the release of insulin. They are readily absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and therefore can be given orally. Important sulfonylureas are glimepiride, glipizide, glyburide, etc.

Important adverse effects are hypoglycemia, vomiting, cholestatic jaundice, agranulocytosis, and aplastic and hemolytic anemias. They can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction. They should be used with caution in pregnancy, lactation, and significant hepatic or renal insufficiency (for the older forms).

Other options:

Option A: Acarbose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor. It reduces the intestinal absorption of glucose by inhibiting the intestinal brush border enzyme, alpha-glucosidase. They reduce post-prandial glucose levels and thus don't cause hypoglycemia.

Option B: Sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitors such as canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, and empagliflozin act by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter present on the proximal segment of the renal tubule. The common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the high glucose content of the urine. 

Option D: Metformin is a biguanide that acts by activation of AMP-dependent protein kinase activation. It mediates a series of actions that helps in reducing hepatic gluconeogenesis. It does not affect the blood glucose levels in normoglycemic states and hence does not cause hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A young man presents with chest pain and breathlessness. Work-up revealed ventricular dilatation and a low ejection fraction on echo. He gives a history of heart disease in the family. Which of the following cardiac histological findings can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young man presenting with chest pain and breathlessness and an echo showing ventricular dilatation with a low ejection fraction, along with a positive family history, is suggestive of familial dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM). Cardiac histology, in this case, would reveal ninja-star nuclei in myocytes.

Familial DCM is most commonly associated with truncation mutation of the TTN gene, which codes for the intra-sarcomeric protein titin. The genetic forms follow the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance with variable penetrance. Histological examinations of cardiac myocytes may reveal nuclei that are hyperchromatic and highly distorted, resembling ninja stars (as shown below).

DCM is characterized by both morphological and functional progressive dilatation of the heart along with systolic dysfunction. It results in the gradual development of congestive heart failure with clinical features of dyspnea, fatigue, chest pain, and peripheral pitting edema.

Other options:

Option A: Contraction band necrosis can be seen in reperfusion injury following myocardial infarction. It is also a histological feature observed in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Histology reveals irreversibly injured myocytes and intensely eosinophilic bands of hypercontracted sarcomeres, as depicted below.

 

Option C: Haphazard disarray of myofibrils is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. It is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy and diastolic dysfunction. Histological findings of myofiber disarray is shown below. 

 

Option D: Hyaline, amorphous eosinophilic deposits on histology are associated with cardiac amyloidosis. It results in restrictive cardiomyopathy with stiffened myocardial walls causing diastolic dysfunction. Transthyretin is the major component of cardiac amyloid deposits. Histological findings of cardiac amyloidosis are shown below.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the casualty following a fall on his hand during a football match. He complains of pain and inability to move his right shoulder. On examination, flattening of the shoulder contour and inability to touch his opposite shoulder are noted. He was managed using the method shown below. Identify the procedure shown.
questions.solution:
The history of a fall on his hand, loss of shoulder contour, and a positive Dugas test (inability to touch the opposite shoulder) are all suggestive of anterior shoulder dislocation and the image shows Kocher's technique of reduction.

Kocher's technique- It is the most commonly used method for the reduction of anterior shoulder dislocation. It involves four steps: 

Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation (TEAM)

  • Steady traction is applied along the long axis of the humerus with the elbow flexed to a right angle
  • Then the arm is externally rotated
  • This is followed by the adduction of the externally rotated arm
  • Finally, internal rotation is done.

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder:

It is the most common type of shoulder dislocation which results due to a fall on an outstretched hand in an abducted and externally rotated shoulder. The patient usually presents with an abducted shoulder, with his elbow being supported by the opposite hand, and complains of pain and inability to move the affected shoulder.

The following findings are seen on examination:

  • Flattening of the normal shoulder contour.
  • A displaced head can be felt as a fullness below the clavicle.
  • Dugas test: Inability to touch the opposite shoulder
  • Hamilton ruler test: A ruler placed on the lateral side of the arm touches the acromion and lateral condyle of the humerus simultaneously due to the flattening of the shoulder.
  • Regiment badge sign: Area of anesthesia around the deltoid due to injury to the axillary nerve
  • Byrant's test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level.

Complications include injury to the axillary nerve and recurrent shoulder dislocation.

Other options:

Allis technique/maneuver is used for the reduction of posterior hip dislocation.

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes. 

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side.

questions.text:
Which of the following medications should be withdrawn before initiating electroconvulsive therapy (ECT)?
  1. Lithium
  2. Tricyclic antidepressant
  3. Benzodiazepine
  4. Monoamine oxidase inhibitor
  5. Bupropion
questions.solution:
Lithium, benzodiazepine, and bupropion (1, 3, 5) should be discontinued before initiating electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).

Before initiating electroconvulsive therapy, certain drugs that affect seizure induction, the seizure threshold or interact with drugs used during ECT should be withdrawn.

Lithium should be stopped because it can lead to postictal delirium and can prolong seizure activity. 

Benzodiazepines used for anxiety should be withdrawn because of their anticonvulsant activity.

Clozapine and bupropion should be withdrawn because they are associated with of late-appearing seizures.

Other drugs that are contraindicated for concomitant use include lidocaine and reserpine.

Tricyclic antidepressants, monoamine oxidase inhibitors and antipsychotics are generally considered acceptable for concomitant use.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: A male neonate of a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. On auscultation, an ejection systolic murmur was heard at the left mid-sternal border. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray showing an egg-on-string appearance is suggestive of transposition of great arteries (TGA). 

TGA is cyanotic congenital heart disease and is commonly seen in infants of diabetic mothers and in male babies. It is characterized by the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery originating from the left ventricle. 

Since systemic and pulmonary circulations are separate, survival depends on the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood. This occurs via the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus in the newborn period, and also via ventricular septal defect (VSD) that is present in about 50% of infants with TGA.

 

It is a medical emergency and most infants present with cyanosis and tachypnea shortly after birth. The level of hypoxia varies depending on the degree of atrial shunt and if the ductus is partially closed or open. Loud single or split S2 and a soft systolic ejection murmur may be heard at the mid-left sternal border. 

Chest X-ray shows a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, therefore appearing like an egg. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the characteristic finding of an egg-on-a-string appearance as shown below.

 

ECG may show right axis deviation. Echocardiography with doppler is confirmatory and shows the transposed ventricular-arterial connections and their size, ductus arteriosus, and the degree of mixing of blood. 

Since the mixing of oxygenated pulmonary blood and deoxygenated systemic blood is essential for these patients, early management includes an immediate infusion of prostaglandin E1 which keeps the ductus arteriosus patent for improving oxygenation. Rashkind balloon atrial septostomy can be done to improve the hypoxic state.
 
Other options: 

Option A: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins that results in total pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium instead of normally joining the left atrium. In supracardiac type of TAPVC, the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign as shown below. 

 

Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by the tetrad of:

  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

In the TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot on the X-ray as shown below.

 

Option C: Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease with diminished pulmonary blood flow due to abnormality of the tricuspid valve. It can occur due to the teratogenic effect of lithium. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium leading to an elevated apex giving a box-shaped heart as shown below. 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Congenital Heart Diseases

Anomaly Sign
Tetralogy of Fallot Coeur en sabot
Transposition of great vessels (TGV) Egg on string
Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return Scimitar sign
Total anomalous pulmonary venous return Snowman sign
Endocardial cushion defects Gooseneck sign
Ebstein anomaly Box-shaped heart

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text: The following wound is discovered on a victim’s body at a crime scene. What is the type of wound and the likely weapon causing it?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a wound with irregular margins, inward bevelling of the margin, associated with burning and blackening of the skin. This is suggestive of an entry wound from a revolver. 

Firearm wounds are of two fundamental types: wounds of entry, through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and wounds of exit, through which the bullet emerges out of the body.

Entry wounds from a revolver are characterized by the presence of bruising, abrasion, and grease collar. The edge of an entry wound is inverted. Abrasion collar results from friction between the gyrating bullet and the inverted epidermis of the skin. It may be surrounded by a black-colored ring of grease collar due to bullet wipe soiling. Burning, blackening, or tattooing may also be seen around an entry wound. 

Other options:

Option B: An entry wound of a shotgun from a mid-range or long-distance shows a central round hole, with multiple pellet holes scattered around the central hole (demonstrated below).

Option C: Usually shotguns do not have an exit wound except in contact wounds, or tangential wounds.

Option D: Exit wounds from revolvers are larger than entry wounds. The edges are everted with the absence of bruising, abrasion, and grease collar. The image given below shows an exit wound from a revolver:

questions.text: Post-mortem examination of a stillborn shows polydactyly, a cleft lip and cleft palate, and a single eye. Further examination reveals fused frontal lobes with a single ventricle. Which of the following chromosomal abnormalities is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
The given findings of polydactyly, a cleft lip and cleft palate, a single eye, fused frontal lobes with a single ventricle (holoprosencephaly) in a stillborn are consistent with trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome).

Trisomy 13, or Patau syndrome, is characterized by forebrain and midline facial abnormalities. Patients can develop holoprosencephaly, which is characterized by fused frontal lobes and a single ventricle. Olfactory bulbs are also absent. The midline facial abnormalities seen with trisomy 13 include cleft lip, cleft palate, nasal defects, and a single central eye (“cyclops”). Other defects include polydactyly, rocker-bottom feet, renal defects, and congenital heart diseases.

The image below shows some characteristic findings of Patau syndrome:

 

Other options:

Option A: Deletion involving chromosome 22 (22q11.2 deletion) causes DiGeorge syndrome. It is associated with the absence of the thymus, which leads to cell-mediated immune deficiencies. The absence of the parathyroids leads to hypocalcemia. Associated velocardiofacial defects include facial dysmorphism, cleft palate, and cardiovascular anomalies.

Option C: Trisomy 18 or Edwards syndrome is characterized by mental retardation, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers: the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. It is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.

Option D: Trisomy 21, or Down syndrome, is the most common chromosomal abnormality. Children with Down syndrome have severe mental retardation. They have characteristic facial features, including a flat profile, oblique palpebral fissures, and prominent epicanthic folds. There is a horizontal palmar crease and decreased muscle tone at birth that leads to a “floppy baby."

questions.text: A man presents with abdominal pain and a soft swelling in the mid-abdomen, movable in the direction shown in the image below. Which of the following is not a component of the characteristic triad seen in this condition?

choices.text: Zone of resonance around the cyst

questions.solution:
The given image showing a swelling that is mobile perpendicular to the attachment of the mesentery. This is known as a positive Tillaux sign and is suggestive of a mesenteric cyst. Transillumination is not included in Tillaux’s triad for mesenteric cysts.

The most common presentation is a painless abdominal swelling in the umbilical region with the characteristic triad of physical signs (Tillaux’s triad):

  • Fluctuant swelling near the umbilicus (Option A)
  • Swelling moves freely in a plane at right angles to the attachment of the mesentery, ie, positive Tillaux’s sign (Option B)
  • Presence of zone of resonance around the cyst (Option D)

Mesenteric cysts occur either in the mesentery adjoining the small intestine (60%) or the colon (40%) and can be classified as the following:

  • Chylolymphatic cysts - most common type
  • Enterogenous cysts
  • Traumatic cysts
  • Hydatid cysts

 

Ultrasonography and computed tomography (CT) scans are used to diagnose mesenteric cysts.

Chylolymphatic cysts have their independent blood supply, allowing for complete excision by enucleation. In comparison, enterogenous cysts share their blood supply with the surrounding bowel and therefore removal of the cyst entails resection of the related portion of the intestine.
